passage_content: ‎והנה עיקר החיות של הצדיק היא ע"י התפילה שעל ידה הוא מתדבק בהבורא יתעלה כנ"ל, וידוע שע"י שם הקדוש היוצא מפסוק 'את 'השמים 'ואת 'הארץ נברא העולם, והוא גימטריה טו"ב, ועיקר תפילת הצדיק היא על השכינה הקדושה, וזהו "ויחי יעקב בארץ מצרים", 'מצרים' לשון מיצר ים, דהיינו ע"י שהיה מצער עצמו על גלות השכינה הנקראת 'ים', עי"ז היה לו חיות שהיה מתדבק בהבורא ב"ה, "שבע עשרה שנה", פירוש שכל זאת היה בכח הא"ס בתחילת הבריאה כשברא כל הנבראים וכל עולמות ע"י שם הקדוש שהוא גימטריה י"ז כנ"ל שבו נברא העולם.
translation: And behold, the essence of the vitality of the righteous is through prayer, by which he cleaves to the Creator, blessed be He, as mentioned above. It is known that through the holy Name that comes from the verse "the heavens and the earth," the world was created, and it has the gematria of good (טו"ב). The main prayer of the righteous is for the holy Shechinah, and this is "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt." 'Egypt' is a term for the straits of the sea, meaning that by constraining himself over the exile of the Shechinah, which is called 'sea,' he thereby had vitality by cleaving to the Creator, blessed be He, "seventeen years," meaning that all of this was through the Infinite Light at the beginning of creation when He created all the created beings and all worlds through the holy Name, which has the gematria of seventeen, as mentioned above, through which the world was created.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the vitality of the righteous (tzaddik) is derived from prayer, which facilitates their connection to the Creator. It highlights the significance of the holy name associated with the creation of the world, represented by the gematria of "טו"ב" (good), and the tzaddik's primary focus in prayer is on the Divine Presence (Shechinah). The reference to Jacob's life in Egypt symbolizes the tzaddik's self-affliction due to the exile of the Shechinah, which in turn grants them spiritual vitality and connection to the Infinite (Ein Sof). The mention of "seventeen years" relates to the divine power present at the beginning of creation, underscoring the connection between the tzaddik's prayer and the foundational aspects of existence.

passage_content: ‎וזהו "ברוך ה' אשר לא הסיר תפילתי" שאני מתפלל, לא הסיר אותה ממני מחמת שהיה אז בכח הא"ס ב"ה וממילא היא מקובלת, "וחסדו מאתי", פירוש ועל כל זאת אודה יה, מאחר שהיה התפילה הזאת בכח הא"ס, נמצא שאין זה מחמתי מצד פעולתי שיהיה ראוי להנתן לי שכר על זה, ואעפ"כ נותן לי השי"ת שכר כאילו היתה הפעולה ממני, "וזהו וחסדו מאתי", שאודה לו ית"ש על חסדו הגדול שמעלה עלי כאילו היה מאתי. והבן.
translation: And this is "Blessed is the Lord who has not removed my prayer" that I pray, He has not removed it from me because at that time it was in the power of the Infinite Blessed Be He, and therefore it is accepted, "and His kindness is from me," meaning that for all this I will give thanks to Hashem, since this prayer was in the power of the Infinite, it turns out that it is not because of my actions that I am worthy of receiving a reward for this, and nevertheless the Holy One, Blessed be He, gives me a reward as if the action were from me, "and this is His kindness from me," that I will thank Him, Blessed be He, for His great kindness that He elevates upon me as if it were from me. And understand.
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept of divine grace in prayer, highlighting that the efficacy of one's prayers stems from the infinite power of the Divine (א"ס). It suggests that even though the prayer is accepted due to this divine influence rather than personal merit, God still rewards the individual as if the action originated from them. This reflects a profound understanding of the relationship between human effort and divine benevolence, underscoring the importance of gratitude for God's kindness. Ultimately, it illustrates the interplay between divine grace and human agency in the spiritual experience.

passage_content: או יאמר "ויחי כו'" ע"פ הפסוק "זמרו כבוד שמו שימו כבוד תהלתו", נראה פירושו היות התחלות אדם בעבדות הבורא ב"ה בוודאי אינו יכול תיכף בהתחלתו [ל]עלות במדרגת עליונים, כי עדיין סבבוהו זרים במחשבתו הדבוקה בעוה"ז השפל ובהבליו, אבל צריך אדם מקודם לפנות מחשבתו ולזמר עריצים, המה הקליפות המבלבלים אותו מעבודתו, ולזה צריך עבודה רבה, ואח"כ יפנה עצמו לעלות במחשבת קדושים ביחודים וכוונות עליונים, ואז נחשב לו אותה העבודה שעבד בתחילתו והיא לזמר עריצים כאותה העבודה החשובה העיקרית שעולה בה לתכליתו, כיון שכוונתו הכל לשם שמים והכל אחד, וזהו "זמרו כבוד וכו'", פירושו כנ"ל שהעבודה של זמיר עריצים הוא חשוב כמו "שימו כבוד תהלתו", ש'תהלה' נקרא המדריגה הגדולה של הצדיק שמאיר לעולמות עליונים, ותהלה הוא לשון אור, כמו עטישותיו תהל אור.
translation: Or he may say "And he lived, etc." based on the verse "Sing the glory of His name; make His praise glorious." It seems that the interpretation is that the beginnings of a person in the service of the Creator, blessed be He, certainly cannot immediately rise to the level of the exalted ones, for he is still surrounded by foreign thoughts, attached to this lowly world and its vanities. However, a person must first direct his thoughts and sing to the tyrants, which are the klipot that confuse him from his service. For this, much effort is required, and afterwards he can turn himself to ascend in the thoughts of the holy ones with unifications and lofty intentions. Then, that work he performed at the beginning, which is to sing to the tyrants, is considered the same important primary work that elevates him to his purpose, since his intention is all for the sake of Heaven and everything is one. And this is "Sing the glory, etc.," meaning as mentioned above that the work of singing to the tyrants is as important as "Make His praise glorious," for 'praise' refers to the great level of the righteous that illuminates the higher worlds, and 'praise' is a term of light, as in "His praises are the light of illumination."
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of initial struggles in divine service, where a person must first confront and overcome distractions represented by "z'ra'zim" (the forces of negativity) before ascending to higher spiritual levels. This process requires significant effort, and the work of battling these distractions is considered as valuable as the ultimate spiritual achievements. The concept of "z'miro" (singing) is linked to the glorification of God's name, suggesting that even the most humble beginnings in service can lead to profound spiritual elevation when performed with the right intention. Ultimately, all efforts, regardless of their initial nature, contribute to the individual's spiritual journey and connection to the divine.

passage_content: ‎וזהו ג"כ הפירוש כאן, "ויחי יעקב בארץ מצרים", ששם היה עבודתו במדריגת קטנות, וזה רמז "שבע עשרה שנה" גימטריה טו"ב, שהוא השם הקדוש במספר קטן, מחמת שהיה בארץ מצרים מקום הקליפות והיה עיקר העבדות לזמר עריצים, אעפ"כ היה נחשב לו זה כשאר שנותיו שהיה עובד בהם במדריגת גדלות, וזהו "ויהי ימי יעקב שני חייו", פירוש שזה היה נחשב לו במנין שאר שנותיו בשוה כנ"ל.
translation: And this is also the interpretation here, "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," that there his service was at the level of katnut (smallness), and this hints at "seventeen years," which is the gematria of טוב (good), the holy name in a small number, because in the land of Egypt, which was a place of klipot (shells), the main servitude was to the tyrants. Nevertheless, this was considered to him like the other years in which he served at the level of gadlut (greatness), and this is "And the days of Jacob, the years of his life," meaning that this was counted for him in the tally of his other years equally, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses Jacob's life in Egypt, highlighting that despite being in a place of spiritual diminishment (symbolized by the "seventeen years" which equals the gematria of "טו"ב" - good), Jacob's service to God was still considered significant. It emphasizes that even in the challenging environment of Egypt, where he faced the influence of negative forces, his devotion was counted equally with his years of spiritual elevation. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that true service to God can transcend external circumstances and maintain its value. Ultimately, Jacob's life in Egypt is viewed as a continuation of his spiritual journey, affirming the idea that every moment of devotion is meaningful.

passage_content: או יאמר "ימי יעקב שני חייו כו'", לפי שעיקר החיות של הצדיק הם אותן הימים שמוסיף בהם אור העבודה, והם נקראים 'ימים' ע"ד שנאמר "ויקרא אלהים לאור יום", וזהו "ויהי ימי יעקב", פירוש הימים שהיה מוסיף בהם אור, הם היו עיקר "שני חייו". וק"ל.
translation: Or he may say, "The days of Jacob, the years of his life, etc.", because the essence of the vitality of the tzaddik is those days in which he adds light to his service, and they are called 'days' as it is stated, "And God called the light Day." And this is "And the days of Jacob were," meaning the days in which he added light, they were the essence of "the years of his life." And it is clear.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the essence of a righteous person's life, particularly that of Jacob, is defined by the days in which they enhance their spiritual work and bring forth light. These days are referred to as "days" in a deeper sense, akin to the creation of light in the biblical narrative. Thus, Jacob's life is characterized by the moments he contributed to spiritual illumination, which are considered the true essence of his years. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that the value of life is measured by one's spiritual achievements and the light they bring into the world.

passage_content: או יאמר "ויחי כו'", ונקדים לפרש הפסוק "הודו לה' כי טוב כו'", דהנה הצדיק ע"י תפילתו הזכה והצלולה הוא ממשיך את הבורא ב"ה וב"ש לעוה"ז, והרי הוא כמו שמביא שמו הגדול אל הקטנות, כי עיקר גדולתו על השמים כבודו, וגדולתו על כל העולמות, והצדיק ממשיכו לזה העולם הוא כמו קטנות, והשם הקדוש בקטנות גימטריה י"ז, אך עי"ז שממשיך את הבורא לעוה"ז אזי מלאה הארץ חסדו בהשפעות וברכות וטובות הרבה, וזה "הודו לה'", היינו שתתפללו לפניו והודו לו, "כי טוב", ר"ל הגם שתביאו אותו ית"ש ויתעלה כמו אל הקטנות, דהיינו השם הקדוש הויה ב"ה בקטנות גימטריה טוב כנ"ל, "כי לעולם חסדו", ר"ל כי עי"ז תפעלו להמשיך לעוה"ז חסדו, היינו השפעות חסדים וטובות.
translation: Or he may say "And he lived, etc.", and we will begin to explain the verse "Give thanks to the Lord for He is good, etc." Behold, the righteous, through his pure and clear prayer, draws down the Creator, blessed be He, and exalted be He, to this world. He is like one who brings His great name to the smallness, for His main greatness is "His glory is above the heavens," and His greatness is over all the worlds. The righteous who brings Him to this world is like smallness, and the holy name in smallness has the gematria of 17. However, by drawing down the Creator to this world, the earth is filled with His kindness through influences, blessings, and many good things. This is "Give thanks to the Lord," meaning that you should pray before Him and give thanks to Him, "for He is good," meaning that even though you bring Him, blessed be He and exalted be He, like to the smallness, that is to say, the holy name Havayah, blessed be He, in smallness has the gematria of good, as mentioned. "For His kindness endures forever," meaning that through this you will cause to draw down to this world His kindness, which is influences of kindness and good things.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author emphasizes the role of the tzaddik (righteous person) in connecting the divine presence to the physical world through pure and sincere prayer. The tzaddik brings the greatness of God into the realm of the small, symbolizing the divine's accessibility and the flow of blessings into the world. The verse "Give thanks to the Lord for He is good" reflects the idea that through prayer and acknowledgment of God's goodness, one can draw down His kindness and blessings into the world, highlighting the eternal nature of God's mercy. Ultimately, the passage illustrates the profound relationship between the tzaddik's actions, divine presence, and the manifestation of God's goodness in the world.

passage_content: ‎וזהו "ויחי יעקב בארץ מצרים שבע עשרה שנה", ר"ל ע"י שם הקדוש שהמשיך למטה והוא גימטריה י"ז כנ"ל, עי"ז היה לו חיות והשפעות טובות בארץ מצרים. וזהו "ברוך ה' אשר כו' וחסדו מאתי", דהיינו שע"י תפילתי אני גורם להמשיך חסדו לעולם כנ"ל. וק"ל.
translation: And this is "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years," meaning through the Holy Name that was drawn down below, which is the gematria of seventeen as mentioned above, through this he had vitality and good influences in the land of Egypt. And this is "Blessed is the Lord who... and His kindness is from me," meaning that through my prayer I cause the continuation of His kindness to the world as mentioned above. And it is clear.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of the holy name and its numerical value of seventeen (י"ז), which enabled Jacob to draw down vitality and positive influences during his time in Egypt. It highlights the connection between prayer and the ability to channel divine kindness into the world. The text reflects a Hasidic understanding of the interplay between human action and divine grace, illustrating how one's spiritual efforts can manifest blessings in the physical realm.

passage_content: או יאמר "ויחי יעקב כו'", דהנה ראוי להשכיל ולהבין על קבלת שכר המצוות, הנה מצד השכל והדין אינו מחמת קיום המצוות, כי מאחר שהבורא ית"ש ויתעלה בראנו לכבודו, ואין אנו מספיקים להודות על אחת מאלף כו' על הטובות כו' שעשה עמנו, וראוי ונכון היותינו מקיימים מצוותיו הקדושים כמאמר התנא "אם למדת תורה הרבה אל תחזיק כו' כי לכך נוצרת", אך עיקר קבלת שכרינו הוא מצד שהבורא ית"ש נתן בנו יצה"ר המסית אותנו בכל עת ורגע ומתגבר עלינו להתאוות תאוה ולהרהר חלילה בעבירה וכל יצר מחשבותיו רק רע כל היום, והאדם עומד כנגדו ובתחבולות יעשה מלחמה נגדו להזהר ולהשמר מכל דבר רע, מחניפות ושקרים וליצנות ולשון הרע ותאוות והרהורים והדומה להם, לזה צריך מלחמה ועבודה רבה לשבר כח התאוות היצה"ר, וזהו עינוי וסיגוף גדול, עי"ז הקב"ה מקדשו ומטהרו כאילו עשה מצוה, כי ע"י המצוות אנו מתקדשים ומתטהרים כאמור "אשר קדשנו במצותיו", וזהו דאמרינן בגמרא "היושב בטל ואינו עובר עבירה מעלה עליו הכתוב כאלו עשה מצוה", והיינו כנ"ל, ע"י שהוא משבר כח התאוה של היצה"ר שלא לחטוא חלילה עי"ז והוא מתקדש כאילו עשה מצוה.
translation: Or he may say, "And Jacob lived, etc." Behold, it is fitting to understand and comprehend the acceptance of reward for the commandments. From the perspective of intellect and law, it is not due to the fulfillment of the commandments, for since the Creator, blessed be He and exalted, created us for His honor, and we are not sufficient to thank Him for even one out of a thousand, etc., for the good things, etc., that He has done with us, it is fitting and proper for us to fulfill His holy commandments, as the Tanna said, "If you have learned much Torah, do not hold it as your own, for this is why you were created." However, the essence of our reward is because the Creator, blessed be He, has placed within us the evil inclination that entices us at every moment and strengthens itself over us to desire desires and to think, Heaven forbid, of sin, and every inclination of the thoughts of his heart is only evil all day long. And a person stands against it and, with cunning, makes war against it to be careful and to guard himself from all evil things, from flattery and lies, mockery, slander, desires, and thoughts similar to them. For this, a great struggle and much work is needed to break the power of the desires of the evil inclination, and this is a great affliction and suffering. Through this, the Holy One, blessed be He, sanctifies and purifies him as if he had performed a commandment, for through the commandments we are sanctified and purified, as it is said, "Who sanctified us with His commandments." And this is what we say in the Gemara, "One who sits idle and does not commit a sin, the Scripture considers it as if he had performed a commandment." And this is as mentioned above, for by breaking the power of the desire of the evil inclination not to sin, Heaven forbid, through this he is sanctified as if he had performed a commandment.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of reward for fulfilling commandments (mitzvot) from a Hasidic perspective, emphasizing that true merit arises not merely from performing mitzvot, but from the struggle against the evil inclination (yetzer hara). It highlights that the constant battle against temptation and sin is a significant form of spiritual work, akin to performing a mitzvah. The text asserts that by overcoming the yetzer hara, an individual is sanctified and purified, receiving divine recognition as if they had fulfilled a commandment. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of inner struggle and moral vigilance in the path of spiritual growth.

passage_content: ‎וזהו שהתפלל משה רבינו ע"ה "שמחינו כימות עניתנו", פירוש שתשמחנו בקדושתך כימות עניתנו ע"י היצה"ר שאנחנו מוכרחים לשבר כח תאוותו, "שנות ראינו רעה", פירוש כל השנים אשר ראינו והסתכלנו ברעה להזהר ולהשמר ממנו, עי"ז "יראה אל עבדיך פעליך", ר"ל יחשב לפניך כאילו עשינו כל מצוותיך ופעליך, כנ"ל שע"י עינויים וסיגופים מהיצה"ר לשבר כחו, יחשב כאילו עשיתי כל המצוות.
translation: And this is what our teacher Moses, peace be upon him, prayed: "Make us happy as the days You afflicted us," meaning that You should make us rejoice in Your holiness as the days we were afflicted by the evil inclination, which we must break the power of its desires. "The years we have seen evil," meaning all the years during which we have seen and looked at evil to be careful and guard ourselves from it, through this "He will look at Your servants, Your deeds," meaning it will be considered before You as if we have fulfilled all Your commandments and Your deeds. As mentioned, that through afflictions and self-denial from the evil inclination to break its power, it will be considered as if I have performed all the commandments.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on Moses' prayer, "Make us happy as the days of our affliction," emphasizing the idea that true joy comes from overcoming the challenges posed by the evil inclination (yetzer hara). The years spent grappling with adversity serve to strengthen one's commitment to holiness and observance of commandments. Through the struggles and self-discipline against temptation, one is considered to have fulfilled all commandments, highlighting the transformative power of suffering and resistance in the spiritual journey.

passage_content: ‎תהו "תאות לבו נתת לו כו'", זה שנתת לאדם הבחירה שיעשה כתאות לבו, "וארשת שפתיו בל מנעת סלה", שלא מנעת ממנו לדבר בשפתיו כרצונו, כל זאת עשית לטובת האדם, "כי תקדמנו ברכות טוב", פירוש עי"ז שהבחירה לאדם והיצה"ר מסיתו והוא כובש את יצרו, עי"ז יקדמנו השי"ת ברכות ושכר גדול, ע"י השם הקדוש שם הויה ב"ה שהוא גימטריה טוב, והיינו אפילו בגלות המר שהשם הוא בקטנות, כי לעתיד שיהיה השם בגדלות, בוודאי אין קץ וסוף להשפעתו, וזהו "הודו לה'", ר"ל להשם הויה שמו הגדול ית"ש, "כי טוב", ר"ל אף בגלות המר שהשם בקטנות, אעפ"כ הוא בגימטריה טוב, וזהו "כי לעולם חסדו".
translation: "Behold, 'the desires of his heart You have given him,' this means that You have given man the choice to act according to the desires of his heart. 'And You have not withheld the speech of his lips,' meaning that You have not prevented him from speaking as he wishes. All this You have done for the benefit of man. 'For You will advance him with blessings of goodness,' which means that through the choice given to man and the evil inclination that entices him, and he conquers his inclination, through this the Holy One, blessed be He, will advance him with great blessings and reward, by the holy name, the name of Havayah, which is the gematria of goodness. And this is even in the bitter exile when the name is in a state of smallness, for in the future, when the name will be in a state of greatness, certainly there will be no end to its influence. And this is 'Give thanks to Hashem,' meaning to the name Havayah, His great name, may He be blessed, 'for He is good,' meaning that even in the bitter exile when the name is in smallness, nevertheless, it is in the gematria of goodness, and this is 'for His kindness endures forever.'"
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept of human free will, highlighting that God grants individuals the choice to act according to their desires, which ultimately serves their benefit. It suggests that by exercising this choice and overcoming the evil inclination, one can receive divine blessings and rewards from God, whose name represents goodness. Even in times of hardship and spiritual diminishment, God's essence remains good, and His kindness endures forever, promising a future of abundant blessings. The text underscores the importance of recognizing God's goodness, even in challenging circumstances, as a central tenet of faith.

passage_content: ‎וזהו "יששכר חמור גרם כו'", פירוש "יש שכר" לאדם ע"י שהחמור - הוא הגוף החומר - החומד ומתאווה והאדם משבר כח תאוותו, הוא גורם לו לשכר הגדול, "רובץ בין המשפתים", פירוש הלשון, שהוא רובץ בין המשפתים, שהבחירה בידו לדבר בלשונו כרצונו, "וירא מנוחה", פירוש ואדם משבר כח תאוותו ואין רואה רק שיהיה לו מנוחה מהתאוות והמחשבות זרות, עי"ז גורם לו "כי 'טוב'", פירוש שיש לו השפעות משם הרחמים שהוא גימטריה טוב.
translation: And this is "Issachar is a strong donkey," meaning "there is reward" for a person by the fact that the donkey - which represents the physical body - desires and yearns, and the person breaks the power of his desire, causing him to attain great reward. "Crouching between the boundaries," meaning the tongue, which is crouching between the boundaries, as he has the choice to speak with his tongue as he wishes. "And he saw rest," meaning that a person breaks the power of his desire and sees only that he should have rest from desires and foreign thoughts. Through this, he causes "for it is good," meaning that he has influences from the place of mercy, which is the gematria of good.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "יששכר חמור גרם," interpreting "יש שכר" as the reward a person receives by overcoming the desires of the body, represented by the donkey. By mastering one's cravings and focusing on inner peace, a person can access divine mercy, which is associated with the concept of "טוב." The text emphasizes the importance of choice in speech and thought, suggesting that true fulfillment comes from transcending base desires and aligning with higher spiritual influences.

passage_content: ‎וזהו "ויחי יעקב בארץ מצרים", פירוש ע"י שהיה משבר כח התאוויות היצה"ר הנקראים 'ארץ מצרים' שהיא הקליפה, עי"ז היה לו חיות והשפעה מהשם הרחמים שהוא גימטריה "שבע עשרה" כנ"ל. וק"ל.
translation: And this is "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," meaning that he was able to break the power of the desires of the evil inclination, which are called 'the land of Egypt,' that is the klipah. Through this, he had vitality and influence from the name of mercy, which is the gematria of "seventeen," as mentioned above. And this is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's life in Egypt, interpreting it as a struggle against the desires of the evil inclination, symbolized by "the land of Egypt," which represents spiritual impurity. By overcoming these desires, Jacob was able to draw vitality and influence from the Divine attribute of mercy, which is numerically equivalent to "seventeen." This highlights the Hasidic theme of transforming challenges into spiritual growth through divine connection.

passage_content: ויקרבו ימי ישראל כו'. ונקדים לפרש הפסוק "שבענו בבוקר חסדך", ולכאורה הלא טוב לנו להתפלל שישבענו בחסדו חסד אל כל היום? אך נראה דהנה החסדים נקראים 'בוקר', וזהו "וישכם אברהם בבוקר", פירוש דאברהם אבינו ע"ה שהיה צדיק גדול והקדים ע"י מעשיו הטובים להשכים ולהקדים את הבוקר, היינו לעורר החסדים הנקראים בוקר, אבל אנחנו דלי מעש וחסרי לב, אנו מתפללין להשי"ת ב"ה שהוא ישבענו בבוקר חסדיו, שהוא יעורר עלינו החסדים, והשי"ת ברוב רחמיו שומע תפילת עמו ישראל ומקבל ברחמים וברצון את תפילתינו.
translation: "And the days of Israel drew near, etc. And we will begin to explain the verse 'We are satisfied in the morning with Your kindness.' And seemingly, is it not better for us to pray that we be satisfied with His kindness, the kindness of God, all day long? But it seems that the kindnesses are called 'morning,' and this is 'And Abraham rose early in the morning,' meaning that our forefather Abraham, peace be upon him, who was a great righteous one, through his good deeds, hastened to awaken and bring forth the morning, which is to arouse the kindnesses that are called morning. But we, who are lacking in deeds and lacking in heart, pray to the Holy One, blessed be He, that He should satisfy us in the morning with His kindnesses, that He should awaken the kindnesses upon us. And the Holy One, blessed be He, in His abundant mercy, hears the prayers of His people Israel and accepts our prayers with mercy and favor."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "שבענו בבוקר חסדך," emphasizing the idea that while the righteous, like Abraham, actively awaken divine kindness through their good deeds, the rest of humanity, lacking such merit, must humbly pray for God to bestow His kindness upon them. It highlights the concept that divine kindness is associated with the morning, symbolizing renewal and hope. The text reassures that God, in His abundant mercy, listens to the prayers of the Jewish people and responds with compassion.

passage_content: ‎ויש לכוון הפירוש במה שתקנו לנו בשלש ברכות ראשונות לומר "גומל חסדים טובים", ר"ל 'חסדים טובים', היינו החסדים שהשי"ת נותן להצדיקים הנקראים טובים, ו'גומל' הוא מלשון ויגמל אברהם כו', פירוש השי"ת הוא גומל את החסדים טובים ואינו ממתין עד שיתעוררו החסדים ע"י צדיקים, רק "קונה הכל", פירוש השי"ת ברוב רחמיו מקבל את כולנו, ולא עוד אלא "וזוכר חסדי אבות", דשלש ברכות הראשונות נקרא 'אבות', והם השלש מוחין הנקראים 'ראש', ובאותן שלש ברכות אין שם תפילה כמבואר בשו"ע או"ח, ויש ליתן טעם לשבח לזה, מפני ששלש ברכות הראשונות הם בעולמות העליונים ושם אין קטרוג כלל, לכן אין צריך שום תפילה רק תהלות ותשבחות, כי אין תפילה אלא במקום קטרוג, וזהו "וזוכר חסדי כו'", פירוש תיכף ומיד בהתחלותנו שבחין, הם הג' ראשונות, מיד הוא זוכר את חסדיו לעשות כל צרכינו מיד ב'אבות', היינו שלש ראשונות, קודם גמר תפילתינו הוא יעננו טרם נקרא.
translation: And one should focus on the interpretation of what they established for us in the first three blessings to say "He who bestows good kindnesses," meaning 'good kindnesses,' which are the kindnesses that the Holy One, Blessed be He, gives to the righteous who are called good. And 'gomal' is from the language of "And he dealt kindly with Abraham" (Genesis 21:1), meaning the Holy One, Blessed be He, bestows good kindnesses and does not wait for the kindnesses to be aroused by the righteous, but rather "He acquires everything," meaning the Holy One, Blessed be He, in His abundant mercy accepts us all. Moreover, "And remembers the kindnesses of the fathers," for the first three blessings are called 'fathers,' and they are the three intellects that are called 'head.' In those three blessings, there is no prayer, as explained in the Shulchan Aruch, Orach Chaim. One should give a reason for this praise, because the first three blessings are in the upper worlds, and there is no accusation at all there. Therefore, there is no need for any prayer, only praises and commendations, for there is no prayer except in a place of accusation. And this is "And remembers the kindnesses," meaning immediately at the beginning of our praises, which are the first three, He immediately remembers His kindnesses to fulfill all our needs right away in 'Avot,' meaning the first three, before the completion of our prayer, He will answer us before we call.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of the first three blessings in the Amidah prayer, which are dedicated to praising God for His "good deeds" towards the righteous, referred to as "good ones." It highlights that God bestows these kindnesses without waiting for the righteous to invoke them, reflecting His boundless mercy. The text also notes that these blessings, associated with the patriarchs, exist in a realm free from accusations, where praise suffices instead of requests, allowing for immediate divine response to our needs. Thus, the act of praising God in these blessings leads to the swift remembrance of His kindnesses.

passage_content: ‎וזהו פירוש "תאות לבו נתת לו", דהתאוה והתשוקה של הצדיק תמיד שיהיו כל ישראל מלאים ושבעים כל טוב, והשי"ת נותן התאוות האלו בלב הצדיק כדי שיתפלל לפניו, שהקב"ה מתאוה לתפילתן כו', "וארשת שפתיו בל מנעת סלה", פירוש והשי"ת שומע תפילתו של הצדיק, ולא עוד אלא "כי תקדמנו ברכות טוב", פירוש וקודם שיתפלל עדיין, הוא מקדים כל ברכות טוב על ידי ש"תשית לראשו עטרת פז", פירוש מחמת שמיד בהתחלת שלש ראשונות הנקראים 'ראש' אתה עושה מהם עטרת פז, ולכן טרם יקרא אתה תענה, כי שם אין צריך לתפילה כנ"ל. וזהו "התהללו בשם", פירוש בעולמות ששם רק תהילה, וממילא "ישמח לב מבקשי ה'" מיד קודם שיתפללו.
translation: And this is the explanation of "The desires of his heart You have given him," for the desire and longing of the righteous is always that all of Israel should be full and satisfied with all good, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, places these desires in the heart of the righteous so that he will pray before Him, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, yearns for their prayers, etc. "And You will meet him with blessings of goodness," meaning that even before he prays, He precedes all blessings of goodness by the fact that "You place a crown of fine gold upon his head," meaning that immediately at the beginning of the first three blessings, which are called 'head,' you make them a crown of fine gold. Therefore, before he calls, You will answer, for there is no need for prayer there, as mentioned. And this is "Let them praise the name," meaning in the worlds where there is only praise, and consequently "Let the heart of those who seek the Lord rejoice" immediately before they pray.
summary: The passage emphasizes the deep desire of the righteous (tzaddik) for all of Israel to be fulfilled with goodness, reflecting God's will. It highlights that God instills these desires in the tzaddik's heart to encourage their prayers, as He yearns for their supplications. Furthermore, it suggests that God preemptively bestows blessings upon the tzaddik even before they pray, indicating a profound connection between divine grace and the tzaddik's spiritual elevation. Ultimately, it conveys that in the higher realms, where only praise exists, those who seek God will find joy even before their prayers are uttered.

passage_content: ‎וזהו "ויקרבו ימי ישראל למות", פירוש יעקב אבינו ע"ה היה מחשב תמיד את יום המיתה שהוא קרוב ושמא ימות היום, וזהו "ויקרבו כו'", ר"ל שכל ימיו היו בעיניו קרובים למיתה, ועי"ז היה מזכך את גופו והיו כל מחשבותיו בעולמות העליונים, וזהו "ויקרא לבנו ליוסף", פירוש זה רמז אף כשהיה בעניני עוה"ז, דהיינו "לבנו" וכדומה, אף על פי כן היו כל מחשבותיו "ליוסף", דהיינו עולם העליון הנקרא 'יוסף'.
translation: And this is "And the days of Israel drew near to die," meaning that our father Jacob, may he rest in peace, was always contemplating the day of death, which was close, and perhaps he would die that day. This is what is meant by "and the days drew near," meaning that all his days were in his eyes close to death. Through this, he was purifying his body, and all his thoughts were in the higher worlds. This is "and he called to his son Joseph," meaning this hints that even when he was involved in matters of this world, that is to say "to his son" and the like, nevertheless, all his thoughts were "to Joseph," meaning the higher world that is called 'Joseph.'
summary: הפסוק "ויקרבו ימי ישראל למות" מתאר את מחשבותיו של יעקב אבינו, שחשב תמיד על יום המיתה הקרוב, מה שהוביל אותו לזכך את גופו ולהתמקד בעולמות העליונים. יעקב, אף כשהיה עוסק בענייני העולם הזה, כמו בנו יוסף, שמר על מחשבותיו מכוונות לעולם העליון, המיוצג על ידי יוסף. זה מדגיש את החשיבות של חיבור בין החיים הגשמיים לרוחניים, ואת השאיפה להתרוממות רוחנית בכל מצב.

passage_content: או יאמר "ויקרבו ימי ישראל כו' שים נא ידך תחת ירכי", נראה דהנה העיקר הוא ליחד שמו הגדול באמת, והוא שימסור אדם נפשו על קדושת שמו יתברך ויתעלה, ולכן מצות עשה בתורה לקרות ק"ש ערב ובוקר, שזה יחוד שמו שאנו מוסרים נפשינו לשמו הגדול יתברך, רק שצריך האדם לדמות בנפשו באמת כאילו עתה נמסר נפשו על יחוד שמו הגדול, וכן הוא דרך הצדיקים.
translation: Or he may say, "And the days of Israel drew near... please place your hand under my thigh." It seems that the main point is to sanctify His great name truly, which is that a person should be willing to give up his life for the sanctity of His name, blessed and exalted. Therefore, there is a positive commandment in the Torah to recite the Shema in the evening and in the morning, as this is the unification of His name for which we are ready to give our lives for His great name, but a person must truly envision in his soul as if he is now giving his life for the unification of His great name, and this is the way of the righteous.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of unifying God's great name through self-sacrifice for His sanctity. It highlights the commandment to recite the Shema twice daily as an expression of this dedication, where one must genuinely feel as if they are currently surrendering their soul for the unity of God's name. This practice reflects the path of the righteous, who embody this profound commitment in their lives.

passage_content: ‎וזהו "ויקרבו ימי ישראל למות", פירוש שתמיד היה מוסר נפשו כ"כ באמת שהיה קרוב למיתה, "ויקרא לבנו ליוסף", לכאורה היה לו לומר 'לבנו יוסף'? אך הענין הוא מה שהאדם מקיים התורה שאינו עובר על מצוותיו, אינו אלא במדריגת 'עבד' שאינו עובר על מצות אדוניו, אבל להיות נקרא 'בן' למקום, צריך לעשות לעצמו גדרים וסייגים ולהוסיף בעבודה לפי שכלו הזך ממדריגה למדריגה, וזהו "ויקרא לבנו" פירוש מי הוא בנו? "ליוסף" שמוסיף תמיד כנ"ל, "שים נא ידך", לפי שהצדיק הגדול המוסיף תמיד בעבודה צריך לשמור עצמו שלא יפול לגאות מחמת שיסבור שהוא טוב ומטיב בעבודה להוסיף בה תמיד, והתקנה לזה הוא לזכור תמיד ולחשוב שכל זכויותיו אינם כדאי להנצל פעם אחד מחטא קרי ר"ל אם נזדמן לו, ובזה יכנע וישפל, וזהו "ויקרא לבנו ליוסף" כנ"ל, "שים נא ידך", פירוש כל כחך, הם התורה והמצוות שאתה מקיים, שים הכל "תחת ירכי" רמז על החטא הנ"ל, אם ח"ו נזדמן לך אז הכל חלף ועבר ח"ו, ובזה תנצל מן הגאוה, וזהו "אל תקברני במצרים", הם הקליפות הנקרא מצרים. וק"ל.
translation: And this is "And the days of Israel drew near to die," meaning that he always risked his life so much in truth that he was close to death. "And he called to his son Joseph," seemingly he should have said 'to his son Joseph'? But the matter is that a person who fulfills the Torah and does not transgress its commandments is only at the level of 'servant' who does not transgress the commands of his master. However, to be called 'son' to the place, one must set up boundaries and fences for oneself and increase in service according to one's pure intellect from level to level. And this is "And he called to his son," meaning who is his son? "To Joseph," who always adds as mentioned above. "Please place your hand," because the great righteous one who always adds in service must guard himself so that he does not fall into arrogance because he might think that he is good and does good in his service by always adding to it. The remedy for this is to always remember and think that all his merits are not worthy to save him even once from the sin of 'erect' if it should happen to him, and in this way, he will humble and lower himself. And this is "And he called to his son Joseph," as mentioned above, "Please place your hand," meaning all your strength, which are the Torah and the commandments that you fulfill, place everything "under my thigh," hinting at the aforementioned sin, if God forbid it should happen to you, then all is null and void, God forbid, and in this way, you will be saved from arrogance. And this is "Do not bury me in Egypt," referring to the klipot that are called Egypt. And so it is understood.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual elevation and humility in the context of one's relationship with God. It emphasizes that merely following the commandments places a person at the level of a servant, while true sonship requires personal growth and the establishment of boundaries in one's spiritual practice. The text warns against pride that may arise from one's achievements in serving God, advocating for a constant awareness of one's vulnerabilities to sin. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of humility and the need to remain grounded in one's spiritual journey to avoid falling into arrogance.

passage_content: ויקח יוסף את שניהם את אפרים בימינו כו' מימין ישראל וישלח כו' והוא הצעיר כו' שכל את ידיו כי מנשה הבכור. ויש לדקדק הלא עיקר כוונת הכתוב הוא לפרש שהבכור היה מימין ישראל והצעיר משמאלו, וימין ושמאל של יוסף הוא מיותר.
translation: And Joseph took both of them, Ephraim in his right hand, etc., to the right of Israel, and he sent, etc., and he was the younger, etc., and he crossed his hands because Manasseh was the firstborn. And one must clarify that the main intention of the verse is to explain that the firstborn was to the right of Israel and the younger to his left, and the right and left of Joseph is superfluous.
summary: In this passage, the focus is on the significance of Joseph's positioning of his sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, during the blessing by Jacob. The text highlights that although Manasseh is the firstborn and should be placed on the right, Joseph intentionally crosses his hands, placing Ephraim, the younger, in the position of prominence. This act symbolizes the idea that spiritual elevation and divine favor are not solely determined by birthright, but rather by one's qualities and potential. The crossing of hands serves as a profound reminder of the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of intention and the unexpected ways in which divine providence operates.

passage_content: ‎אך נראה שעיקר מחשבת יעקב אבינו ע"ה היה להמשיך לישראל אחריו כל הימים השפעות והברכות כולם להיותם קיימים תמיד, ורצה להמשיך ע"י ב' צדיקים הללו אפרים ומנשה, כאומרו "בך יברך ישראל כו' כאפרים וכמנשה", והטעם למה דוקא ע"י אלו הצדיקים? היות שהעולם צריך תמיד לב' מיני צדיקים, האחד הוא שיחשוב תמיד בעולמות העליונים וביחודים להוסיף אור תמיד למעלה למעלה, ואחד לחשוב בצורכי עולם, מה שהעולם צריכין פרנסה וברכה וחיים ושאר הצטרכותם, ובב' מיני צדיקים הללו הוא קיום העולם, ולזה רצה להמשיך ולפעול זאת על ידם, "כי מנשה הבכור" היה במדריגתו לעלות תמיד ממדריגה למדריגה ולא לחשוב בעניני העוה"ז כלל, ואפרים היה צעיר ממנו בעבודה שלא היה כ"כ הולך במדריגות, כי אם שהיה חושב תמיד המשכת השפעה על ישראל, וזה היה חשוב בעיני ישראל אבינו יותר, כי עיקר מגמתו היה למשוך טוב על ישראל, וכוונת יוסף היה היפך, שהיה סבר שמנשה חשוב מחמת רוב כוונתו ועלייתו, ולזה לקח את אפרים לימין עצמו, כי כוונתו היתה ג"כ בשביל ישראל להמשיך הברכות ע"י ב' הצדיקים הללו, אך שסבר שדי לאפרים כח ימינו במה שהעמידו לימין עצמו, בזה יהיה די לפעול הברכות לישראל וכנ"ל, ועיקר היה אצלו מנשה לפי שהיה עובד במדריגות גדולות ולכך העמידו לימין אביו, ולא כן היה דעת יעקב אבינו ע"ה, אדרבה להיפך, לפי שהיה אפרים הצעיר לכך שכל את ידיו לברכו בימין, כי זה היה עיקר פעולת יעקב להטיב אחריו לדורותיו שיהיו מזומנים כל טוב השפעה ורחמים, וזה היה מדריגת אפרים.
translation: But it seems that the main intention of our father Jacob, peace be upon him, was to continue to Israel after him all the influences and blessings, so that they would always be present. He wanted to continue this through these two righteous ones, Ephraim and Menashe, as it is said, "In you shall Israel bless, saying, 'May God make you like Ephraim and like Menashe.'" And the reason why specifically through these righteous ones? Because the world always needs two types of righteous individuals: one who constantly thinks about the upper worlds and the unifications to continually add light above, and one who thinks about the needs of the world, what the world requires for sustenance, blessing, life, and other necessities. With these two types of righteous individuals, the world is sustained. Therefore, he wanted to continue and act through them. "For Menashe the firstborn" was in his level to always ascend from level to level and not to think at all about the matters of this world. And Ephraim was younger than him in service, as he did not ascend so much in levels, but rather he always thought about the continuation of influence upon Israel. This was more important in the eyes of our father Israel, for his main intention was to draw good upon Israel. And Joseph's intention was the opposite; he thought that Menashe was important because of his greater intention and ascent. Therefore, he placed Ephraim at his right side, for his intention was also for Israel to continue the blessings through these two righteous ones. However, he thought that it was sufficient for Ephraim to be at his right side, believing that this would be enough to bring blessings to Israel, as mentioned. The main one in his eyes was Menashe, as he was working at great levels, and therefore he placed him at his father's right. But this was not the opinion of our father Jacob, peace be upon him; on the contrary, it was the opposite. Since Ephraim was the younger one, he extended both of his hands to bless him with his right, for this was the main action of Jacob to bestow goodness after him for his generations, that they should be prepared for all good influences and mercy, and this was the level of Ephraim.
summary: יעקב אבינו רצה להמשיך את השפעות והברכות לישראל לדורות, ולכן בחר באפרים ומנשה כצדיקים שיביאו את הברכות לעולם. הוא הבחין בשני סוגי צדיקים: אחד שמתרכז בעולמות העליונים ואחד שדואג לצרכי העולם הזה. מנשה, הבכור, היה במדריגה גבוהה אך לא התעסק בעניינים גשמיים, בעוד אפרים, הצעיר, היה ממוקד בהבאת השפעות לישראל. יעקב העדיף את אפרים לברכה, כי הוא ראה בו את היכולת להמשיך טוב ורחמים לדורות הבאים.

passage_content: ‎וזהו שאמר יעקב "ידעתי בני ידעתי", פירוש שאמר ליוסף הידיעה של בני, ידעתי מזה ג"כ שמנשה הוא היותר גדול במדירגתו, "ואולם אחיו הקטן" במדריגתו "יגדל ממנו וזרעו יהיה מלא הגוים", שיהיה כל העולם מלא מהשפעותיו וטובו, ולכך הוא חביב בעיני יותר, לזה "וישם את אפרים לפני מנשה".
translation: And this is what Jacob said, "I know, my son, I know," meaning that he told Joseph about the knowledge of his sons. I also know that Manasseh is the greater one in his rank. "However, his younger brother" in his rank "will grow greater than him, and his seed will be filled among the nations," that the whole world will be filled with his influences and goodness. Therefore, he is more beloved in my eyes, and for this reason "he placed Ephraim before Manasseh."
summary: יעקב מביע את ידיעתו על מעמד בניו, במיוחד על מנשה ואפרים. הוא מזהה שמנשה הוא הבן הבכור, אך מציין כי אפרים, האח הקטן, יגדל ויהיה בעל השפעה רבה על כל העמים. בכך, יעקב מדגיש את חשיבותו של אפרים ואת טובו, ולכן הוא שם את אפרים לפני מנשה, מה שמעיד על העדפתו הרוחנית של אפרים. זהו ביטוי לתפיסה החסידית של עליית הנשמה הקטנה והכוח הרוחני שלה להשפיע על העולם.

passage_content: ‎וזהו "סוד ה' ליראיו (ובריתו להודיעם)", פירוש היראים - הם הצדיקים הממשיכים השפעות, צריכין לעשות בסוד בהסתר מפני הקטרוג שלא יקטרג על הטוב ההוא, "ובריתו" הוא צדיק המתנהג ע"פ הברית והתורה, "להודיעם" פירוש שיודיע זאת לבני אדם שילמדו ממנו הדרך הטוב ההוא.
translation: And this is "The secret of the Lord is for those who fear Him (and His covenant to make it known to them)," the meaning of those who fear - they are the righteous who continue the influences, and they need to act in secret due to the accusations, so that the good will not be accused, "and His covenant" refers to the righteous who conduct themselves according to the covenant and the Torah, "to make it known to them" means that he will make this known to people so that they will learn from him the good way.
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept that the secret of God is revealed to those who fear Him, specifically the righteous (tzaddikim) who channel divine influences while operating in concealment to avoid negative judgments. The term "His covenant" refers to the tzaddik who adheres to the covenant and Torah, embodying a life of righteousness. Furthermore, the purpose of this revelation is to teach others the path of goodness, highlighting the role of the tzaddik as a guide for humanity.

passage_content: שכל את ידיו כי מנשה הבכור. ולכאורה הטעם הוא ההיפך של עשיה, אלא למדה תורה דרך ארץ שינהוג אדם כבוד בחבירו לפי הראוי לו, ואעפ"י שהיה יכול יעקב אבינו ע"ה לחזור ולהעמידם כרצונו זה לימינו וזה לשמאלו, אלא שכוונתו היה שלא לבייש את מנשה ולכך שכל את ידיו בראשם. וק"ל.
translation: He crossed his hands because Manasseh was the firstborn. At first glance, the reason seems to be the opposite of action, but the Torah teaches a way of conduct that a person should show respect to his friend according to what is fitting for him. And although our forefather Jacob, peace be upon him, could have returned and positioned them as he wished, this one to his right and that one to his left, his intention was not to embarrass Manasseh, and therefore he crossed his hands over their heads. And this is understood.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author highlights the importance of treating others with respect and dignity, as exemplified by Jacob's actions when blessing his grandsons, Ephraim and Manasseh. Despite having the ability to position them as he wished, Jacob chose to cross his hands to avoid embarrassing Manasseh, the elder. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of humility and the value of interpersonal relationships, emphasizing that true righteousness involves consideration for the feelings of others. Jacob's decision serves as a model for how one should conduct themselves with honor and sensitivity towards others.

passage_content: או יאמר "אם עד שלא פרעו כו'", דהנה כל אדם יש בו חלק אלקי ממעל, וגם בשעה שעושה עבירה חלילה אילולי החלק אלקי שבו לא היה בו כח להתנענע בשום תנועה בשום אבר לעשות, וההכרח לחלק אלהי להתלבש בלבושים על גבי לבושים לסבול הצער הגדול של העבירה, וזהו סוד גלות השכינה, ואח"כ כשאדם חוזר בתשובה ובוכה על עוונותיו, זה הוא שבוכה על גלות השכינה, ועי"ז הוא משבר את הלבושים שהוכרח החלק אלקי להתלבש בהם ונתגלה בתיקונו כשמתקן עוונו, וזהו "עד שלא פרעו", ר"ל שעדיין לא הסיר וגילה את הלבושים מחלק אלקי, שעדיין לא עשה תשובה כהוגן "חייב", "ואם משפרעו פטור", כנ"ל, "ר"י אומר (וכו')", כנ"ל.
translation: Or he might say, "If until they have not been paid, etc.", behold, every person has a divine spark above, and even at the time he commits a sin, heaven forbid, were it not for the divine spark within him, he would not have the strength to move in any way with any limb to act. It is necessary for the divine spark to be clothed in garments upon garments to endure the great pain of the sin, and this is the secret of the exile of the Shechinah. And afterwards, when a person repents and cries over his transgressions, this is the one who cries over the exile of the Shechinah, and through this he breaks the garments that the divine spark was forced to be clothed in, and it is revealed in its rectification when he rectifies his sin. And this is "until they have not been paid," meaning that he has not yet removed and revealed the garments from the divine spark, that he has not yet repented properly, "he is liable," "and if after they have been paid, he is exempt," as mentioned, "Rabbi Yochanan says (etc.)," as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the intrinsic divine spark within every person, which enables them to act, even when committing sins. It emphasizes that this divine essence must endure the pain of sin through layers of concealment, representing the exile of the Shechinah. When a person repents and mourns their transgressions, they are effectively lamenting the exile of the divine presence and breaking the barriers that concealed it. The text highlights the importance of sincere repentance in revealing and restoring the divine essence within oneself.

passage_content: יהודה אתה יודוך כו'. דהנה אנו מתפללים בברכת אהבה רבה "ותן בלבנו לאהבה וליראה את שמך", ולכאורה הוא ההיפך, היראה מביאה לידי אהבה. אך אמנם האמת שניהם צדקו יחדיו, דאית יראה ואית יראה, אית יראה תתאה הנקרא 'אימא תתאה', וממדריגה זו בא לידי אהבה, ואהבה זו נקראת בשם 'אח' שעדיין אינה אהבה שלימה, וממדריגת אהבה זאת בא לידי אהבה שלימה הנקרא בשם 'אב', וממדריגת אהבה זאת בא לידי יראה עילאה הנקרא בשם 'אם', וזהו שנאמר "איש אמו ואביו תיראו", רמז ליראה תתאה, נאמר אם קודם לאב, ואצל כיבוד שהיא אהבה נאמר אב קודם לאם.
translation: Judah, you will praise Him, etc. Behold, we pray in the blessing of Ahavah Rabbah, "And place in our hearts to love and fear Your name," and seemingly it is the opposite, for fear leads to love. However, the truth is that both are correct together, for there is fear and there is fear; there is a lower fear called 'Imma Tata' (the lower mother), and from this level, one comes to love, and this love is called 'Ach' (brother), which is not yet complete love. From this level of love, one comes to complete love called 'Av' (father), and from this level of love, one comes to higher fear called 'Im' (mother). And this is what is said, "You shall fear each man, his mother and his father," hinting at the lower fear, where 'Im' is mentioned before 'Av,' and regarding honor, which is love, 'Av' is mentioned before 'Im.'
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between love and fear in the context of prayer, specifically in the blessing "Ahavah Rabbah." It highlights that there are two types of fear: the lower fear (Yirah Tata'ah), associated with the maternal aspect (Imma Tata'ah), which leads to a preliminary love (Ahavah) referred to as 'brotherly love' (Ach). This initial love can evolve into a higher, complete love (Ahavah Shleimah), which in turn leads to a higher fear (Yirah Ilah), symbolized by the maternal figure (Imma), emphasizing the interconnectedness of love and fear in spiritual development. The text also notes the order of honoring parents, where love (Ab) precedes fear (Im) in the context of respect.

passage_content: ‎וזהו שאמר אברהם אבינו ע"ה לאבימלך "וגם אמנם אחותי בת אבי", פירוש מחמת שהיה בדרך לא היה יכול להשיג מדריגת אהבה עילאה הנקרא בשם 'אב', ולא היה כי אם במדריגת אהבה תתאה הנקרא בשם 'אח', שהיא כמו בת למדירגת אהבה עילאה, "אך לא בת אמי", שאינו במדריגת אהבה שהיא כמו 'בת' ליראה עילאה הנקרא בשם 'אם', "ואומר לה בכל מקום אשר נבוא שמה אמרי לי אחי הוא", רמז שאני במדריגת אהבה הנקרא בשם 'אח'.
translation: And this is what our forefather Abraham, peace be upon him, said to Abimelech: "And indeed she is my sister, the daughter of my father," meaning that because he was on a journey, he was unable to attain the level of supreme love, which is referred to as 'father,' and he was only at the level of lower love, which is called 'brother,' as it is akin to a daughter in relation to the level of supreme love. "But not the daughter of my mother," which is not at the level of love that is like a 'daughter' to the supreme awe, which is called 'mother.' "And say to her, wherever we go, say that you are my sister," hinting that I am at the level of love that is called 'brother.'
summary: In this passage, the author interprets Abraham's statement to Abimelech as reflecting different levels of love in relation to divine connection. The term "אח" (brother) signifies a lower level of love, while "אב" (father) represents a higher, more profound love that is unattainable in Abraham's current state. The mention of "אם" (mother) relates to a higher level of awe and reverence, indicating that true spiritual connection requires a deeper understanding and relationship with the divine. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the varying degrees of love and fear in one's relationship with God, illustrating the complexity of spiritual ascent.

passage_content: ‎וזהו "יהודה אתה", דהיינו כשאתה בנגלות, דהיינו מדריגת 'אתה' שהוא הנגלה, כמו שאנו אומרים 'ברוך אתה' הוא הנגלה, 'אשר קדשנו' הוא הנסתר, ובמדריגה הזאת "יודוך אחיך" ר"ל אותם שהם במדרגת 'אח' כנ"ל, אבל "ידך בעורף אויביך", פירוש כשתהיה במדריגה עליונה שיש כח בידך לכלות האויבים והדינים, אז "וישתחוו לך בני אביך", אותם שהם במדרגת 'אב'. והבן מאוד.
translation: And this is "Judah, you are," meaning when you are in exile, which is the level of 'you' that is revealed, as we say 'Blessed are You' which is the revealed, 'Who has sanctified us' which is the hidden. And in this level "your brothers will praise you," meaning those who are on the level of 'brother' as mentioned above. But "your hand is on the neck of your enemies," meaning when you are on a higher level where you have the power in your hand to annihilate the enemies and judgments, then "the sons of your father will bow to you," those who are on the level of 'father.' And understand this very well.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual significance of the name "Judah" in the context of exile and revelation. It contrasts the revealed aspect of the Divine, represented by "you" (אתה), with the hidden aspect, symbolized by the blessings of sanctification. The text emphasizes that when one reaches a higher spiritual level, they gain the power to overcome adversaries, leading to the ultimate recognition and reverence from those in the higher spiritual rank of "father." This reflects the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of spiritual elevation and the interconnectedness of different levels of divine awareness.

passage_content: יששכר חמור גרם כו'. נראה לפרש, דהנה הצדיק המתפלל צריך להסתיר דבריו בכדי שלא יבין המקטרג לקטרג חלילה, ואילולי הקטרוג היה הצדיק יכול להוציא בשפתיו כל דבריו שירצה, רק מחמת הקטרוג צריך לכחד דבריו תחת לשונו ושפתיו, וזהו "יששכר חמור גרם רובץ בין המשפתים", פירוש הגוף, הוא החומר, גורם לצדיק שמוכרח להיות רובץ את דבריו בין השפתים, 'משפתים' לשון 'שפתים', היינו כנ"ל שצריך להסתיר את דבריו בין שפתיו שלא לדברם בפירוש מפני המקטרג שיכול לקטרג על הצדיק מחמת גוף החומר, ולכן חכם בדעת ידבר ויתפלל, ותפילתו יעלה לרחמים ולרצון. אמן.
translation: Yissachar is a strong donkey, etc. It seems appropriate to explain that the righteous person who prays must conceal his words so that the accuser does not understand and accuse, Heaven forbid. Were it not for the accusation, the righteous could express all his words freely; however, due to the accusation, he must hide his words beneath his tongue and lips. This is what is meant by "Yissachar is a strong donkey, crouching between the borders," meaning the body, which is the material aspect, causes the righteous to be compelled to keep his words hidden between his lips, 'between the borders' refers to 'lips,' which means, as mentioned, that he must conceal his words between his lips and not speak them explicitly because of the accuser who can accuse the righteous due to the material body. Therefore, a wise person in understanding will speak and pray, and his prayer will ascend to mercy and favor. Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity for a righteous person (tzaddik) to conceal their prayers and intentions from potential accusers (mekatrig) who might use them against them. It emphasizes that the physical body (represented by "יששכר חמור גרם") restricts the tzaddik from openly expressing their thoughts, requiring them to keep their words hidden between their lips. This concealment is portrayed as a wise approach, allowing the tzaddik's prayers to ascend favorably to divine mercy. Ultimately, the text highlights the tension between spiritual aspirations and the limitations imposed by the material world.

passage_content: לא תראה חמור אחיך רובץ תחת משאו כו'. דהאדם העוסק בעניני ועסקי עוה"ז, הרי העולם עליו כמשא ורובץ תחת משאו, ואמר הכתוב "לא תוכל להתעלם", אזהרה לצדיק שיתפלל עליו. וק"ל.
translation: "You shall not see your brother's donkey lying under its burden, etc. For a person who is engaged in the matters and affairs of this world, the world is upon him as a burden and lies under his load, and the verse says 'You shall not be able to ignore,' a warning to the righteous to pray for him. And it is clear."
summary: The passage emphasizes the moral obligation to care for others, particularly those burdened by the struggles of worldly life, likening these struggles to a heavy load. It highlights the idea that a righteous person should not ignore the suffering of others, as indicated by the command "you shall not ignore." This reflects a key Hasidic concept of communal responsibility and the importance of prayer and intercession for those in distress. Ultimately, it underscores the interconnectedness of individuals within the spiritual and physical realms.

passage_content: ענין שני חיי יעקב עיקרן שבע שנים שי"ב ולכן בגימ' ז' הויות וארבעים הוא חיותו מחב"ד והדעת כלול חו"ג הרי ד"פ עשר הם ארבעים וכן ז' וארבעים הה מ"ז הוא החיים הבאים מחיבור הויה אהיה ומאת שנה הוא הרצון והפסוק כסדר:
translation: The second matter of the life of Jacob is primarily seven years, which is twelve, and therefore in gematria, seven is the name of the fourty, which is his vitality from Chabad, and the intellect is included in Chochmah and Binah, thus the ten are forty, and likewise seven and forty, this is the life that comes from the connection of the name Ehyeh, and from the year is the will, and the verse is in order.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's life, emphasizing that its essence is encapsulated in the seven years of his service, which correspond to the divine names and the concept of life derived from the union of the names "Havayah" and "Ehyeh." It highlights the interplay between intellect (Chabad) and emotions (Chochmah and Binah), suggesting that true life is achieved through the integration of these spiritual dimensions. The reference to the number forty symbolizes completeness and the fulfillment of divine will, reflecting the deeper connection between desire and existence in the context of Hasidic thought.

passage_content: אפרים ומנשה כראובן ושמעון. אפרים כראובן בחסד. ומנשה אותיות שמעון והעי"ן מתחלף בה'. ולכן לקח יוסף אפרים בימינו ומ"מ יהי' מנשה מזומן לברכה. לפי מ"ש מ"ו בספרו כי מנשה הלך בצדקו הכל להבורא וא"כשם מנשה ששכח בזה העולם אלא דיבק בכל מחשבתו להבורא והי' בבחי' אור חוזר כמ"ש שהוא כח גבורות החוזרת לשורשם וזה הי' בכור שעיקר שיצא בריאה הי' אור חוזר שאל"כ בכח בלי סוף א"א לבורא' וז"ש גם הוא יגדל אולם אחיו הקטן כי הצדיק שרוצה להשפיע צריך בכל פעם להשגיח על העולם וצריך להתקטן והוא יגדל ממנו כי בתחילת הבריאה ג"כ אהבה דוחקת הבשר ויעקב שכל ידיו ואמר מ"ו לוי יצחק להיות בכ"מ לא יהי' מכה עד שיברא רפואה תחלה ואפשר עשה לתיקון ליהושיע כאמור יה יהושעך ואפשר עד ביאת משיח בן אפרי' שלא ימות ויהא הגאולה ברחמים ועיין בתיקון ס"ת ועיין בר"מ ר"פ ויצא ושם במאמר פתח ר"ש דאמר בהאי גם שהוא אבא יו"ד לאשלמא רמ"ה לגבי משיח בן יוסף שלא ימות ע"ש כי יוסף משך חיים מאבא ולכן נק' משכיל ומשם מושך חיים לדוד וכאב יסד ברתא:
translation: Ephraim and Manasseh are like Reuben and Simeon. Ephraim is like Reuben in kindness. And Manasseh, the letters of Simeon, and the 'ayin is exchanged with a 'hei'. Therefore, Joseph took Ephraim in his right hand, and nevertheless, Manasseh should be prepared for blessing. According to what is written in the book of M.V. that Manasseh walked in his righteousness, all for the Creator. And just as Manasseh forgot in this world, he clung with all his thoughts to the Creator, and he was in the aspect of reflected light, as it is said that it is the strength of the severities returning to their source. This was in the firstborn, whose essence that came into being was reflected light, for otherwise, with the infinite power, it is impossible to create. And it is said, he too will grow greater than his younger brother, for the righteous who wishes to bestow must always pay attention to the world and needs to diminish himself, and he will grow from him. For at the beginning of creation, love also pressed the flesh, and Jacob with all his hands said M.V. Levi Yitzchak to be everywhere, there will be no blow until a remedy is created first. And perhaps he made a correction for Yehoshua, as it is said, "May your salvation be," and perhaps until the coming of the Messiah, son of Ephraim, that he should not die and that the redemption should be in mercy. And see in the correction of the Torah scroll, and see in the Rambam, in the section of Vayeitzei, and there in the saying of Rabbi Shimon, who said in this, even though he is a father, Yud of Shlemut, 245 regarding the Messiah, son of Joseph, that he should not die, as it is written, for Joseph drew life from the father, and therefore he is called wise, and from there he draws life to David, and the father established the daughter.
summary: The passage discusses the symbolic roles of Ephraim and Manasseh, equating Ephraim with the kindness of Reuben and Manasseh with the strength of Simeon, emphasizing their spiritual significance. It highlights Manasseh's dedication to God, representing a return to the divine source, and the necessity for the righteous to diminish themselves to elevate others. The text also connects these themes to the messianic hope, suggesting that through the lineage of Joseph, who embodies life and wisdom, there is a potential for redemption and healing in the world. Ultimately, it reflects on the interplay of divine attributes and the anticipation of a compassionate redemption in the messianic era.

passage_content: אז חללת. תיבת אז מיותר הנה הזוהר כתב שהבכור' הגיע' לבני' של רחל שמחשבה ראשונה הי' לה אלא שכתיב ובחללו ניטלה הבכורה והיינו שבאמת לאה הי' בעולם עליון שלא הי' יכול יעקב להזדווג לה כמ"ש ועיני לאה רכות שהיא ארוכה והי' צ"ל היחוד ע"י רחל והי' זה כזיווג אחור בפנים שהוא לא הי' פונה לה עד שראובן מצא דודאים והעלה לה חן אז אמרה אלי תבא ולכן זכה יששכר לוירא מנוחה להסתכל בפני' של תורה והנה לא הי' מקום לראובן לומר רחל היתה צרה לאמי אדרב' ע"י רחל נזדווגה ובדיבורו העלה המקטרג לומר שהיה יכול להזדווג והוא כבן תמורה וז"ש אז חללת למפרע על תחלת בנינך והבן:
translation: Then you have desecrated. The word "then" is superfluous; behold, the Zohar writes that the firstborn came to the children of Rachel, as it was her initial thought, but it is written, "and in his desecration the birthright was taken away," meaning that in truth Leah was in the upper world, to which Jacob could not unite with her, as it is said, "and the eyes of Leah were tender," which means she was long, and the union had to be through Rachel. This was like a coupling of back to front, as he was not facing her until Reuben found the mandrakes and brought her grace, then she said, "Let him come to me." Therefore, Issachar was worthy of seeing the restfulness to gaze upon the countenance of the Torah. And behold, there was no place for Reuben to say that Rachel was a rival to my mother; on the contrary, through Rachel they were united, and by his speech, the accuser raised the claim that he could have united, and he is like a son of exchange. This is what is meant by "then you have desecrated" retroactively regarding the beginning of your building. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the complex dynamics of the relationships between Leah, Rachel, and Jacob, emphasizing the spiritual significance of their union. It highlights the idea that Rachel's initial intention was to be the primary partner, yet Leah's status as the firstborn was ultimately challenged. The text suggests that the true connection between Jacob and Leah was hindered until Reuven's actions facilitated a deeper bond, illustrating the interplay of divine providence and human agency in the unfolding of their destinies. This reflects key Hasidic themes of redemption and the transformative power of intention and action in spiritual relationships.

passage_content: ובענין איך יצא לוי ממנין השבטים הוא כשנלקח הבכורה מראובן וגם הכהונה אז נתחלק לוי שהיה ממוצע כגוף בין חסד לגבורה ונתחלק כהונ' לצד אחד ממילא נשאר לשאר לווים רק צד שמאל ולכן כהן לוי ישראל ובאמת שורש לוי נשאר למעלה לצד ממוצע והוא כשורש אבל אח"כ הענפים נתחלקו לשנים לכהנים ולוים ובכ"מ כמו שיוסף אינו נמנה שהוא משך הגוף לוי לא נמנה שהוא הגוף עצמו ובמקום שיוסף נמנה גם לוי נמנה:
translation: Regarding how Levi was excluded from the count of the tribes, it is because the birthright was taken from Reuven and the priesthood was also designated. Thus, Levi, who was an intermediary like a body between Chesed and Gevurah, was divided, with the priesthood going to one side. Consequently, the remaining Leviim were left with only the left side. Therefore, we have Kohen, Levi, Yisrael. In truth, the root of Levi remains above on the side of the intermediary, as a root. However, later the branches were divided into two: for the Kohanim and for the Leviim. And in any case, just as Yosef is not counted because he represents the body, Levi is not counted because he is the body itself. In the place where Yosef is counted, Levi is also counted.
summary: The passage discusses the unique status of the tribe of Levi, which emerged after the priesthood was taken from Reuben. Levi is portrayed as a mediating force between the attributes of kindness (Chesed) and severity (Gevurah), with the division of the tribe resulting in the roles of priests (Kohanim) and Levites. The text emphasizes that while Levi represents the physical embodiment of the Jewish people, he is not counted among the tribes in the same way as Joseph, who also embodies a central role. Ultimately, the division reflects a deeper spiritual hierarchy, with Levi's essence remaining connected to a higher, mediating root.

passage_content: כבס ביין לבושו. במד"ר שמחוור להם התורה ובד' ענבים סותה. שמחוור להם טעיותהון כי כתיב במחשכים הושיבני זו תלמוד בבלי וע"ז ספדי גדול הוא בשש"ך הם הש"ך דינים שמחוורין בפילפול התלמוד בבלי ונעשים מהם הכתר בתכשיטי הלכה ושם לו ברקת זו טבריא זה הקו"ף של רקת נתחלף בך' של שש"ך שגם הוא גימ' כתר אלא רקת הוא מה שעולם עליון מכתר לעול' התחתון וששך הוא העולם התחתון שנכתר מעולם העליון ואמר שבעת המשיח יתגלה הסוד שבתלמוד בבלי שהכל מיוסד בגנזי אורייתא בזה יחוור להם ביין שהוא הסוד ואמר שהגם שאדם יאמר שמא אני טועה בפילפולי ואמר שהקב"ה יחוור הטעות שהוא כעין תכשיטי כלה כאמור בזוהר שיר השירים והכל מכוונים ליפות הכלה לכן כולם דברי אלהים חיים ודרשו אין אדם עומד על דברי תורה אלא א"כ נכשל בה ואז יתרון אור מן החושך:
translation: Washed in wine is his garment. In the Midrash, it is explained to them that the Torah and in four grapes, he intoxicates. It is explained to them their mistakes because it is written, "In darkness He has seated me," this refers to the Babylonian Talmud, and on this, the great Sefardi is in the Shach, they are the Shach's laws that are clarified in the pilpul of the Babylonian Talmud and from them the crown is made in the jewels of halacha. And there is a beryl, this is Tiberias, this is the kuf of Rekat, which is exchanged for the shin of Shach, which is also the gematria of crown, but Rekat is what the upper world receives from the crown for the lower world, and Shach is the lower world that is crowned from the upper world. And he said that in the time of the Messiah, the secret in the Babylonian Talmud will be revealed, that everything is founded in the treasures of the Torah; in this, it will be clarified to them in wine, which is the secret. And he said that even if a person says, "Perhaps I am mistaken in my pilpul," it is said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will clarify the mistake, which is like the adornments of a bride, as stated in the Zohar on the Song of Songs, and all are directed to beautify the bride. Therefore, all these are the words of the living God, and it is taught that no one stands on the words of Torah unless he has stumbled in it, and then the advantage of light from the darkness.
summary: The passage emphasizes the transformative power of the Talmud Bavli, likening its intricate discussions to precious adornments that beautify the divine bride, representing the Torah. It suggests that even when one doubts their understanding, God will clarify the truth, revealing deeper insights akin to hidden treasures of the Torah. The text also alludes to the Messianic era, where the secrets of the Talmud will be unveiled, illuminating the connection between the higher and lower worlds. Ultimately, it conveys that encountering challenges in understanding Torah leads to a greater illumination, as darkness gives way to light.

passage_content: לישועתך קויתי ה'. במד"ר הכל בקיווי יסורין קדושת השם. זכות אבות. תאוות עוה"ב הה"ד אף אורח משפטיך קוינוך לשמך ולזכרך תאות נפש. אלו הם ד' מדריגות של העולמות שהיו בתחלה בעולם התוהו הם יסורים בבית הסוהר וכשאדם בא לזה העולם יש לו יסורים ועליה ראשונה הוא בקידוש השם שהוא מלכות ואח"כ לזכות אבות ואח"כ לתאוות עוה"ב שהעלי' עד הבינה ואמר גם חנינה בקיווי שאפילו שהעולמות של חנינה הם בקו מדה במדה וכן הסליחה כי למי נושא עון למי שעובר על פשע ואדם חונן דלים ומעורר מדת החנינה והסליחה במדה וז"ש הקב"ה למי שאין לו היינו שעובד באי"ן והן הבני עלי' דעיילי בלא בר בלי גבול ומ"מ כל ישראל בכלל זה וכל רשעי ארץ. והגם שבדעתם שוב לא יהא להם עוה"ב מגודל רשעתם ועכ"ז עושים איזה צדקה ומצות. היא ללא תשלום שכר וראוי' בוודאי לחנינה. ומכ"ש הצדיקים שמגודל צדקתם אינם בטוחים כלל בשכר כמאמר דוד. וא"כ הם עובדי' להש"י בחנם ולא נוציא מזה אלא איזה בינונים וסכלים וכל ישראל ראוים לחנינה: (עד כאן)
translation: To Your salvation, I have hoped, O Lord. In the Midrash, everything is in the hope of suffering, the sanctity of the Name. The merit of the Patriarchs. The desires of the World to Come, as it is said, "Even the path of Your judgments, we hope for Your Name and for Your remembrance, the desire of the soul." These are the four levels of the worlds that were initially in the world of Tohu; they are sufferings in the prison. And when a person comes to this world, he has sufferings, and the first ascent is in the sanctification of the Name, which is kingship, and afterwards to the merit of the Patriarchs, and then to the desires of the World to Come, which ascend to understanding. And it is also said that grace is in hope, for even though the worlds of grace are measured, so too is forgiveness, for to whom does He bear sin? To one who transgresses a transgression. And a person grants grace to the poor and awakens the attribute of grace and forgiveness in measure. And thus it is said, the Holy One, blessed be He, to one who has none, meaning one who works in nothingness, and they are the sons of ascent who enter without measure, without limit. Nevertheless, all of Israel is included in this, and all the wicked of the earth. And although in their minds they will not have the World to Come due to their great wickedness, nevertheless, they do some charity and commandments. It is without payment of reward and certainly worthy of grace. How much more so the righteous, who due to their great righteousness are not at all secure in reward, as David said. And thus they serve the Holy One, blessed be He, for free, and we will not derive from this except for some intermediates and fools, and all of Israel are worthy of grace.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of hope in God's salvation and the role of suffering as a means of sanctifying God's name. It outlines four spiritual levels, beginning with the suffering in this world, leading to the merit of the ancestors, and culminating in the desire for the World to Come. It highlights the concept of divine grace and forgiveness, suggesting that even those who have sinned can attain mercy through acts of charity and good deeds, while the righteous serve God selflessly, not seeking reward. Ultimately, it conveys that all of Israel, regardless of their actions, are deserving of divine compassion.

passage_content: ויברך את יוסף ויאמר האלהים אשר התהלכו אבותי לפניו. במד"ר ר"ב ואמרי לה בשם ר"י ור"ל ר"י אמר לרוע' שהוא עומד ומביט בצאנו. ר"ל אמר לנשיא מהלך והזקנים לפניו על דעת' דר"י אנו צריכין לכבודו על דעתיה דר"ל הוא צריך לכבודנו. ע"ש פירושו בפירוש מ"כ. ונראה לומר ע"פ מ"ש כבר במקום אחר דשני דרכים לעובדי ה' האחד הוא מתהלך לפני ה' וצריך סעד לתומכו ולשמרו מכל עצת יצה"ר והיא למשל כמו התינוק הולך לפני אמו ואמו משגחת עליו שלא יפול ולא ימעדו קרסוליו. ויש עוד דרך יותר חזק כשמתישן בצדקו ומתגבר ללכת אחרי ה' עד שאינו צריך שומר והוא כמו התינוק שמתגדל והולך אחרי אמו ואינו צריך להשגחת' ולשמירתה. וזה שמצינו אפי' באברהם אבינו ע"ה קודם שנימול אמר לו הקב"ה התהלך לפני כי עדיין לא קיבל את התורה רק ששמר מעצמו כל התורה לכן עדיין צריך שמירת הבורא ב"ה והוצרך להתהלך לפניו מה שאין כן בנ"י אחרי קבלתם התורה מן השמים כתיב אחרי ה' אלהיכם תלכו שיתחזקו בדרך הטוב עד שיהיו נשמרים מאליהם וילכו כתינוק המתהלך אחרי אמו וזה פלוגתת ר"י ור"ל ר"י אמר לרועה שהוא מביט בצאנו והוא משגיח עליהם לשמרם. ור"ל אמר לנשיא מהלך והזקנים לפניו. היינו שהם אין צריכים לו. ואפשר עוד לומר כי כל אחד לשיטתו אזיל. ר"י שהוא מתהלך בצדקו וקדושתו מיום הולדו ולא נטה ללכת ימין ושמאל לכן דרכו צריך שימור כל ימיו שלא ילכד בעצת יצרו כי לא ידע את מהמוריו ועצתו אשר יקוש בהם בני אדם לכן צריך לשמיר' הבורא ב"ה. וזה שדרש כעין דרכו. משא"כ ר"ל שהיה רחוק ונתקרב לקדושה ע"י גיסו ר' יוחנן כמבואר במס' בבא מציעא פרק הפועלים ובוודאי בעל תשובה כמוהו נשמר מעצמו כי הוא צריך לעבוד ביתר שאת ולשמור נפשו מפחת יצרו אשר כבר יודע כי נלכדו רגליו לכן שומר את נפשו ואינו צריך לשמירה מלמעלה ולפי דרכו דרש המקרא:
translation: And he blessed Joseph and said, "The God before whom my fathers walked." In Midrash Rabbah, it is said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Elazar. Rabbi Yochanan said to the shepherd who stands and watches over his flock. Rabbi Elazar said to the prince who walks and the elders before him, according to the understanding of Rabbi Yochanan, we need to honor him, while according to the understanding of Rabbi Elazar, he needs to honor us. The explanation of this is found in the commentary of M'k. And it seems to say, based on what has already been mentioned elsewhere, that there are two paths for the servants of God. One is to walk before God and require support to uphold him and protect him from all the counsel of the evil inclination, and this is like a child walking before his mother, and the mother watches over him so that he does not fall and his ankles do not stumble. There is another, stronger path when one strengthens himself in his righteousness and overcomes to walk after God until he does not need a guardian, and this is like a child who grows up and walks after his mother and does not need her supervision and protection. This is what we find even with our forefather Abraham, peace be upon him, before he was circumcised, when the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "Walk before Me," for he had not yet received the Torah, but he kept all the Torah by himself; therefore, he still needed the Creator's protection and had to walk before Him. This is not the case with the Children of Israel, after they received the Torah from heaven, as it is written, "You shall walk after the Lord your God," so that they strengthen themselves in the good way until they are protected by themselves and walk like a child walking after his mother. And this is the dispute between Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Elazar. Rabbi Yochanan said to the shepherd who watches over his flock, and he supervises them to protect them. Rabbi Elazar said to the prince who walks and the elders before him, meaning they do not need him. It is also possible to say that each one follows his own reasoning. Rabbi Yochanan, who walks in his righteousness and holiness from the day of his birth and has not swayed to the right or to the left, therefore his path requires protection all his days so that he does not get caught in the counsel of his inclination, for he does not know the counsel of his masters and the advice by which people get ensnared; therefore, he needs the protection of the Creator, blessed be He. This is what he interpreted in a manner similar to his path. In contrast, Rabbi Elazar, who was distant and drew close to holiness through his brother-in-law Rabbi Yochanan, as explained in Tractate Baba Metzia, Chapter of the Workers, and certainly a penitent like him protects himself because he needs to work with greater strength and guard his soul from the fear of his inclination, which he already knows has ensnared his feet; therefore, he guards his soul and does not need protection from above, and according to his path, he interpreted the verse.
summary: The passage discusses two approaches to serving God: one where a person walks before God and requires divine protection, akin to a child needing a mother's watchful care, and another where a person grows in righteousness and can follow God independently, like a mature child. It contrasts the experiences of Abraham, who needed divine guidance before receiving the Torah, with the Israelites, who, after accepting the Torah, are encouraged to walk after God with self-sufficiency. The differing views of Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer highlight the necessity of divine support for those who are still vulnerable to temptation, while those who have achieved a higher level of holiness may not require such protection.
