passage_content: או יאמר על דרך אומרם ז"ל (בראשית רבה ס"ו, ד') הצדיקים תחילתן יסורים וסופן שלוה. וזה אומרו מטרף בני שעל ידי טרפת בני בבחינת היסורין מזה עלית עד אשר כרע רבץ כארי וגו' כי סופן שלוה וממשלה, ולזה אמר הכתוב.
translation: Or it can be said in the manner of our Sages, of blessed memory (Bereishit Rabbah 66:4), that the righteous begin with suffering and end with tranquility. This is the meaning of "from the tearing of the sons," for through the tearing of the sons, in the aspect of suffering, you have ascended until "he crouched and lay down like a lion," etc., for their end is tranquility and dominion. And thus the verse states.
summary: The passage emphasizes the Hasidic belief that the righteous experience suffering at the beginning of their journey, which ultimately leads to peace and authority. This concept is illustrated through the metaphor of a lion, suggesting that through enduring trials, one can achieve a state of strength and tranquility. The text reflects the idea that suffering is a necessary precursor to spiritual elevation and fulfillment. Ultimately, it conveys the message that the path of the righteous, though fraught with challenges, culminates in divine reward and serenity.

passage_content: לא יסור שבט מיהודה וגו'. כי הכתוב אומר (משלי י"ג, כ"ד) חושך שבטו שונא בנו וכן הקב"ה עם ישראל כי את אשר יאהב ה' יוכיח (שם ג', י"ב) ולא יחשוך שבטו ממנו ועל כן לא יסור ה' שבט מיהודה בכדי להזכירו תמיד ביראת ה' והכנעתו עד כי יבוא שילה מלך המשיח ואז ומחה ה' אלהים דמעה מעל כל פנים שלא יהיה שום בחינת יסורין בעולם כי אם שלום וברכה השקט ובטח.
translation: The scepter shall not depart from Judah, etc. For the scripture says (Proverbs 13:24), "He who spares his rod hates his son," and so too the Holy One, Blessed be He, with Israel, for "whom the Lord loves, He reproves" (Proverbs 3:12), and He will not withhold His rod from him. Therefore, the Lord will not remove the scepter from Judah in order to always remind him of the fear of the Lord and his submission, until Shiloh comes, the King Messiah. Then the Lord God will wipe away tears from all faces, so that there will be no form of suffering in the world, but only peace and blessing, tranquility and security.
summary: The passage emphasizes the enduring presence of the tribe of Judah as a symbol of divine guidance and discipline, reflecting the idea that God's love for Israel is demonstrated through correction and instruction. It highlights the belief that the Messiah, referred to as Shiloh, will ultimately bring an end to suffering and usher in an era of peace and security. This underscores the Hasidic concept of divine providence and the transformative power of redemption, where God's love leads to both accountability and ultimate salvation.

passage_content: אא"ז מו"ר זצלה"ה הגיד ויחי יעקב בא"מ כי ע"י בחי' אמת יכולין לחיות גם בא"מ וכ' תתן אמת ליעקב עכ"ד. דהנה לא הל"ל רק ויהי יעקב בא"מ. ומשמע דעיקר הרבותא מה שהי' בבחי' חיים גם בא"מ ופי' חיים הוא דביקות בשורש ומקור שמשם נמשך תמיד חיות. וכ"כ בזוה"ק ויגש ע"פ ותחי רוח יעקב. ונ"ל שהוא מלשון מים חיים שע"י שמחת הנפש מעורר מקור החיים וניתוסף חיות. [ונ"ל שז"ש ויהי האדם לנפש חי'. פי' נפש. הרצון. ע"י פנימיות הנפש נמשך חיות תמיד]. והגם שהי' בא"מ ידע שכל המצרים הם רק קליפה והסתר. אבל הפנימיות הוא חיות הש"י. ולכך אחז"ל כי הרשעים בחייהם נק' מתים שנפרשים ממקור החיות כנ"ל. וכ' במדרש גרים אנחנו כו' כי כל בריאת אדם בעוה"ז לא הי' כדי להידבק ח"ו בעוה"ז. רק להיפוך שע"י דביקות האדם בעיקר החיות מתמשך גם עניני עוה"ז להש"י. וגר לשון המשכה כמו מעלה גרה. שגם מה שנק' גר מי שמגייר עצמו. ג"כ ע"ש זה. שמוציא נקודה קדושה שהי' נטבע באומות. וכן ענין גלות מצרים שכ' גר יהי' זרעך כו' ג"כ הפי' להוציא נ"ק שנטבעו במצרים. וז"ש ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול [רכוש גדול ר"ת גר רק מהופך שזה הענין הוא מלמטה למעלה כמובן]. וז"ש רש"י ז"ל ביקש לגלות הקץ. פי' שרצה לברר זה שהגלות רק הסתר והכח פנימי הוא רק מהש"י. רק אם הי' נגלה זה לא הי' גלות כלל. ונסתם. ומ"מ כ' בזוה"ק שגילה מה שרצה לגלות רק בדרך הסתר. והפי' ע"י אמונה יכולין למצוא האמת להתברר שהוא רק הסתר כנ"ל. ולכך ויחי יעקב סתום. שזה מקור החיות להיות נמצא גם בא"מ. זה נסתם [ולכך נק' שהתחיל השעבוד] וכמדומה לי שאא"ז ז"ל הגיד בשם הרב מפרשיסחא ז"ל שהקשה למה רצה לגלות הקץ. ותי' שכשנודע הקץ. הגלות בנקל. ע"כ אני זוכר. ונראה כנ"ל שפי' גילוי הקץ לידע שיש קץ להגלות. והוא ע"י שהוא רק הסתר ואינו כח בפ"ע ח"ו. כי הפנימיות שהוא אמת אין לו קץ וההסתר יש לו קץ. ורצה שיהי' זה נגלה. ולא הי' גלות כלל. ונשאר סתום. ומ"מ ע"י אמונה שמאמינים זה בנ"י. שאין שום כח בלתי הש"י רק כ"ז רק הסתר. אף שאין רואין זה בעין. מ"מ ע"י אמונה ג"כ יכולין לראות האמת. רק יעקב אע"ה רצה שלא נוכל לטעות כלל. שיהי' זה נגלה. ונשאר סתום שצריכין יגיעה למצוא זה. וזה בחי' דהמע"ה דלית לי' מגרמי' כו'. ומשיג האמת רק ע"י הביטול. וזה ההפרש שבין אמת לאמונה. וכ"כ אא"ז מו"ר זצלה"ה על יעקב אבינו לא מת. מקרא אני דורש כו'. שכשאדם דורש ומייגע עצמו שזה בחי' תושבע"פ. יכול למצוא הארה מחיות יעקב אבינו גם בתוך ההסתר. וגם בשבת מתעורר בחי' יעקב כמ"ש והאכלתיך נחלת יעקב ע"י הביטול כו' מתעברין מינה כו':
translation: The esteemed Rabbi, may his memory be a blessing, explained that "and Jacob lived in the land of Egypt" means that through the aspect of truth, one can live even in Egypt. It is written, "You shall give truth to Jacob." Thus, it could have simply stated, "And Jacob lived in Egypt," implying that the main novelty is that he was in a state of life even in Egypt. The interpretation of life is a connection to the root and source from which life is continually drawn. This is also stated in the Zohar, "And he approached," based on "and the spirit of Jacob revived." It seems to me that this is from the language of living waters, for through the joy of the soul, the source of life is awakened, and vitality is added. [And it seems to me that the verse "and man became a living soul" refers to the soul, the will. Through the inner essence of the soul, vitality is continually drawn.] And although he was in Egypt, he knew that all the constraints were merely a shell and concealment. However, the inner essence is the vitality of the Holy One, blessed be He. Therefore, our sages have said that the wicked in their lifetime are called dead, as they are separated from the source of life, as mentioned. It is written in the Midrash, "We are strangers..." because the entire creation of man in this world was not to cling to this world, God forbid, but rather the opposite: that through the clinging of man to the essence of life, the matters of this world are also drawn to the Holy One, blessed be He. The term "ger" (stranger) implies continuation, as in "a ger is raised." Even one who converts himself is also referred to as such, for he brings forth a holy point that was embedded among the nations. Similarly, the matter of the Egyptian exile, as it is written, "Your seed shall be a stranger..." also refers to bringing forth the holy points that were embedded in Egypt. This is what is meant by "and afterward they went out with great wealth" [great wealth is an acronym for "ger," but reversed, indicating that this matter is from below to above, as is understood]. This is what Rashi, may his memory be a blessing, wrote: he sought to reveal the end, meaning he wanted to clarify that the exile is merely a concealment, and the inner strength is only from the Holy One, blessed be He. If this were revealed, there would be no exile at all, and it was concealed. Nevertheless, it is written in the Zohar that he revealed what he wanted to reveal only in a concealed manner. The interpretation is that through faith, one can find the truth to clarify that it is only a concealment, as mentioned. Therefore, "and Jacob lived" is concealed. This is the source of life being present even in Egypt. This was concealed [and thus it is called that the servitude began], and it seems to me that the esteemed Rabbi, may his memory be a blessing, explained in the name of the Rabbi from Preshischa, may his memory be a blessing, who asked why he wanted to reveal the end. He answered that when the end is known, the exile is easily resolved. Therefore, I remember. It appears, as mentioned, that the interpretation of revealing the end is to know that there is an end to the exile. This is through the understanding that it is only a concealment and not a power in itself, God forbid, because the inner essence, which is truth, has no end, while the concealment has an end. He wanted this to be revealed, and there would be no exile at all, but it remained concealed. Nevertheless, through faith, believing this in the Children of Israel, that there is no power apart from the Holy One, blessed be He, only that it is all merely a concealment. Even though this is not seen with the eye, through faith, one can also see the truth. However, Jacob, our father, wanted that we should not be able to err at all, that this should be revealed. It remained concealed, and we need effort to find this. This is the aspect of "the Holy One, blessed be He, has no self." He grasps the truth only through nullification. This is the distinction between truth and faith. The esteemed Rabbi, may his memory be a blessing, also said about our father Jacob that he did not die. "I interpret the verse..." that when a person seeks and exerts himself, this is the aspect of the Oral Torah, he can find illumination from the vitality of our father Jacob even within the concealment. And also on Shabbat, the aspect of Jacob is awakened, as it is said, "And I will feed you with the inheritance of Jacob," through nullification, etc., they are imbued from him, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of living with truth (אמת) even in a world of concealment (א"מ), emphasizing that true life is found in the connection to the divine source of vitality. It highlights that the challenges of existence are merely external veils, while the inner essence is the life force of God. The text also reflects on the idea that the purpose of human existence is to draw down divine energy into the physical world, and that through faith and effort, one can uncover the hidden truth of God's presence, even amidst suffering and exile. Ultimately, it suggests that the revelation of the end of exile is tied to recognizing that the concealment itself is temporary and not an independent force.

passage_content: במדרש ושמעו אל ישראל אביכם מה הקב"ה בורא עולמות אף יעקב אביכם כו'. נ"ל כי חיות מצרים עצמו הי' ע"י יעקב. וזהו עשה הש"י הכנה לגאולה כענין שכ' בזוה"ק על יוסף שהי' צריך להיות מקודם כפוף ת"י השבטים ע"ש וישב. כמו כן מ"ש ויחי יעקב בא"מ פי' חיות א"מ עצמו הי' ע"י יעקב. וזהו בורא עולמות שנותן חיות בתוך ההעלם:
translation: In the Midrash, "And hear, O Israel, your father," what the Holy One, blessed be He, creates worlds, so too Jacob, your father, etc. It seems to me that the vitality of Egypt itself was through Jacob. And this is what the Holy One, blessed be He, prepared for redemption, as it is written in the Zohar about Joseph, who needed to be first submissive to the ten tribes, as it is written, "And he dwelt." Likewise, what is written, "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," means that the vitality of the land of Egypt itself was through Jacob. And this is the Creator of worlds who gives vitality within the concealment.
summary: The passage emphasizes the role of Jacob (Yaakov) in the divine plan of creation and redemption, suggesting that his presence and actions were instrumental in sustaining the vitality of the world, particularly in Egypt. It draws a parallel between Jacob and Joseph, indicating that just as Joseph's humility was necessary for the unfolding of the divine narrative, so too was Jacob's life essential for the hidden vitality within the world. The text highlights the concept of God creating worlds and infusing them with life, even amidst concealment, through the actions of righteous individuals like Jacob. Ultimately, it reflects a Hasidic understanding of the interconnectedness of divine providence and human agency in the process of redemption.

passage_content: בזוה"ק פי' וזאת אשר דיבר להם. כי הטביע בהם בחי' זאת. שהפירוד נק' אלה. ובחי' הקדושה. מ"ש. חיות הש"י נק' זאת. ודיבר מלשון דבר א' לדור. שלמד להם שינהגו כל מעשיהם ע"פ בחי' זאת להיות נמשך הכל אחר נקודה הפנימיות כנ"ל. [וז"ש כל אלה כו' וזאת כו'] והבן:
translation: In the Zohar it is explained, "And this is what He spoke to them." For He instilled in them this aspect, that separation is called "Elohim." And the aspect of holiness, as it is said, "The living beings of the Holy One, Blessed be He," are called "this." And "spoke" is from the term "Dibur," which means to teach them to conduct all their actions according to this aspect, so that everything should be drawn after the inner point, as mentioned above. [And this is what is meant by "all these" and "this" etc.] Understand.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the Zohar emphasizes the distinction between the divine aspect of holiness and the separation represented by the term "אלה" (Elohim). It highlights that the essence of divine life, referred to as "חיות הש"י," is connected to the inner point of spirituality. The teaching encourages individuals to align their actions with this inner essence, suggesting that all deeds should be guided by this deeper spiritual understanding. The phrase "כל אלה וזאת" underscores the unity of these concepts within the framework of divine revelation and practice.

passage_content: אא"ז מו"ר זצלה"ה הגיד עמ"ש השבעה לי כו' וישתחו ישראל כו' ופרש"י שהי' מטתו שלימה שהרי יוסף מלך כו' ע"ש. ומה ענינו לשבועה זו. ופי' שע"י השבועה שהוא התדבקות כל החיות ז' מדות נתוודע בחי' יוסף ליעקב ע"ש ודפח"ח. ונ"ל להוסיף כי למה צריך להשביעו. ונראה כי לא הי' זה דבר קטן מה שחגר יוסף מתניו להיות בזכותו הגאולה במצרים. וכ"כ חז"ל שע"י יוסף היו גדורין בעריות. וכן הים ראה וינס כו'. וזה שלא נקבר יעקב בא"מ כ' בזוה"ק ע"י שהבטיחו הש"י אנכי אעלך כו' להיות נקבר בארץ ע"ש. ושם כ' ויוסף ישית ידו כו'. ונראה שכח יעקב נתן ליוסף. וע"י השבועה נתדבק בכל כחו וקיבל בחי' יעקב להיות נשאר חי גם בתוך מצרים כו'. וע"י שראה כי בניו קיבלו כוחו להיות נשארים אחר הסתלקותו בא"מ. השתחוה שזה בחי' מיטתו שלימה. וז"ש ויראו כו' כי מת אביהם כו' לו ישטמנו כו' כי הכירו שבחי' אביהם נשאר אצל יוסף כי לא הי' אצלם וע"כ נשאר אצל יוסף:
translation:
The esteemed Rabbi, may his memory be a blessing, explained that it was said to me, "And Israel bowed down," and Rashi explained that his bed was complete since Joseph was king, etc. What is the connection to this oath? It is explained that through the oath, which is the attachment of all the seven attributes, the essence of Joseph was revealed to Jacob, etc. And may it be for a good purpose. 

I would like to add that why was it necessary to swear him? It seems that it was not a small matter that Joseph girded his loins to merit the redemption in Egypt. And so our Sages have said that through Joseph, they were protected from immorality. And likewise, the sea saw and fled, etc. This is why Jacob was not buried in the Land of Israel, as it is written in the Zohar, because the Holy One, blessed be He, promised him, "I will bring you up," etc., to be buried in the land, etc. And there it is written, "And Joseph will place his hand," etc. 

It seems that Jacob's strength was given to Joseph. And through the oath, he attached himself to all his strength and received the essence of Jacob to remain alive even within Egypt, etc. And by seeing that his sons received his strength to remain after his passing in the Land of Israel, he bowed down, for this is the aspect of his complete bed. And this is what is meant by "And they saw," etc., that their father had died, etc., "lest he will hate us," etc., for they recognized that the essence of their father remained with Joseph, for it was not with them, and therefore it remained with Joseph.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's oath and its connection to the spiritual legacy of Jacob. It emphasizes that through this oath, Joseph embodies the qualities of Jacob, ensuring the continuity of their lineage and spiritual strength even in Egypt. The text highlights that Joseph's actions and character were pivotal in maintaining moral integrity and divine protection for the Israelites, reflecting the deep bond between father and son. Ultimately, it illustrates how Jacob's essence remained with Joseph, allowing him to sustain his family's faith and identity in a foreign land.

passage_content: אא"ז מו"ר ז"ל פי' ברכת יוסף הצדיק ברכות אביך גברו כו' זה בחי' שבת שכ' ז"ל המענג את השבת נותנין לו נחלה בלי מצרים כו'. והפי' ע"י שיודע כי חיות הכל מהש"י שיש נקודה פנימיות בכל דבר ממנו ית'. וכפי ידיעת זאת הנקודה כך נתברך ונדבק הכל בשורש החיים. וממילא לא שייך מיצר וסוף לזה כי הנקודה חיות מהש"י אין לה סוף כי מא"ס היא. אך פי' המענג את השבת הוא שכל תענוגיו הם רק לזאת הנקודה הפנימיות שנק' שבת באמת שהוא מנוחת הכל. ולאשר יודע שהוא העיקר נתברך בזה. ונק' תאות גבעות עולם שכל הנבראים מתאוין לידבק בזאת הנקודה כי היא מחי' כולם. ואא"ז מו"ר ז"ל פי' ויחי יעקב בא"מ שע"י בחי' אמת כמ"ש תתן אמת ליעקב יכולין להתקיים גם בא"מ. והוא ידיעה הנ"ל שהכל חיות הנקודה הפנימיות וזה אמת. כי שקר אין לו רגלים. ואמת מקיים העולם כנ"ל. וכשדביקין באמת כנ"ל לא יש מיצר כי כולם מושכין חיות מזה:
translation: The esteemed Rabbi, may his memory be blessed, explains the blessing of Joseph the Righteous: "The blessings of your father have surpassed..." This is the aspect of Shabbat, as he, may his memory be blessed, wrote: "One who delights in the Shabbat is given an inheritance without measure..." The explanation is that by knowing that the life of all comes from the Holy One, blessed be He, there is an inner point in everything from Him. And according to the knowledge of this point, so is one blessed and attached to the root of life. Consequently, there is no place for limitation or end to this, for the point of life from the Holy One, blessed be He, has no end, as it is from the Infinite. However, the explanation of delighting in the Shabbat is that all his pleasures are only for this inner point, which is truly called Shabbat, as it is the rest of all. And one who knows that this is the essence is blessed in this. It is called the desire of the hills of the world, for all creations yearn to attach themselves to this point, for it gives life to all. And the esteemed Rabbi, may his memory be blessed, explained: "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," that through the aspect of truth, as it is said, "You shall give truth to Jacob," they can also exist in the land of Egypt. This is the aforementioned knowledge that all life is from the inner point, and this is the truth, for falsehood has no legs. And truth sustains the world, as mentioned. And when they are attached to the truth, as mentioned, there is no limitation, for all draw life from this.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the inner point of divine life within all creation, emphasizing that true enjoyment and blessing come from recognizing this divine essence, particularly through the observance of Shabbat. It highlights that those who understand and connect with this inner point experience a boundless life, free from limitations, as it is rooted in the infinite nature of God. The text also connects the idea of truth with the sustenance of existence, asserting that by adhering to this truth, one can attain a lasting connection to the divine source of life. Ultimately, it conveys that all beings yearn to unite with this inner point, which sustains and enlivens them.

passage_content: ויברך את יוסף. והקשו כי אין הברכה רק להנערים. אך כי כל ברכה הוא מבחי' יוסף שהוא להיות כל דבר נדבק ונקשר בשורשו שהוא חיות הנקודה הפנימיות מהש"י ממילא יש ברכה כי בשורש יש תמיד התחדשות. וכן בשבת כ' ויברך ויקדש מיני' מתברכין כל שיתא יומין ע"י שנתברר בשבת כי הש"י ברא כל הנבראים עי"ז ניתוסף להם חיות מחדש על כל ימי הבריאה. ובנ"י שמעידין ע"ז בש"ק מתברכין. וכ"פ אא"ז מו"ר ז"ל מ"ש וידגו כו' בקרב הארץ ובמד' פי' כדגים שפותחין פיהם לטיפה מים כאילו לא טעמו כו'. והוסיף הפי' אף שהם בקרב הארץ וע"כ עושין מעשים גשמיים. מ"מ יהי' עיקר החיות להש"י כמ"ש כי הם חיינו כו' ולהיות תמיד דבוק בשורש זה הברכה כנ"ל. וכ' ישימך כו' כאפרים כו'. וקשה כי רק כראובן ושמעון יהיו כו' ואמאי נתיחד הברכה ישימך כאפרים ומנשה. אך כי לאשר הי' דור שאחר השבטים ומ"מ נתעלו להיות בכללם. וזה ע"י הברכה כנ"ל להיות דבוק בשורש אף שהם למטה במדרגה. ובאופן זה יוכל להיות נמשך ברכה לכל איש ישראל מאבות הקדושים אף אלף דור כי השורש מהם. ובזה י"ל ג"כ מ"ש ויברך את יוסף. כיון שנתעלו בניו להיות שבטים. ממילא נתעלה הוא יותר [ועיין בזוה"ק הטעם שיוסף לא נמנה בין השבטים כי נתעלה למעלה מבחי' שבטים ע"ש]:
translation: And he blessed Joseph. They questioned why the blessing is only for the youths. However, every blessing comes from the aspect of Joseph, which is to have everything adhere and connect to its root, which is the life of the inner point from the Blessed One. Therefore, there is a blessing, for in the root there is always renewal. Likewise, on Shabbat it is written, "And he blessed and sanctified," from it all six days are blessed because it was clarified on Shabbat that the Blessed One created all the creations, and through this they receive renewed life for all the days of creation. And the Children of Israel testify to this on Shabbat, they are blessed. And so our teacher, may his memory be blessed, explained what is written, "And you shall be fruitful and multiply," in the midst of the land, and in the Midrash it is explained like fish that open their mouths for a drop of water as if they have not tasted. And he added the explanation that even though they are in the midst of the land, and therefore they perform physical actions, nevertheless, the main life should be for the Blessed One, as it is written, "For they are our life," and to always be attached to this root of the blessing, as mentioned above. And it is written, "He shall make you like Ephraim and Manasseh." It is difficult because only like Reuben and Simeon shall they be, and why is the blessing specifically "He shall make you like Ephraim and Manasseh"? However, for the generation that came after the tribes, they were elevated to be included in them. And this is through the blessing mentioned above, to be attached to the root even though they are lower in rank. In this way, a blessing can be drawn to every Jew from the holy ancestors, even a thousand generations, for the root is from them. And in this, we can also say what is written, "And he blessed Joseph," since his sons were elevated to be tribes. Therefore, he himself was elevated even more [and see in the Zohar the reason why Joseph was not counted among the tribes, for he was elevated above the aspect of tribes, as mentioned there].
summary: The passage discusses the concept of blessing as rooted in the essence of Joseph, symbolizing the connection of all things to their divine source, which brings renewal and vitality. It emphasizes that through the observance of Shabbat, all creations receive renewed life, and the Jewish people testify to this blessing. The text highlights that even those in lower spiritual states can attain connection to their roots through blessings, allowing for the potential of divine vitality to flow to all Jews, extending even to future generations. Ultimately, it notes that Joseph's elevation, through his sons becoming tribes, signifies a higher spiritual status beyond that of the tribes themselves.

The invocation of divine assistance underscores the belief in God's active role in guiding and supporting one's spiritual journey. Overall, it encapsulates the aspiration for a life rooted in faith and communal values.

passage_content: ברש"י נסתמו עיניהם ולבם כו'. כי באמת לב ועינים של איש ישראל הוא להשי"ת. ורק אחר שנפטר יעקב אע"ה נסתם ונסתר האמת. וכ' ול"ת אחרי לבבכם כו' עיניכם כו' כמו שהוא בהסתר החיצוניות. וזה עיקר הגלות להפנימיות שא"י להתפשט בכל האדם. והעצה שמעתי מא"א מו"ז ז"ל ע"פ ויחי יעקב בא"מ. שע"י אמת יכולים לעורר החיות גם בכל הסתר ומיצר כמ"ש תתן אמת ליעקב. והוא להיות בטל תמיד אל הפנימיות שהוא האמת. שהחיצוניות אינו אמת. רק הסתר. ולפי הרצון שבאדם באמת בכל דבר להיות נעשה רצון המקום ב"ה בלבד. כמו כן נתגלה לו האמת. ואדרבה בכל מקום שיש יותר הסתר. שמה נגנז דבר פנימי כנודע. וכן מצינו במצות מילה שאבר המילה הוא קודש. ולכן שם דוקא מקום הערלה. וכמ"ש סוד ה' ליראיו ודרשו ז"ל על המילה:
translation: In Rashi, their eyes and hearts were closed, etc. For indeed, the heart and eyes of a Jew are for the Holy One, Blessed be He. And only after Jacob, our father, passed away, was the truth concealed and hidden. And it is written, "And do not stray after your hearts, etc., and your eyes," as it is in the concealment of the external. And this is the essence of the exile, for the inner self cannot be revealed in all of man. And the advice I heard from my revered teacher, may his memory be blessed, based on "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," is that through truth one can awaken life even in all concealment and distress, as it is said, "You shall give truth to Jacob." And this is to be constantly nullified to the inner self, which is the truth, for the external is not truth, but only concealment. And according to the true desire within a person in everything, the will of the Omnipresent, blessed be He, alone should be done. Likewise, the truth will be revealed to him. And conversely, wherever there is more concealment, there an inner matter is hidden, as is known. And so we find in the commandment of circumcision that the organ of circumcision is holy. Therefore, there specifically is the place of the foreskin. And as it is written, "The secret of the Lord is with those who fear Him," and our sages expounded on the circumcision.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the true essence of a Jewish person's heart and eyes is directed towards God, but this truth becomes obscured after the passing of Jacob. It emphasizes that the exile represents a concealment of inner truth, and that through the pursuit of truth, one can awaken vitality even in times of concealment. The text highlights the importance of being constantly aligned with this inner truth, as external appearances are mere illusions. Additionally, it notes that deeper truths are often hidden in places of greater concealment, as illustrated by the significance of the mitzvah of circumcision, where the act reveals a sacred aspect of the body.

passage_content: ויברך את יוסף כו' יברך כו' הנערים כו'. לשון התעוררות כמ"ש אא"ז מו"ר ז"ל פי' נער על שיש בו התעוררות יותר. ונתן ברכה בבחי' התעוררות של ישראל והיא בחי' יוסף. הגואל אותי. ומה גאולה הי' צריך יעקב אבינו. וי"ל על הנקודה שנשאר בבנ"י מהאבות כמ"ש אא"ז מו"ר ז"ל פי' מגן אברהם שיש נקודה ממנו בכל איש מישראל שהקב"ה מגין עלי' וכן בכל האבות. ואותי הוא אות [ברית] קודש שנשאר ממנו לזרעו. וזה צריך שמירה מכל רע. וידגו לרוב כו' פי' מו"ז ז"ל בקרב הארץ הגשמיות. הוא כנ"ל שיתפשט נקודה הנ"ל בכל מקומות מושבותיהם כנ"ל:
translation: "And he blessed Joseph, etc. He will bless, etc. the youths, etc. This is a language of awakening, as our teacher, may his memory be a blessing, explained that 'youth' refers to one who has more awakening within him. And he gave a blessing in the aspect of the awakening of Israel, which is the aspect of Joseph. 'He who redeems me.' And what redemption did our forefather Jacob need? It can be explained regarding the point that remains in the Children of Israel from the forefathers, as our teacher, may his memory be a blessing, explained that the 'Shield of Abraham' has a point from him in every Jew, which the Holy One, blessed be He, protects. And so too with all the forefathers. And 'me' is the sign [of the] holy covenant that remains from him for his descendants. And this needs protection from all evil. 'And they shall multiply greatly,' etc. Our teacher, may his memory be a blessing, explained that in the midst of the physical land, it is as mentioned above that this point should spread throughout all their dwelling places, as mentioned above."
summary: The passage discusses the blessing given by Jacob to Joseph and his sons, emphasizing the concept of "awakening" as a key aspect of spiritual growth. It highlights the idea that each Jew carries a divine spark from the patriarchs, which serves as a protective shield, referred to as the "Magen Avraham." This divine connection requires safeguarding from negativity, and the blessing of "multiplying" signifies the expansion of this spiritual essence throughout the physical world. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic belief in the importance of nurturing the inner spiritual potential within every individual.

passage_content: למה פ' זו סתומה שנסתמו עיניהם ולבן כו' ד"א שביקש לגלות הקץ ונסתם ממנו. הכלל שחיות כל הנבראים הוא התורה. וגם כל הזמנים ואף בגלות. פנימיות החיות מהתורה. רק שהוא בדרך נסתר. ופרשה זו הוא חיות שנות הגלות. וז"ש ויחי יעקב בא"מ כי יעקב אע"ה המשיך החיות גם במצרים. ושמעתי ממו"ז ז"ל רמז שע"י בחי' אמת יכולין לחיות גם במצרים כמ"ש תתן אמת ליעקב. וענין הפרשה היא התפשטות חיות התורה לכל הנבראים. והפסקות הם ליתן ריוח להתבונן כו'. להעמיד כל פרט ופרט על מכונו. וכן הי' בזמן שבנ"י שרוין על אדמתן והי' כל המעשים ע"פ התורה ממש. ועתה בגלות פרשה סתומה שצריך להיות אמונה בדרך כלל. וכן בפנימיות סוד הקץ הוא נקודה חיות שורש האחדות שנק' רזא דאחד כי בגלות הוא בסוד חתום. ולעתיד יתגלה ויהי' ה' ושמו אחד. וכפי שבאין לשורש נקודה זו יוצאין מהגלות. לכן ש"ק דאתאחדת ברזא דאחד ויש עלי' לכל הנבראים לשורשם ובפרט בנ"י שמתאספין בנפשותיהם במס"נ עבור קדושת שמו ית' בש"ק [כמ"ש במ"א]. לכן כ' והאכלתיך נחלת יעקב כו' בלי מצרים כדכ' ויחי יעקב בא"מ שהמשיך גם שם בחי' החיות וממילא בלי מצרים. וכ' האספו ואגידה כו' ואי' בזוה"ק כי אע"פ שנסתם ממנו מ"מ גילה מה שחפץ לגלות רק בדרך נסתר וכשבנ"י מתאספין ומתבטלין לשורש החיות יכולין למצוא מקומו של יעקב כדאי' יעקב אבינו לא מת כו' מקרא אני דורש כו' ופי' אא"ז מו"ר ז"ל כי כשבנ"י דורשין אותו בכל לבם הוא נמצא להם כמ"ש דרשוני וחיו וז"ש מקרא אני דורש כו':
translation: Why is this portion closed? Because their eyes were sealed, and so on. Another explanation is that he sought to reveal the end, and it was concealed from him. The principle is that the life force of all creations is the Torah. And also all times, even in exile. The inner life force comes from the Torah, but it is in a hidden manner. This portion represents the life force of the years of exile. And this is what is meant by "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," for Jacob, our father, continued the life force even in Egypt. And I heard from my revered teacher, may his memory be blessed, a hint that through the aspect of truth, one can live even in Egypt, as it is said, "You shall give truth to Jacob." The matter of the portion is the expansion of the life force of the Torah to all creations. The breaks are to provide space for contemplation, to establish each detail in its place. And so it was when the Children of Israel dwelled on their land, and all actions were according to the Torah itself. And now, in exile, the portion is closed, and there needs to be faith in general. And likewise, in the inner secret of the end, it is a point of life, the root of unity, which is called the secret of the One, for in exile it is in a sealed secret. In the future, it will be revealed, and "the Lord will be one, and His name one." And as one approaches this root point, they exit from exile. Therefore, the Shabbat is the unity in the secret of the One, and there is an elevation for all creations to their root, and especially for the Children of Israel, who gather in their souls with self-sacrifice for the sanctity of His name on Shabbat, as it is written elsewhere. Therefore, it is written, "And I will feed you with the heritage of Jacob," without Egypt, as it is written, "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," for he continued there the aspect of life, and consequently, without Egypt. And it is written, "Gather and I will tell you," and it is stated in the Zohar that although it was sealed from him, nonetheless, he revealed what he wished to reveal, only in a hidden manner. And when the Children of Israel gather and nullify themselves to the root of life, they can find the place of Jacob, as it is stated, "Jacob our father has not died," and I interpret, "I am interpreting a verse," and my revered teacher, may his memory be blessed, explained that when the Children of Israel seek him with all their heart, he is found for them, as it is said, "Seek Me and live," and this is what is meant by "I am interpreting a verse."
summary: The passage discusses the hidden nature of divine life force in the Torah, particularly during the exile, emphasizing that true vitality comes from the Torah even in difficult times. It highlights the importance of faith and unity, suggesting that through sincere devotion and connection to the essence of the Torah, the Jewish people can access this life force and transcend their exile. The text also alludes to the future revelation of God's oneness, where the hidden aspects of faith will be fully realized. Ultimately, it conveys that through collective yearning and dedication, the Jewish people can revive their connection to their spiritual roots.

passage_content: מאשר שמנה לחמו. פי' בזוה"ק על לחם משנה בשבת שיש לחם מן השמים ומן הארץ כו'. כי השבטים הם יסוד העולם כדאיתא בזוה"ק וזאת אשר דיבר להם אביהם. כי פי' זאת שמעתי ממו"ז ז"ל שהיא נקודה מלכות שמים שאין לשום דבר חיות רק מנקודה זו. לכן נק' זאת שאין דבר בעולם בלתי זאת. ונתן להם יעקב אע"ה שיהיו מקבלין נקודה זאת. ועי"ז נמשך חיות לכל הנבראים. ואשר הוא סוף השבטים כדכ' אשר כו' לחוף ימים כו' ישכון. וכ' ומשם יפרד כו'. לכן מחבר חיות התורה למשוך משם חיות לכל הנבראים. ובימות החול בנ"י מכינים בעבודה ביגיעות רבות שיזכו בשבת למנוחה כדאי' מי שטרח בע"ש כו' וזה לחם משנה שכפי היגיעה בחול מתרבה הברכה בשבת עבור ימי החול ג"כ. ונק' לחם משנה שבשבת נמשך שפע ברכה מצד עצם היום. ולבד זה מצד היגיעה בחול והוא ב' לחם הנ"ל. והוא כדמיון יששכר וזבולון שהקדים זבולון בתורה שנתן לפיו של יששכר. כן המיגע בחול לש"ש מתחבר עם בחי' שבת כנ"ל:
translation: "That he has given him bread. This is explained in the Zohar regarding the double portion of bread on Shabbat, that there is bread from heaven and from the earth, etc. For the tribes are the foundation of the world, as it is stated in the Zohar, and this is what their father spoke to them. For the explanation of 'this' I heard from my revered teacher, may his memory be blessed, that it is the point of the kingdom of heaven, from which no thing has life except from this point. Therefore, it is called 'this,' for there is nothing in the world without this. And Jacob, peace be upon him, gave them that they should receive this point. And through this, life is drawn to all creations. And that which is the end of the tribes, as it is written, 'and he shall dwell by the shore of the seas,' etc., 'and from there he shall part,' etc. Therefore, he connects the life of the Torah to draw from there life to all creations. And during the weekdays, the children of Israel prepare through much labor that they should merit on Shabbat to rest, as it is stated, 'whoever toils on Erev Shabbat,' etc. And this is the double portion of bread, that according to the toil during the week, the blessing on Shabbat increases for the weekdays as well. And it is called the double portion of bread on Shabbat, which draws forth an abundance of blessing from the essence of the day. And besides this, from the toil during the week, and this is the two breads mentioned above. And it is like the example of Issachar and Zebulun, that Zebulun preceded in the Torah that he gave to the mouth of Issachar. So too, one who toils during the week for Shabbat connects with the aspect of Shabbat, as mentioned."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "לחם משנה" (double bread) on Shabbat, emphasizing the divine sustenance that comes from both heaven and earth. It highlights the role of the tribes of Israel as foundational to the world, with Jacob imparting a vital spiritual essence that sustains all creation. The text underscores the importance of human effort during the week, suggesting that the blessings of Shabbat are proportional to one's labor, akin to the partnership between the tribes of Issachar and Zebulun. Ultimately, it illustrates the connection between earthly toil and heavenly reward, reinforcing the idea that spiritual vitality is drawn from both divine grace and human endeavor.

passage_content: במדרש פרשה זו סתומה שכשנפטר יעקב אבינו נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל ד"א שביקש לגלות הקץ ונסתם ממנו. פרשה זו היא ויחי יעקב בא"מ שזה הי' הכנה להגלות מה שחי יעקב במצרים. ולכן לא הי' יכול להתחיל הגלות עד שנסתם זה החיות של יעקב שהי' במצרים. כדכ' נחלת ימיהם זכורה לעולם רק שהי' נסתר זה כדי לחול הגלות ולכן פרשה זו סתומה שנסתם זה החיות אח"כ כנ"ל. וגם לפי הפשוט גוף הגלות לא התחיל עד שתמו כל הדור ההוא. רק שנסתם עין השכל מקודם. כי קודם גלות הגוף הוא גלות הנפש כי הגוף תלוי בתהלוכת הנפש. וגלות הנפשות הי' מיד שנסתם חיותו של יעקב אע"ה. ובזה פרשנו הפסוק ויראו אחי יוסף כו' מת אביהם כו' לו ישטמנו והשב כו' הרעה אשר גמלנו כו' ויבך יוסף כו' אתם חשבתם כו' להחיות עם רב כו' והוא שהשבטים הרגישו מיד בהגלות. וז"ש שראו כי מת אביהם כי לא מצאו חיותו של יעקב כנ"ל. ויוסף ירש מקום אביו. והם סברו שע"י מכירתם את יוסף גרמו גלות מצרים. וז"ש הרעה אשר גמלנו. ויוסף שהי' במדריגת יעקב והי' דבוק בגאולה ידע והבין כי הכל לטובה כי שורש הגלות הוא הגאולה. וז"ש ביקש לגלות הקץ ונסתם ממנו. אם הפי' על זמן ביאת משיח לא ידענו מה סוד עמוק הוא זה. וגם מה נ"מ בידיעה זו. רק עיקר הפי' שרצה לברר להם שורש הגלות והגאולה. כי באמת אין רע יורד משמים וימי הרעה נעשים רק ע"י חסרון המקבלים שנהפך להם לרע. והוא רק הסתר. ולכן יש לו סוף וקץ כי השקר אין לו רגלים וקיום. ואם הי' יודעין זה האמת לא הי' שולט בהם הגלות רק כי לא הי' ניתקן הכל כראוי והי' מוכרח להיות גלות מצרים. ולכן לא הי' יכול לגלות זה הקץ. ומ"מ איתא כי גילה מה שרצה לגלות רק בדרך הסתר ופרשנו בעזה"י כי יש אספקלריא המאירה והיא בחי' יעקב שאין לפניו הסתר ורואה הכל בעין הראות ויש אספקלריא שאינה מאירה. והיא בחי' אמונה שע"י ההסתר עצמו צריכין לבוא אל האמת ע"י האמונה ונק' אספקלריא שא"מ כי האור בא מההסתר דייקא כנ"ל והבן. וכיון שלא הי' יכול יעקב לגלות זה הקץ שהוא לברר להם האמת בבחי' אספקלריא המאירה צריך להיות התיקון בבחי' אמונה. וזה צריכין לידע גם עתה כי בכל גלות כן. שהקב"ה מכין קודם הגלות הארות קדושות שיכולין להתדבק בהם אף בחשך רק שאינו נגלה וכשמאמינים כראוי יכולין למצוא האמת ואז בא גאולה כי תכלית הגלות הגאולה כנ"ל. וכן שמעתי מפי מו"ז ז"ל ע"פ ויחי יעקב בא"מ שע"י בחי' אמת מדתו של יעקב כדכ' תתן אמת ליעקב עי"ז יכולין לחיות גם בכל המצרים שיש לכל איש ישראל כנ"ל. נחזור להנ"ל שהשבטים הרגישו הגלות והבינו כי יוסף הוא שורש הגאולה. וחששו שע"י ששנאו אותו בחשבם כי יוסף רוצה לדחותם מאביהם. עי"ז לא יוכלו להתדבק בו עתה. וחשבו שגרמו הגלות. ויוסף השיב להם כי הכל לטובה רק הם חשבו לרעה. ואפשר עי"ז שחשבו לרעה נענשו בזה שהרגישו הגלות וחשבו שח"ו נסתר דרכם מה'. אבל אלקים חשבה לטובה להחיות עם רב שהוא תיקון הראוי שבא ע"י הגלות. כי יוסף הי' דבוק בהגאולה ולא הרגיש הגלות. ולכן ויבך יוסף בדברם אליו כי ראה שהם התחילו מיד להרגיש הגלות:
translation:
In the Midrash, this section is sealed, for when our father Jacob passed away, the eyes and hearts of Israel were sealed. Another interpretation is that he sought to reveal the end, but it was sealed from him. This section is "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," which was a preparation for the exile that Jacob lived in Egypt. Therefore, the exile could not begin until the vitality of Jacob, which was in Egypt, was sealed. As it is written, "The inheritance of their days is remembered forever," only that this was hidden in order for the exile to occur. Hence, this section is sealed, as this vitality was sealed afterwards, as mentioned. 

Also, according to the simple meaning, the body of the exile did not begin until that entire generation had passed. However, the eye of understanding was sealed beforehand. For before the exile of the body, there is the exile of the soul, as the body is dependent on the movements of the soul. The exile of the souls occurred immediately when the vitality of Jacob, our father, was sealed. 

With this, we explain the verse "And Joseph's brothers saw that their father was dead..." They said, "Perhaps Joseph will hate us and repay us for all the evil which we did to him..." and Joseph wept... "You thought evil against me..." to sustain a great nation... and it was that the brothers immediately felt the exile. This is why it is said that they saw that their father was dead, for they did not find the vitality of Jacob, as mentioned. And Joseph inherited the place of his father. They thought that by selling Joseph, they caused the exile to Egypt. This is why it is said, "the evil which we repaid." 

And Joseph, who was in the level of Jacob and was attached to redemption, knew and understood that everything is for the good, for the root of the exile is the redemption. This is why it is said, "He sought to reveal the end, but it was sealed from him." If the interpretation is about the time of the coming of the Messiah, we do not know what deep secret this is. Also, what is the practical difference in this knowledge? The main interpretation is that he wanted to clarify to them the root of the exile and redemption. For in truth, no evil descends from Heaven, and the days of evil occur only due to the deficiency of the receivers, which turns to evil for them. It is only a concealment. Therefore, it has an end and a limit, for falsehood has no legs and no existence. 

If they had known this truth, the exile would not have ruled over them, only because everything was not rectified properly, and it was necessary for the exile of Egypt to occur. Therefore, he could not reveal this end. Nevertheless, it is stated that he revealed what he wanted to reveal, only in a concealed manner. We explained, with God's help, that there is a shining mirror, which is the aspect of Jacob, who has no concealment before him and sees everything with the eye of vision, and there is a mirror that does not shine. This is the aspect of faith, through which, by the concealment itself, one must come to the truth through faith, and it is called a mirror that does not shine, for the light comes specifically from the concealment, as mentioned, and understand. 

And since Jacob could not reveal this end, which is to clarify to them the truth in the aspect of a shining mirror, the rectification must be in the aspect of faith. This is something that must be known even now, for in every exile it is so. That the Holy One, blessed be He, prepares before the exile holy illuminations that one can cling to even in darkness, only that it is not revealed. And when one believes properly, one can find the truth, and then redemption comes, for the purpose of the exile is redemption, as mentioned. 

And so I heard from my revered teacher, may his memory be blessed, based on "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," that through the aspect of truth, the attribute of Jacob, as it is written, "You shall give truth to Jacob," through this one can live even in all the troubles that every Jew has, as mentioned. 

Let us return to the above, that the brothers felt the exile and understood that Joseph is the root of redemption. They feared that by hating him, thinking that Joseph wanted to distance them from their father, they would not be able to cling to him now. They thought they caused the exile. And Joseph replied to them that everything is for the good, only they thought it was for evil. And perhaps because they thought it was for evil, they were punished by feeling the exile and thought that, Heaven forbid, their path was concealed from God. But God meant it for good, to sustain a great nation, which is the proper rectification that comes through the exile. For Joseph was attached to redemption and did not feel the exile. Therefore, Joseph wept when they spoke to him, for he saw that they immediately began to feel the exile.
summary: The passage discusses the hidden nature of the exile that began with the death of Jacob, whose vitality was essential for the Israelites. It emphasizes that the true understanding of exile and redemption lies in recognizing that all suffering stems from a lack of connection to divine truth, which is often obscured. Jacob's inability to reveal the end of days symbolizes the necessity of faith in the face of concealment, as the ultimate purpose of exile is to lead to redemption. The brothers' fear of having caused the exile through their actions towards Joseph reflects a deeper understanding that even perceived evil can serve a greater good, as Joseph embodies the root of redemption.

passage_content: במדרש שמע ישראל סבא כו'. כי זה האחדות נתן להם יעקב אע"ה כמ"ש וזאת אשר דיבר להם פי' בזוה"ק שנתן להם בחי' זאת והיא מלכות שמים להיות כל הנהגתם בבחי' זאת ומזה בא כל הברכות ועי"ז ויברך אותם:
translation: In the Midrash, "Hear, O Israel, the elder said, etc." For this unity, Jacob, our father, gave them, as it is written, "And this is what he spoke to them," which is explained in the Zohar that he gave them this aspect, which is the Kingdom of Heaven, so that all their conduct should be in this aspect, and from this comes all the blessings, and through this, "And he blessed them."
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, it is emphasized that Jacob imparted the concept of unity to his descendants, as reflected in the Zohar's interpretation of his blessings. This unity is associated with the divine sovereignty, or the "Kingdom of Heaven," guiding their actions and governance. Through this connection to divine unity, all blessings are derived, highlighting the importance of aligning one's life with this spiritual principle. Ultimately, the blessings bestowed upon them are a manifestation of their adherence to this profound unity.

passage_content: במדרש למה פרשה זו סתומה כו'. פי' כי הכתוב משבח מעשה יעקב אע"ה אשר חי במצרים י"ז שנים כי הי' דבוק בחיים ולא הי' כל טומאת מצרים עומד לנגד קדושתו. והי' י"ז שנים אלו הכנה לכל הגלות. אך כי פרשה זו סתומה לנו פי' שאין אנו משיגין איך המשיך חיות הקדושה במצרים כי אם היו משיגין זאת לא הי' הגלות כלל. ובוודאי יש בכח איש ישראל לעורר החיות בכ"מ וע"ז נאמר השם נפשנו בחיים. דכ' ויפח באפיו נ"ח ויהי האדם לנ"ח. פי' נפש. הרצון. שהאדם יכול לעורר החיות ברצונו. ובנ"י דבוקים בחיים. ומ"ש חז"ל ביקש לגלות הקץ ונסתם משל שרצה לגלות מסטורין של המלך ראה המלך עומד והשיח לדברים אחרים. והוא תימה כי ח"ו שירצה יעקב אע"ה להעלים מעשיו מהשי"ת. אך הפי' כי ביקש להראותם עומק הרע ושיתגלה להם מלכותו ית' בכל המקומות עד דרגא תתאה כמ"ש באחרית הימים וזה הוא בעת הסתרת פנים. והקב"ה לא רצה בזה. כדי שיהי' הגלות. שכך רצונו ב"ה. לכן נגלה עליו השכינה. וע"י שהי' התגלות לא הי' יכול לגלות הקץ. שזה רק בעת ההסתר. וכן הי' דרכו של יעקב אע"ה תמיד להכניס עצמו במקומות אשר המה מסוכנים כי הי' מפתח לבנים. ורמז לדבר המלאך הגואל אותי מכל רע מכלל שירד לכל מקומות הרעים וניצל מהם. ודרך הזה רצה ללמד לבניו ונסתם ממנו כנ"ל:
translation: In the Midrash, why is this section closed, etc.? The explanation is that the text praises the actions of Jacob, our forefather, who lived in Egypt for seventeen years because he was attached to life, and no impurity of Egypt stood against his holiness. These seventeen years were a preparation for all the exile. However, this section is closed to us, meaning we do not comprehend how he continued the vitality of holiness in Egypt, for if they had understood this, there would have been no exile at all. And certainly, it is within the power of a Jewish person to awaken the vitality anywhere, and concerning this it is said, "The Lord has kept our soul alive." As it is written, "And He breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and man became a living soul." The explanation is that the soul, the will, allows a person to awaken vitality through his will. And the Children of Israel are attached to life. And what our Sages said, he sought to reveal the end and it was closed off, is like a parable of one who wanted to reveal the secrets of the king, but saw the king standing and turned to other matters. And it is a wonder, for Heaven forbid that Jacob, our forefather, would want to conceal his actions from the Holy One, Blessed be He. But the explanation is that he sought to show them the depth of evil and that His sovereignty should be revealed in all places, even to the lowest level, as it is said in the end of days, and this is at a time of hiddenness of the face. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not want this, so that the exile would occur, for thus is His will, Blessed be He. Therefore, the Shechinah revealed itself to him. And through the revelation, he could not reveal the end, for this is only at the time of hiddenness. And so was the way of Jacob, our forefather, always to place himself in places that are dangerous, for he was a key to the children. And this is hinted at in the phrase, "The angel who redeems me from all evil," who descended to all the evil places and was saved from them. And in this way, he wanted to teach his sons, and it was closed off from him, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's 17 years in Egypt, highlighting his ability to maintain holiness despite the surrounding impurity, which serves as a preparation for the impending exile. It emphasizes that the concealment of divine life in Egypt is beyond human comprehension, and that the Jewish people possess the potential to evoke divine vitality through their will. Jacob's desire to reveal the end of days reflects a yearning for the manifestation of God's sovereignty even in darkness, but this revelation was withheld to allow for the experience of exile, which is part of God's divine plan. Ultimately, Jacob's journey illustrates the importance of engaging with challenging environments while remaining connected to the source of life.

passage_content: בפסוק אוסרי לגפן עירה ולשורקה בני אתונו כבס ביין לבושו. דאחז"ל כנ"י נק' גפן שאינה מקבלת הרכבה ממין אחר כו'. פי' נקודה טמונה שיש בכל איש ישראל אשר אינו מתחלף כלל והיא נקראת גפן. וזה נתן הקב"ה להיות בטבע נפש הישראלי. וכן מדות טובות שבישראל נק' שורקה כמ"ש ואנכי נטעתיך שורק. אך עבודת האדם לקשר כל התעוררות שבו לזאת הנקודה. וז"ש אוסרי לגפן עירה. פי' התעוררות כל נפש האדם. לשעבד הגוף להנשמה. וכן המדות צריך האדם לקיים אותם ע"פ התורה כמ"ש במ"א שלא יהי' תיקון המדות כדי ליישר עצמו באשר הוא מבין שהם עדות לחכמת האדם. רק כדי להיות כלי מוכן לעבודתו ית'. כי התורה שוכנת בגוף מתוקן. ואם הכוונה כן מתקיים לעד. כי התורה נק' עוז. שכל דבר שנעשה בצירוף התורה ולשמה. מתקיימת. וז"ש לשורקה בני אתונו מלשון איתן שהתורה נק' עוז כנ"ל. כבס ביין לבושו. הוא תיקון מעשים הגשמיים אשר הם כמו מלבוש וקישוטין להגוף כשהם נעשין בטהרה:
translation: In the verse "Bind the vine of the city and the red-haired one, the son of your donkey, is dressed in wine." This teaches us that the Jewish people are called a vine that does not accept grafting from another species, etc. The explanation is that there is a hidden point within every Jewish person that does not change at all, and it is called a vine. This was given by the Holy One, blessed be He, to be in the nature of the soul of the Jewish people. Likewise, the good traits in Israel are called "red-haired," as it is said, "And I have planted you a red-haired one." However, a person's work is to connect every awakening within him to this point. And thus it is said, "Bind the vine of the city." This means the awakening of every person's soul, to subjugate the body to the soul. Likewise, a person must uphold the traits according to the Torah, as it is said elsewhere, that the rectification of traits should not be to straighten oneself based on what he understands to be a testimony to human wisdom, but rather to be a vessel prepared for His service. For the Torah dwells in a perfected body. And if the intention is so, it will be established forever, for the Torah is called strength. Everything that is done in conjunction with the Torah and for its sake is sustained. And thus it is said, "To the red-haired one, the son of your donkey," from the language of "eternal," that the Torah is called strength, as mentioned. "Dressed in wine" refers to the rectification of physical actions, which are like garments and adornments for the body when they are done in purity.
summary: The passage emphasizes the intrinsic, unchanging spiritual essence within every Jew, symbolized by the "gfen" (vine), which represents a divine connection that cannot be altered. The "shorak" (good traits) reflects the cultivation of these qualities in accordance with Torah, highlighting the importance of aligning one's actions and character with divine will. The text underscores that true fulfillment of one's potential and the permanence of Torah's teachings arise from a sincere commitment to spiritual growth and purity in one's deeds. Ultimately, the Torah is portrayed as a source of strength and permanence, guiding the individual towards a life of holiness and purpose.

passage_content: במדרש גר אנכי עמך כו' כצל ימינו עלי ארץ. כי עיקר הימים הם האורות המיוחדים לכל נפש מבנ"י. אמנם למטה מתלבשים נקודות הארות מהימים עליונים לזמן הגשמיי. וע"ז נאמר מחדש בכל יום מ"ב. והם רק כמו צל ודמות. דומה להימים העליונים. אבל אינם העיקר רק בבחי' גרים. פי' כמו גר שהמעלה שלו מצד שנתקרב ממקום רחוק וע"ז המעלה הי' כל בריאת עוה"ז שבעבודת האדם מתקרב זמן הטבע לימים העליונים. אמנם יעקב אע"ה תיקן גוף הימים בעוה"ז ג"כ להיות מקורבים הם עצמם להש"י כמ"ש בזוה"ק ביאור הפ' ויקרבו ימי ישראל למות שיקרבו הימים לה'. ולכן נסתלק אח"כ כי בהשלמת העבודה המיוחדת לאדם נסתלק מעולם ועבודת יעקב הי' לקרב עצם הימים לה' כנ"ל. ונאמר עליו ויחי יעקב בא"מ. שהביא החיות גם בא"מ כי גם חושך לא יחשיך ממנו. ובמדרש למה פ' זו סתומה שנסתם עיניהם כו' ד"א שסתם ממנו כל צרות שבעולם. לכאורה ב' הפירושים סותרין. זה נדרש לשבח כו'. אמנם הכל אחד דאיתא ביקש לגלות הקץ ונסתם ממנו. ע"ש המשל שגילה לבנו מקום גט שיחרורו. וראה המלך עומד והשיח לדברים אחרים. וביאור הענין כי יעקב אע"ה הי' למעלה מהטבע ושלט על הטבע. לכן הי' בכוחו להסתיר החיות במצרים. וזהו פי' המד' ושמעו אל ישראל אביכם אל ישראל מה הקב"ה בורא עולמות אף אביכם בורא עולמות. פי' הקב"ה הוא עד שלא נברא העולם והוא משנברא העולם. אולם בבריאת העולם נתגלה זה הפלא אשר הסתיר כבוד מלכותו ית' תוך הטבע באופן שלא יהי' ניכר. עד שנמצא בעולם העושים היפוך רצונו. וזאת היא יותר פלא מהכל. וכן פי' מו"ז ז"ל שם עולם ע"ש ההעלם שעשה הבורא להיות נעלם השגחתו ית' בעוה"ז. וכמו כן הצדיק בורא עולמות כאלו אשר בעבודתו מכניס הארת הקדושה במעשים גשמיים בהצנע והסתר. דומין לבוראם. וזה שאמר להם יעקב הקבצו ושמעו פי' שגנוז הכח גם במצרים רק שצריך יגיעה להוציא מכח אל הפועל. וזה הגלות. והנה יעקב הכניס עצמו למצרים אף כי הי' באמת בן חורין וכן הי' תמיד דרכו בקודש להכניס עצמו במקומות הללו כמ"ש במ"א. ובאופן זה רצה לגלות להם הקץ פי' אף שיהיו באמת בחירות. יכניסו עצמם ברצון להגלות לעשות רצון הבורא. ולא גילה להם מקום השיחרור כדי לפרוק עול הגלות ח"ו. רק כנ"ל שיקבלו עליהם ברצון שיהי' סוד הקץ בהסתר אצלם. אבל לא הי' בכחם למשוך לגמרי אחר מדריגת יעקב. וזה ענין שנסתם ממנו פי' שבהתגלות עיקר כוחו של יעקב עלה בעלמא דאתכסיא מה שלא היו השבטים מגיעים עד שם. וזה עצמו מ"ש במדרש שסתם ממנו כל צרות כו' לכן לא הי' במדרגה של השבטים ולא היו יכולים למשוך אחריו לגמרי. לכן הי' העצה ע"י יוסף וז"ש ויקרא לבנו ליוסף. קריאה לשון חיבה ודביקות שמסר כחו ליוסף וע"י אמצעיות יוסף נמשכו כולם אחר כח יעקב. וז"ש האספו ואגידה פי' ע"י שיהיו אגודה אחת לבטל עצמם אל הכלל. וזה סוד יוסף. וז"ש נתתי לך שכם אחד על אחיך פי' שנתן לו בחי' האחדות והתכללות להיות כולם כלולין בו ועי"ז יבוא הגאולה. וזה סוד השבת דבי' מתאחדין ברזא דאחד. [שכם אחד ר"ת ש"כ מלכותו והוא רזא דאחד והמ"י] לכן אלו משמרין ב' שבתות נגאלין. וב' הם יוסף ובנימין שעל שניהם נאמר צדיקים יירשו ארץ כמ"ש בזוה"ק. וכ"נ הפשוט ג"כ שליוסף מסר סוד הקץ לכן אמר להם יוסף הסימן פקוד יפקוד כו':
translation: In the Midrash, "I am a stranger among you," etc., "like the shadow of our days upon the earth." For the essence of the days are the special lights for each soul from the children of Israel. However, below, points of illumination from the upper days are clothed for the physical time. And for this, it is said anew every day, "forty-two." And they are only like a shadow and a form, resembling the upper days. But they are not the essence, only in the aspect of strangers. This means like a convert whose merit comes from having drawn close from a distant place, and for this merit, the entire creation of this world in the service of man draws the time of nature closer to the upper days. However, Jacob, our father, established the body of the days in this world as well, to be themselves close to the Blessed One, as it is written in the Zohar, explaining the verse, "And the days of Israel drew near to die," that the days draw close to God. Therefore, he was later removed because in the completion of the special work for man, he was removed from the world, and Jacob's work was to draw the essence of the days to God, as mentioned above. And it is said about him, "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," that he brought life even in Egypt, for even darkness will not darken him. And in the Midrash, "Why is this section closed?" that their eyes were closed, etc., another explanation is that he closed off from him all the troubles of the world. At first glance, the two explanations contradict each other. This is interpreted for praise, etc. However, they are all one, as it is written, "He sought to reveal the end and it was closed off from him." See there the parable that he revealed to his son the place of his release. And he saw the king standing and the conversation turned to other matters. The explanation of the matter is that Jacob, our father, was above nature and ruled over nature. Therefore, he had the power to conceal the life force in Egypt. And this is the meaning of the Midrash, "And he heard Israel, your father, to Israel, as the Holy One, blessed be He, creates worlds, so too your father creates worlds." This means that the Holy One, blessed be He, is before the world was created and He is since the world was created. However, in the creation of the world, this wonder was revealed, which concealed His royal glory within nature in such a way that it would not be noticeable. Until it is found in the world that they do the opposite of His will. And this is more wondrous than all. And so explained our teacher, may his memory be blessed, that the world is named for the concealment that the Creator made to be hidden His providence in this world. And likewise, the righteous create worlds such that through their service, they bring the light of holiness into physical actions in secrecy and concealment. They resemble their Creator. And this is what Jacob said to them, "Gather and listen," meaning that the power is also hidden in Egypt, only that effort is needed to bring it from potential to actual. And this is the exile. And behold, Jacob entered himself into Egypt even though he was truly a free man, and so was his way always in holiness to enter himself into such places, as mentioned elsewhere. And in this way, he wanted to reveal to them the end, meaning that even though they would truly be free, they should willingly enter into exile to do the will of the Creator. And he did not reveal to them the place of their release in order to remove the yoke of exile, Heaven forbid, but rather as mentioned above, that they should willingly accept upon themselves that the secret of the end be hidden with them. But they were not able to draw entirely after the level of Jacob. And this is the matter that was closed off from him, meaning that in the revelation of the essence of Jacob's power, he ascended to the hidden world, where the tribes could not reach. And this itself is what is said in the Midrash, "He closed off from him all troubles," etc. Therefore, he was not on the level of the tribes, and they could not draw entirely after him. Therefore, the advice was through Joseph, and it is said, "And he called his son Joseph." Calling is a term of affection and attachment, that he gave his power to Joseph, and through Joseph's mediation, they all drew after Jacob's power. And this is what he said, "Gather and I will tell you," meaning that by being one group, they should nullify themselves to the collective. This is the secret of Joseph. And this is what he said, "I have given you one portion above your brothers," meaning that he gave him the aspect of unity and inclusion, to be all included in him, and through this, redemption will come. And this is the secret of the Sabbath, that in it they unite in the secret of the One. [One portion is an acronym for "Sh'k" (ש"כ) of His kingdom, and it is the secret of the One and the "M" (מ"י)]. Therefore, those who observe two Sabbaths will be redeemed. And the two are Joseph and Benjamin, of whom it is said, "The righteous will inherit the land," as it is written in the Zohar. And similarly, the simple meaning is also that he gave Joseph the secret of the end, therefore Joseph said to them, "The sign is, 'I will surely visit you.'"
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the divine light of the "days" and the earthly existence of the Jewish people, emphasizing that the spiritual essence of these days is reflected in the material world as mere shadows. It highlights Jacob's unique role in bridging the spiritual and physical realms, allowing for a connection to God even in exile. Jacob's ability to conceal and reveal divine truths illustrates the hidden nature of God's presence in the world, while the unity of the tribes, particularly through Joseph, is essential for achieving redemption. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of striving for spiritual elevation and collective unity to access the hidden potential for redemption.

passage_content: ויברך את יוסף כו' המלאך כו' יברך כו' הנערים. ומקשין מה הברכה ליוסף. אבל הפי' הוא שנתן ברכה להתפשטות כוחו של יוסף. והנערים הוא התעוררות החיות שבעולם. והכלל כי שורש החיות בא מיוסף אבל כשבא השפע בעולמות שלמטה צריך שמירה. כי לכן בגלות ע"י שליטת הסט"א א"א להתגלות הקדושה. כאשר חכמים הגידו בשנת רעבון אסור הזיווג. אך העצה בגלות ע"י התורה כמ"ש וידגו לרוב פרש"י כמו הדגים שהים מכסה עליהם שאין שולט בהם עה"ר כו'. כמו כן ע"י התורה שנמשלה למים יכול אדם להתכסות מסט"א. ואיתא במדרש כמו דגים שמצפים לטיפה מים כו' כן בנ"י מצפים לתורה. וכפי רוב השתוקקות. התורה מגין עליהם. ואיתא ברש"י בראשית שניתן ברכה לדגים ע"י שצדין מהם כו'. ולכן יוסף שהיא שורש הכל צריך ברכה. וזה ענין ויברך אלקים כו' יום השביעי ע"י שהוא שורש כל הימים כמ"ש מיני' מתברכין. לכן צריך שמירה יותר כמ"ש ופרוס סוכת שלומך כו'. וזהו ויברך את יוסף כו' וידגו לרוב כו' התפשטות כח יוסף כנ"ל:
translation: And he blessed Joseph, etc., the angel, etc., will bless, etc., the youths. And they ask what the blessing is for Joseph. But the explanation is that he gave a blessing for the expansion of Joseph's power. And the youths refer to the awakening of the vitality in the world. The general principle is that the root of vitality comes from Joseph, but when the flow comes into the worlds below, it requires protection. Therefore, in exile, due to the dominance of the Other Side, holiness cannot be revealed. As the sages have said, during a year of famine, coupling is forbidden. But the remedy in exile is through the Torah, as it is written, "and they will multiply like fish," Rashi explains, like the fish that the sea covers over them, and the Other Side does not have dominion over them, etc. Likewise, through the Torah, which is compared to water, a person can be covered from the Other Side. And it is stated in the Midrash that just as fish await a drop of water, so too the Children of Israel await the Torah. And according to the intensity of their yearning, the Torah protects them. And it is stated in Rashi on Genesis that a blessing was given to the fish because they are caught from them, etc. Therefore, Joseph, who is the root of all, needs a blessing. This is the matter of "And God blessed," etc., the seventh day, as he is the root of all the days, as it is said, "from it, blessings come." Therefore, it requires more protection, as it is said, "and spread the shelter of Your peace," etc. And this is "And he blessed Joseph," etc., "and they will multiply," etc., the expansion of Joseph's power, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the blessing given to Joseph, emphasizing that it represents the expansion of his spiritual power, which is the source of vitality in the world. It highlights the necessity of protection for this divine energy, especially during exile when the forces of impurity dominate. The Torah is likened to water, providing a safeguard against these negative influences, and the longing for the Torah reflects the Jewish people's hope for spiritual sustenance. Ultimately, Joseph's role as the root of all blessings necessitates heightened vigilance and divine protection.

passage_content: בפסוק לו ישטמנו יוסף כו'. וקשה כי ראו שהוא הצדיק ואיך חשדו אותו שישנא אותם. אך השבטים עשו תשובה גדולה על חטא המכירה. ומרוב צערם חשבו כי הם גרמו כל גלות מצרים. האמנם הי' סיבה באמת משמים לקיים עצה עמוקה כו'. אבל הם חשבו שהכל בא רק על ידם. וע"ז השיב להם יוסף כי אלקים חשבה לטובה. וי"ל פי' אתם חשבתם עלי רעה פי' שע"י שעשו תשובה גדולה עי"ז נהפך מזדונות לזכיות ולכך אלקים חשבה לטובה:
translation: In the verse, "He will hate us," it is difficult to understand because they saw that he was the righteous one, and how could they suspect that he would hate them? However, the brothers did a great repentance for the sin of selling him. Out of their great sorrow, they thought that they caused the entire exile in Egypt. Indeed, there was a reason from Heaven to fulfill a deep counsel. But they thought that everything came only through them. To this, Joseph replied that "God intended it for good." It can be explained that you thought of me for evil, meaning that through their great repentance, their intentional sins were transformed into merits, and therefore God intended it for good.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on the brothers' deep remorse for selling Joseph, believing they were responsible for the suffering that led to the Egyptian exile. Despite their guilt, Joseph reassures them that God intended their actions for good, highlighting the transformative power of repentance. The key insight is that their sincere teshuva (repentance) turned their sins into merits, illustrating the Hasidic belief in divine providence and the ability to find purpose in suffering. Ultimately, it emphasizes that even perceived wrongdoing can lead to a greater good orchestrated by God.

passage_content: במד' פרשה זו סתומה שנסתמו עיניהם ולבן כו' ד"א שנסתם ממנו כל צרות שבעולם כו'. כי נחלת יעקב הוא בלי מצרים. לכן כל זמן שלא נסתם בחי' יעקב לא הי' אפשרות להיות הגלות. ופי' הד"א הוא ג"כ כן שלפי שסתם ממנו כל הצרות לכן הי' הגלות. כי כל ימיו של אבינו יעקב שהי' בצער הי' הכל בעבור בנ"י. ואם הי' סובל צער בי"ז שנים הללו בא"מ לא היו צריכין לגלות כלל. אבל הש"י חס על הצדיק ולא הי' יכול עוד לענותו. וסתם ממנו כל הצרות. ועי"ז הי' הגלות אח"כ. והפסוק ויחי יעקב בא"מ הוא עדות גם לדורות כי נמצא חיותו של יעקב בכל עת צר. אך כי הוא נסתר ונעלם. לכן בש"ק שזוכין לנחלת יעקב בלי מצרים מתעורר קצת גאולה. וכתיב האספו ואגידה. הקבצו ושמעו כו' שע"י התאחדות והתכללות כ"א מתעורר כוחו של יעקב. וזה ג"כ הטעם בשבת דמתאחדין ברזא דאחד לכן מתעורר כוחו כנ"ל. וחכמים הגידו כי ביקש לגלות הקץ ונסתם ממנו כו'. בודאי הי' חסרון שלא היו יכולין להתאחד כמו שהי' רצון יעקב. וכפי מציאות האחדות כן מתעורר ומתגלה הקץ כנ"ל. וב' הלשונות הקבצו האספו הם ב' מיני התאחדות. בחי' יוסף ויהודה. משיח בן יוסף ומשיח בן דוד. אשר ע"ז אמרו חכמים אלו שמרו בנ"י ב' שבתות הם נגאלין. כי יש שבת במתנה בחי' יוסף שהוא נבדל מעוה"ז נזיר אחיו והוא התאחדות השורש ממש ע"י ביטול אל השורש. ויש בחי' שבת הבא ע"י יגיעת העבודה בחול ונק' שבת של חול והוא מציאת המנוחה ע"י היגיעה כמ"ש יגעתי ומצאתי תאמין. שהגם שמנוחה היא למעלה מהטבע עכ"ז צריכין להאמין שע"י יגיעה בטבע זוכין להמנוחה כנ"ל. והוא בחי' משיח בן דוד ויהודה שזה יהי' גמר הגאולה שדבר הבא ע"י עבודת האדם מתקיים לעד. וזה האספו ואגידה בחי' יוסף. הקבצו ושמעו מצד השומע בחי' יהודה כנ"ל. ומעין זה כ' במד' צוה לכבד שבט יהודה ובנימין [שג"כ זרע רחל] ע"ש:
translation: In this section of the Midrash, it is sealed because their eyes were sealed, and so on. Another interpretation is that all the troubles of the world were sealed from him. For the inheritance of Jacob is without Egypt. Therefore, as long as the aspect of Jacob was not sealed, it was not possible for the exile to occur. And the interpretation of the other explanation is also so, that since all the troubles were sealed from him, therefore the exile occurred. For all the days of our father Jacob, when he was in pain, it was all for the sake of his children. And if he had suffered pain during those seventeen years in Egypt, they would not have needed to go into exile at all. But the Holy One, blessed be He, had compassion on the righteous and could no longer afflict him. And He sealed from him all the troubles. And as a result, the exile came afterward. And the verse "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt" is a testimony also for future generations, for the life of Jacob is found in every time of trouble. But it is hidden and concealed. Therefore, on Shabbat, when we merit the inheritance of Jacob without Egypt, a bit of redemption is awakened. And it is written, "Gather and I will tell." "Assemble and hear," that through the unity and integration of each one, the power of Jacob is awakened. And this is also the reason on Shabbat, where we unite in the secret of the One, therefore his power is awakened as mentioned. And the sages have said that he sought to reveal the end and it was sealed from him. Certainly, there was a deficiency that they could not unite as Jacob desired. And according to the reality of the unity, so the end is awakened and revealed as mentioned. And the two expressions "gather" and "assemble" are two types of unity: the aspect of Joseph and Judah, the Messiah son of Joseph and the Messiah son of David. Concerning this, the sages said that if the children of Israel observe two Shabbats, they will be redeemed. For there is a Shabbat given as a gift, the aspect of Joseph, who is separated from this world, a Nazir to his brothers, and this is the unity of the root itself through nullification to the root. And there is the aspect of Shabbat that comes through the labor of work during the week, and it is called the Shabbat of the week, and it is the finding of rest through effort, as it is said, "I toiled and found, you should believe." For although rest is above nature, nevertheless, one must believe that through effort in nature, one merits rest as mentioned. And this is the aspect of the Messiah son of David and Judah, which will be the completion of the redemption, for that which comes through the work of man endures forever. And this is "gather and I will tell" in the aspect of Joseph. "Assemble and hear" from the aspect of the hearer, in the aspect of Judah as mentioned. And similarly, it is written in the Midrash, "Command to honor the tribe of Judah and Benjamin" [who are also the seed of Rachel], as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of suffering and redemption in relation to Jacob and his descendants, emphasizing that Jacob's own suffering was for the sake of the Jewish people. It suggests that the cessation of Jacob's suffering led to the eventual exile, and that the unity of the Jewish people, particularly through the observance of Shabbat, can awaken the redemptive power of Jacob. The text highlights the dual aspects of unity represented by Joseph and Judah, indicating that true redemption comes from both spiritual elevation and the labor of the people. Ultimately, it conveys that the fulfillment of redemption is linked to the collective effort and unity of the Jewish people.

passage_content: בן פורת יוסף כו' עלי עין כו' עלי שור. דאי' בגמ' בשילה חלק יוסף הי' קדשים נאכלין בכל הרואה ע"י שקידש יוסף הצדיק ראות עיניו לכן זכה לזה כאשר הגיד אדוני מו"ז ז"ל. נמצא ע"י שמירת עינו של יוסף הצדיק קידש כל משך ראות העין אף חוץ לחומה. והענין ע"פ מאמר חז"ל אפי' מחיצה של ברזל אין מפסקת ב"י לאביהם שבשמים. אמנם כפי החיבה שנמצא בבנ"י כמו בן לאב. כך מתבטלין כל המחיצות. וי"ל בנות לשון בנין חומה שהבנין נתפשט להלן עד שור שהוא הסתכלות שהי' נמשך הקדושה בכל הרואה כנ"ל. וכמו דאיתא הים ראה וינס ראה ארונו של יוסף כו' וינס ויצא כו' והוא ביטול הטבע. וכמו כן בנות צעדה שהחומות נסו ונתבטלו עלי שור כלומר בעבור הסתכלות של יוסף הצדיק כנ"ל:
translation: Son of a fruitful vine, a fruitful vine by a spring, a daughter of a wall. It is stated in the Gemara that in Shiloh, the portion of Joseph was holy, eaten by all who see, because Joseph the righteous sanctified the sight of his eyes; therefore, he merited this, as my master, may his memory be blessed, has said. It is found that through the guarding of the eye of Joseph the righteous, he sanctified all the duration of sight, even outside the wall. The matter is according to the saying of our Sages, that even a partition of iron does not separate the Jewish people from their Father in Heaven. However, according to the affection found in the Children of Israel, like a son to a father, all partitions are nullified. It can be said that the term "building a wall" refers to the building that extends further to the ox, which is the contemplation that drew holiness to all who see, as mentioned. And as it is stated, "The sea saw and fled," it saw the coffin of Joseph and fled and went out, which is the nullification of nature. Likewise, the daughters of Tzaddikah, the walls fled and were nullified by the sight of Joseph the righteous, as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the sanctity and spiritual influence of Joseph's righteous gaze, which extends beyond physical boundaries, symbolizing the connection between the Jewish people and their divine Father. It emphasizes that through Joseph's vigilance, even barriers like iron walls cannot separate the Jewish people from God, reflecting a profound bond akin to that of a son to a father. The text illustrates how Joseph's holiness causes a transcendence of natural laws, as seen in the sea's reaction to his presence, highlighting the power of righteous vision to elevate and sanctify all that it perceives. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that the holiness of the righteous can dissolve barriers and bring forth divine revelation.

passage_content: פרשה זו סתומה. אף כי פרשה היא פי' אור התורה המתפשט להיות מובן בחכמת אדם. אך יש פי' נסתר ויש פי' נגלה. וכמ"ש בזוה"ק דגלי מה דבעי רק גלי וסתים ע"ש. וכ"ז שיעקב קיים. גבר הפנימיות על ההסתר וכשנסתלק נסתר לגמרי. ובודאי ירידת יעקב למצרים הי' הכנה לגלות. וז"ש ויחי יעקב בא"מ שהניח שם הארת הקדושה והטמין נקודה חיות בא"מ רק שהי' בהסתר. וכמו כן בכל גלות נמצא נקודה חיות אך ע"י הביטול להפנימיות יכולין למצוא נקודה הנ"ל שהוא סוד הגאולה. וכ' האספו ואגידה לכם שע"י הביטול להאחדות יכולין לעורר חיות יעקב אבינו גם בחשיכה. ולכן בש"ק דמתאחדין ברזא דאחד נתעורר הגאולה כמ"ש בזכות השבת נגאלין. ואא"ז מו"ר ז"ל אמר שע"י בחי' האמת יכולין לעורר החיות גם תוך המיצר כמ"ש ויחי יעקב והוא אמת כמ"ש תתן אמת ליעקב כו'. אכן גם האמת נסתר בגלות והעצה ע"י אמונה כי האמונה פתח ושער לבוא לאמת. ובאמת כל ההסתר הוא כדי לברר מדת האמונה כי בהתגלות האמת לא שייך אמונה. ונמצא שורש ההסתר ע"י אמונה. וממילא גם האמונה היא מפתח של הגאולה:
translation: This section is sealed. Although it is a section, it is the light of the Torah that spreads to be understood in the wisdom of man. However, there is a revealed interpretation and a hidden interpretation. As it is written in the Zohar, "What is needed is revealed, and what is hidden is hidden." And all this is as long as Jacob exists. The inner strength overcomes the concealment, and when the concealment is completely removed. Certainly, Jacob's descent to Egypt was a preparation for the exile. Therefore, it is said, "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," that he left there the illumination of holiness and concealed a point of life in the land of Egypt, only that it was in concealment. Likewise, in every exile, there is a point of life, but through the nullification to the inner essence, one can find the aforementioned point, which is the secret of redemption. And it is written, "Gather and I will tell you," that through the nullification to the unity, one can awaken the life of our father Jacob even in darkness. Therefore, on Shabbat, when we unite in the secret of the One, the redemption is awakened, as it is said, "In the merit of Shabbat, we are redeemed." And our teacher, may his memory be blessed, said that through the aspect of truth, one can awaken the life even within the straits, as it is said, "And Jacob lived," and it is truth, as it is written, "You shall give truth to Jacob." Indeed, even the truth is concealed in exile, and the counsel is through faith, for faith is the opening and the gate to come to the truth. And in truth, all concealment is to clarify the measure of faith, for in the revelation of truth, faith does not apply. Thus, the root of concealment is through faith. Consequently, faith is also the key to redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the dual nature of Torah interpretation, distinguishing between revealed and hidden meanings, particularly in the context of Jacob's descent into Egypt as a precursor to exile. It emphasizes that within every exile, there exists a hidden spark of life that can be accessed through humility and the pursuit of inner truth, which ultimately leads to redemption. The text highlights the importance of faith as a means to uncover this hidden truth, asserting that the essence of concealment serves to refine and strengthen belief. Thus, faith is presented as the key to redemption, enabling the revelation of divine life even in times of darkness.

passage_content: במד' ורש"י משנפטר יעקב אבינו נסתמו עיניהן ולבן של ישראל כו'. כי ישראל עלו במחשבה. והם קיום כל העולם. ומראש הבריאה עד סופו הכל נמשך מדרגה אחר מדרגה השלמת ישראל. והאבות הם המוחין וראשן של ישראל. ואחר הראש נמשך הגוף. ובודאי הארת המוחין עד הרגלים עכ"ז אין מורגש הארת השכל בגוף כמו בראש וכן סדר כל הדורות עד עתה שנק' עקבותא דמשיחא. לכן הי' גם אחר גלות מצרים זמנים מתוקנים מאוד. אח"כ ירידות ועליות כפי משך ציור האדם. ובמצרים הי' חיות הנשמה במיצר. והוא התחלת הארת המוחין בגוף לכן מצווין תמיד לזכור יצי"מ שזה ראשית תיקון ישראל כמ"ש במד' כעובר הנולד כו':
translation: In the Midrash and Rashi, after our father Jacob passed away, their eyes were closed, and the son of Israel, etc. For Israel ascended in thought. And they are the sustenance of the entire world. From the beginning of creation until its end, everything is drawn from level to level, the perfection of Israel. And the patriarchs are the intellect and the head of Israel. And after the head, the body is drawn forth. And certainly, the illumination of the intellect extends down to the feet; nevertheless, the illumination of the intellect is not felt in the body as it is in the head, and so is the order of all generations until now, which is called the footsteps of the Messiah. Therefore, there were also very rectified times after the exile of Egypt. Afterwards, descents and ascents according to the duration of the human form. And in Egypt, the vitality of the soul was in constriction. And this is the beginning of the illumination of the intellect in the body; therefore, we are always commanded to remember the Exodus from Egypt, for this is the beginning of the rectification of Israel, as it is said in the Midrash, like a newborn child, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Jewish people, referred to as Israel, as the foundation of the world, with the patriarchs representing the intellectual and spiritual essence of the nation. It emphasizes the continuous flow of divine influence from the highest spiritual realms down to the physical world, illustrating the cyclical nature of spiritual elevation and descent throughout history. The mention of the Exodus from Egypt highlights a pivotal moment of spiritual awakening and redemption, serving as a reminder of the ongoing process of rectification for Israel. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of recognizing these spiritual dynamics in understanding the Jewish experience and destiny.
