passage_content: במד' האלקים הרועה כו' הקיש גאולה לפרנסה כו'. פי' זה הכח נתן בהם יעקב אבינו לדבק להשורש שלמעלה מהטבע. מה גאולה פלאים כן יש לידע כי הפרנסה הכל בהשגחת הבורא ית' בפרט לכל ברי' כמ"ש יושב וזן מקרני ראמים כו'. וכ"כ נותן לחם לכ"ב. נותן דייקא בכל יום. וז"ש ויברך את יוסף בבחי' יוסף להיות נמשך כ"ד אחר ברכתו ושורשו שלמעלה. וז"ש איש אשר כברכתו כו'. והנה בהדיא לשון ברכה לא מצינו בברכת יעקב לבניו רק ביוסף כי הוא שורש הברכה כנ"ל. ובו נתקיים איש אשר כברכתו. ועל ידו בירך לכולם. והפי' כשנמשכין באמת אחר נקודה פנימיות מהנשמה אז יש תוספות ברכה אל אותה נקודה. ואיש אשר כברכתו אח"כ בירך אותם. כענין שכ' במ"א ע"פ שתה מים מבורך אח"כ מתוך בארך:
translation: In the matter of the God who shepherds, etc., redemption is linked to sustenance, etc. This means that this power was given to them by our forefather Jacob to connect to the root that is above nature. Just as redemption is wondrous, so too one must know that sustenance is all under the supervision of the Creator, blessed be He, specifically for every creature, as it is said, "He sits and sustains from the horns of the wild ox," etc. And so it is said, "He gives bread to the living." He gives precisely every day. And this is what is meant by "and he blessed Joseph" in the aspect of Joseph, to be drawn after the blessing and its root that is above. And this is what is meant by "a man as his blessing," etc. And indeed, we do not find the explicit language of blessing in Jacob's blessing to his sons except for Joseph, for he is the root of the blessing, as mentioned above. And through him, he blessed them all. The explanation is that when one truly draws after the inner point of the soul, then there is an increase of blessing to that point. And "a man as his blessing" afterwards blessed them, as it is written elsewhere, "You shall draw water with joy from the wells of salvation."
summary: The passage emphasizes the connection between redemption and sustenance, highlighting that both are under divine providence. It explains that Jacob imparted a unique power to his descendants to connect with a higher spiritual source beyond nature. Specifically, Joseph is identified as the root of blessing, through whom all blessings are channeled, illustrating that true abundance comes from tapping into the inner essence of the soul. The text suggests that when one aligns with this inner point, they receive an increase in blessings, as exemplified by Joseph's blessing to his brothers.

passage_content: בפסוק בן פורת יוסף. כמ"ש בזוה"ק ע"פ אלה תולדות יעקב יוסף כי הוא העושה פירות. פורת עלי עין שעושה פירות למטה ולמעלה בשורש. וגם הוא בהסתר לכן יש לו מריבות כמ"ש וימררוהו כו' ועי"ז עצמו נתחזק והגיע למעלתו הרמה משם רועה כו' משם דייקא מאותן המריבות. כמ"ש רבות רעות צדיק. ובזוהר מפרש לצדיק לא נאמר רק שע"י אותן הרעות נגמר בצדקו. מכולם יצילנו ה' לשון הצלה והפרשה כמ"ש ויצל אלקים כו' מקנה אביכם כו':
translation: In the verse "Ben Porat Yosef." As it is written in the Zohar, "These are the generations of Jacob: Joseph," for he is the one who produces fruits. "Porat" refers to the eye that produces fruits below and above in the root. And he is also in concealment; therefore, he has conflicts, as it is said, "And they embittered him," etc. And through this very thing, he strengthened himself and reached his exalted level from there, "a shepherd," etc., specifically from those conflicts. As it is said, "Many are the afflictions of the righteous." And in the Zohar, it is explained that it is not said for the righteous, but that through those afflictions, he is completed in his righteousness. May the Lord save us from all of them, the language of salvation and separation, as it is said, "And God saved," etc., from the flock of your father, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph, referred to as "Ben Porat," highlighting his ability to produce fruits both spiritually and materially, symbolizing his connection to higher realms. It emphasizes that despite facing challenges and conflicts, which are seen as a means of strengthening his character, Joseph ultimately achieves a lofty spiritual status. The Zohar notes that the trials faced by the righteous serve to complete their righteousness, suggesting that adversity is integral to spiritual growth and divine protection. The text concludes with a prayer for deliverance from all troubles, reinforcing the theme of divine salvation amidst struggles.

passage_content: כבר כ' במ"א ענין חיות יעקב במצרים שהוא רשימה קדושה שהניח שם יעקב אבינו רק שהוא בדרך נסתר ונק' פרשה סתומה והם הארות הנמצאים ג"כ בגלות לכ"א כפי מה שזוכה וע"י הביטול להכלל האספו והוא בש"ק ג"כ כמ"ש נותנין לו נחלה בלי מצרים נחלת יעקב כו' וכמ"ש במ"א. ובמד' הקיש גאולה לפרנסה מה פרנסה בכל יום אף גאולה כו'. פי' יעקב אבינו פעל זאת להיות נשאר כח וחיות שיוכל איש ישראל בכל יום למצוא הארת הקדושה גם בגלות וזה ק"ש ותפלה בחי' שמע ישראל. שהוא שזוכין ע"י הביטול להכלל למצוא חיות הנ"ל. וכמ"ש אמו"ז ז"ל ע"פ דרשוני וחיו ע"ש. וכ' ויראו אחי יוסף כי מת אביהם שהם ראו זאת. אבל בחי' יוסף הי' למעלה מהם. וראה כי עודנו חי והי' דבוק בנקודת חיותו של יעקב לכן באו אליו. וכמ"ש במ"א במ"ש ויקרא אל יוסף כו' דרשו חז"ל שהי' סיפוק בידו. והענין הוא שקיבל יוסף הצדיק על שכמו להיות עומד במקום יעקב אבינו. וע"י שקיבל עליו זאת הי' יכול יעקב לעלות ליקבר במערה. ולכן וישתחו ישראל כו' ע"ש. וז"ש נתתי לך שכם אחד כמ"ש משכמו ומעלה גבוה כו' פי' שהעמיד אותו למעלה מבחי' השבטים:
translation: It has already been written elsewhere about the matter of the vitality of Jacob in Egypt, which is a holy imprint that our forefather Jacob left there, but it is in a hidden manner and is called a concealed section. These are the illuminations that are also found in exile, each according to what he merits, and through the nullification to the collective, they are gathered, and this is also on Shabbat, as it is said, "They give him an inheritance without measure, the inheritance of Jacob," etc., as mentioned elsewhere. And in the Midrash, redemption is compared to sustenance; just as sustenance is every day, so too is redemption, etc. The explanation is that our forefather Jacob caused this to remain a strength and vitality so that a Jewish person could find the illumination of holiness every day, even in exile, and this is the Shema and prayer, the aspect of "Hear, O Israel." This is because they merit, through the nullification to the collective, to find the aforementioned vitality. And as our master, may his memory be blessed, wrote according to "Seek Me and live," etc. And it is written, "And the brothers of Joseph saw that their father was dead," meaning they saw this. But in the aspect of Joseph, he was above them. And he saw that he was still alive and was attached to the point of the vitality of Jacob; therefore, they came to him. And as mentioned elsewhere regarding "And he called to Joseph," etc., our sages expounded that he had sustenance in his hand. The matter is that Joseph the righteous accepted upon himself to stand in the place of our forefather Jacob. And by accepting this, Jacob was able to ascend to be buried in the cave. Therefore, "And Israel bowed down," etc., as mentioned. And this is what is meant by "I have given you one portion," as it is said, "from the shoulders and above, high," etc., meaning that he was established above the aspect of the tribes.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual legacy of Jacob in Egypt, emphasizing that he left behind a holy essence that remains accessible to the Jewish people, even in exile, through humility and connection to the collective. It highlights the relationship between redemption and sustenance, suggesting that just as physical sustenance is provided daily, so too is spiritual redemption. Jacob's ability to maintain vitality for the Jewish people is linked to the practice of prayer and the recitation of the Shema, which fosters a connection to divine light. Additionally, Joseph is portrayed as a pivotal figure who embodies Jacob's spirit, allowing for continuity and elevation within the lineage of the tribes.

passage_content: בפסוק ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת. יובן עפמ"ש חז"ל כי הנפטר בח"ל ובא ליקבר בארץ הוא חטא ע"ש רק יעקב הי' מקושר שם בעודנו במצרים ז"ש חסד ואמת שידע יוסף כי הוא נקבר שם באמת אע"פ שנפטר כאן כנ"ל:
translation: In the verse "And you shall do with me kindness and truth," it can be understood according to what our Sages have said that when a person passes away outside the Land of Israel and comes to be buried in the Land, it is a sin, for only Jacob was connected there while he was still in Egypt. This is what is meant by kindness and truth, for Joseph knew that he would be buried there in truth, even though he passed away here, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "chesed" (kindness) and "emet" (truth) in relation to burial practices, emphasizing that a deceased person who passes away outside of the Holy Land and is brought back for burial has sinned, except for Jacob, who remained spiritually connected to the land even while in Egypt. It highlights that Joseph understood the importance of being buried in the land of Israel, signifying a deep connection to truth and divine promise. This reflects a broader Hasidic teaching on the significance of the land and the spiritual implications of one's final resting place. Ultimately, it underscores the interplay between physical presence and spiritual truth in the context of life and death.

passage_content: האספו ואגידה הקבצו ושמעו. שיש ב' מיני אסיפות א' לעורר כח השפעה והוא בחי' יוסף הצדיק. וכנראה שזה נתקיים בהם לכן הי' מוכן לגלות להם. והקבצו ושמעו הוא בחי' בנימין הצדיק כח הקיבוץ להיות מוכנים לקבל. ובחי' זו לא היתה מתוקנת עדיין. לכן נסתם ממנו כי הי' התחלת הגלות. ועיקר הגלות הוא שא"י להתאסף לבות בנ"י כאחד. וע"ז מבקשין קבץ נדחינו. לכן בש"ק דמתאחדין כו' יש התעוררות הגאולה. ויחי יעקב בא"מ הוא שהקדים הקב"ה רפואה למכה. וראה יעקב אע"ה התועלת שיהי' בגאולת מצרים כמ"ש ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול. ושם נעשו לגוי גדול כמו שהמשילו חז"ל כעובר הנולד ע"ש על פסוק מכור הברזל וזה הסוד של הקץ שרצה להראות להם. וכמו כן נגלה ליוסף ולכן ויבך יוסף בדברם אליו כמ"ש בשנים הקודמין. מזה שהם הרגישו הגלות והסתלקות יעקב וחששו שגרמו ח"ו ירידה לאביהם כנראה מלשון הפסוק ויראו כו' כי מת אביהם. כאילו היו סבורין שיעקב אע"ה יתקן שיהי' בלע המות לנצח ומכ"ש שלא ישלוט בו מה"מ כאשר באמת חכמים הגידו כי יעקב לא מת. ויוסף אמר להם כי אדרבה יעקב המשיך הארת החיות לתוך מצרים להחיות עם רב:
translation: Gather and I will tell you, assemble and listen. There are two types of gatherings: one is to awaken the power of influence, which is in the aspect of Joseph the Righteous. And it seems that this was fulfilled in them, therefore he was prepared to reveal to them. And the gathering and listening is in the aspect of Benjamin the Righteous, the power of gathering to be ready to receive. And this aspect was not yet rectified. Therefore it was sealed from him, as it was the beginning of the exile. And the essence of the exile is that the Land of Israel should not gather the hearts of the Children of Israel as one. And for this we request the gathering of our dispersed. Therefore, on Shabbat, when they unite, there is an awakening of redemption. And "Jacob lived in the land of Egypt" means that the Holy One, blessed be He, preceded healing to the blow. And Jacob, our forefather, saw the benefit that would come from the redemption from Egypt, as it is said, "and afterwards they went out with great wealth." And there they became a great nation, as our Sages have likened it to a newborn, as mentioned in the verse "from the iron crucible," and this is the secret of the end that he wanted to show them. And likewise, it was revealed to Joseph, and therefore "Joseph wept when they spoke to him," as it is said in the previous years. From the fact that they felt the exile and the departure of Jacob, they feared that they had caused, Heaven forbid, a decline to their father, as is evident from the language of the verse "and they saw... that their father was dead." As if they thought that Jacob, our forefather, would rectify that death would be swallowed up forever, and certainly that it would not rule over him from the other side, as indeed the Sages have stated that Jacob did not die. And Joseph said to them that, on the contrary, Jacob drew down the light of life into Egypt to sustain a great nation.
summary: The passage discusses two types of gatherings: one that awakens the power of influence, represented by Joseph, and another that prepares for reception, represented by Benjamin. It emphasizes that the essence of exile is the inability of the Jewish people to unite as one in the Land of Israel, and that the call for gathering reflects a yearning for redemption. Jacob's foresight of the future redemption and the transformation of the Jewish people into a great nation in Egypt illustrates the divine plan, where even in exile, the light of life is sustained, countering the fear of death and separation. Ultimately, Joseph reassures his brothers that Jacob's spirit continues to bring vitality to the people, highlighting the enduring connection between them.

passage_content: במדרש על פסוק הרועה אותי הגואל אותי הקיש פרנסה לגאולה מה פרנסה בכל יום כן גאולה. ומה גאולה פלאים כן פרנסה פלאים. כנראה שזה יסוד הגאולה לידע כי יש התחדשות בכל יום גם תוך הטבע כמ"ש מחדש בכל יום מ"ב וגם הפרנסה שאדם טורח ומוציא הכל פלאים. רק שיש נפלאות מגולים ויש נסתרים תוך הטבע. והמשכיל יתבונן כמו שבכל יום מחדש הקב"ה הטבע. כן מתגלין בכל יום גאולות בלבות בנ"י עובדי השי"ת. וכשיש הארת זאת ההתחדשות אין גלות בעולם. ועל ענין זה יסדו חז"ל ב' ברכות בכל יום קודם ק"ש ערב ובוקר. על בריאת אור וחושך שהוא התחדשות בבחי' הטבע בחי' עשרה מאמרות. ועל תורה ומצות שהוא התחדשות הפנימיות בחי' גאולה שבכל יום כנ"ל בחי' עשרת הדברות. וזה הדרך המיוחד רק לבנ"י. ואחר ב' אלו ההתחדשות באין לאחדות של ק"ש. וזה הרמז יברך את הנערים. מלשון התעוררות ב' אלו ההתחדשות שיש בכל יום. ואפרים הפנימיות. ומנשה בחי' התחדשות מ"ב. לכן הקדים לאפרים. הגם כי מתחלה צריכין לתקן הטבע ולכן הקדימו ברכת יוצר לאהבה. אבל צריכין לידע ולבטל הכל אל העיקר שהיא התורה. [ועמ"ש רמז בפ' מקץ וליוסף יולד שני בנים כו'. כי התחדשות של יוסף עצמו הוא עיקר האחדות רק אח"כ מתפשט לב' בחי' הנ"ל. ומזה יפרד אח"כ לכמה מינים עד שיוכל להיות ג"כ שני הרעב. וכמו כן נתקיים זה הרמז שלא התחיל גלות מצרים עד שנתעלה יוסף. ומנשה ואפרים עמדו במקומו. ואח"כ התחילו להרגיש הגלות]. וב' בחי' הנ"ל הם בחי' חומר וצורה בכלל הבריאה שנמשכו מן ההוי' הראשונה:
translation: In the Midrash on the verse "The shepherd who guides me, the redeemer who saves me," it compares sustenance to redemption: just as sustenance is provided daily, so too is redemption. And just as redemption is miraculous, so is sustenance miraculous. It seems that the foundation of redemption is to know that there is renewal every day, even within nature, as it is said, "He renews every day the act of creation," and also the sustenance that a person toils for and expends is all miraculous. There are revealed wonders and hidden ones within nature. The wise will contemplate that just as every day the Holy One, blessed be He, renews nature, so too do redemptions manifest daily in the hearts of the Jewish people, servants of the Blessed One. When there is illumination of this renewal, there is no exile in the world. Regarding this matter, our Sages established two blessings every day before the Shema, in the evening and in the morning: one for the creation of light and darkness, which is the renewal in the aspect of nature through the ten utterances, and one for the Torah and commandments, which is the renewal of the inner aspect, the aspect of redemption that occurs every day, as mentioned in the aspect of the Ten Commandments. This is the special path only for the Jewish people. After these two renewals, they come to the unity of the Shema. And this is the hint "He will bless the youths," from the language of awakening of these two renewals that exist every day. And Ephraim represents the inner aspect, while Menashe represents the renewal of the ten utterances. Therefore, he precedes Ephraim, even though initially they need to rectify nature, and thus the blessing of the Creator is preceded by love. But they need to know and nullify everything to the essence, which is the Torah. [And see the hint in Parashat Miketz, "And Joseph had two sons born to him," etc. For the renewal of Joseph himself is the essence of unity, only afterwards does it expand to the two aforementioned aspects. From this, it will later separate into various kinds until it can also be the two famines. And likewise, this hint is fulfilled that the exile of Egypt did not begin until Joseph was elevated. And Menashe and Ephraim stood in his place. And afterwards, they began to feel the exile.] And the two aforementioned aspects are the aspect of matter and form in the entirety of creation that are drawn from the first existence.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel emphasizes the connection between daily sustenance and redemption, highlighting that both are manifestations of divine renewal within nature. It teaches that just as God renews the world each day, so too do hidden miracles of redemption occur in the hearts of the Jewish people. The text underscores the importance of recognizing this daily renewal, which can lead to a state of unity and the absence of exile. Additionally, it reflects on the roles of Ephraim and Manasseh, symbolizing inner renewal and the need to prioritize Torah and mitzvot as the essence of this divine connection.

passage_content: בפסוק וזאת אשר דיבר להם אביהם כו' איש אשר כברכתו ברך אותם. כי צורתו של יעקב חקוקה תחת כסה"כ שהוא האדם שברא השי"ת בעולם. וצורתו למטה כצורתו למעלה שנמשך אחר השורש. והי' הכולל של כל ישראל לכך קרא שמו ישראל. וזה רמז איש אשר כברכתו על יעקב שהי' איש למטה כמו השורש שלו למעלה. והעיד הכ' שהי' יכול לברך אותם כי עיקר הברכה למשוך מן השורש אל הצורה שלמטה ונתן לכל א' מקומו והראה להם מקום אחוזתם בו כמ"ש אשר דיבר להם אביהם שהמשיך אותם אחריו שהוא השורש שלהם ושל כל בנ"י כנ"ל. כי דיבור הוא הנהגה כמו ידבר עמים:
translation: In the verse "And this is what their father spoke to them," etc., "a man as his blessing he blessed them." For the form of Jacob is engraved under the Divine Throne, as he is the man whom the Holy One, blessed be He, created in the world. And his form below is like his form above, as it follows the root. And he is the totality of all Israel; therefore, he called his name Israel. And this hints at "a man as his blessing" upon Jacob, who was a man below like his root above. And the verse testifies that he was able to bless them, for the essence of the blessing is to draw from the root to the form below, and he gave each one his place and showed them their portion in it, as it is said, "which their father spoke to them," as he drew them after him, being their root and that of all the children of Israel, as mentioned. For speech is guidance, as in "He will speak to the nations."
summary: The passage emphasizes the connection between Jacob and the divine, illustrating that Jacob's form is inscribed under the Divine Throne, representing the archetype of humanity created by God. It highlights that Jacob's blessings to his sons reflect his ability to draw from the spiritual root above to the physical realm below, thereby establishing their unique places within the collective identity of Israel. The act of speaking, as demonstrated by Jacob, signifies guidance and leadership, linking the physical descendants to their spiritual source.

passage_content: עוד לפסוק הנ"ל כל אלה ש"י שנים עשר. וקשה כל מיותר. ולבאר הענין בקצרה כי השבטים הם התפשטות ישראל שהוא ענין י"ג מדות שהתורה נדרשת בהן. כי עצם התורה למעלה נעלמה מעיני כל חי. רק ע"י הי"ג שבטים הם כלים ומדות לצמצם הארת התורה ע"י אלה המדות. וכמו שהאבות הם הם המרכבה ויעקב עיקר התורה. כן השבטים הם הי"ג דרכים המקבלים הארת התורה. וז"ש כל אלה שאין בהם רק בחי' שבטי ישראל שהם רק רוחניות כמו האבות במרכבה עליונה כן השבטים סמוכין להם. וכל הוא לשון מדה כמו וכל בשליש עפר הארץ. גם הוא לשון השתוקקות כמו כלתה רוחי. וע"י שהם היו נכספין ומשתוקקים רק לקבל השפעת האבות. עי"ז התשוקה מתהוה בחי' צימצום ומדות בהתורה. וז"ש ע"י שכל אלה ש"י כו' וזאת אשר דיבר כו' שעי"ז נולד בהתורה כח הצימצום והתפשטות כנ"ל:
translation: Furthermore, regarding the aforementioned verse, all these are twelve. And it is difficult, as everything is superfluous. To explain the matter briefly, the tribes are the expansion of Israel, which is the matter of the thirteen attributes through which the Torah is interpreted. For the essence of the Torah above is hidden from the eyes of all living beings. Only through the thirteen tribes are they vessels and measures to constrict the illumination of the Torah through these attributes. Just as the patriarchs are the chariot and Jacob is the essence of the Torah, so the tribes are the thirteen pathways that receive the illumination of the Torah. And this is what is meant by all these, which contain only the aspect of the tribes of Israel, which are only spiritual, like the patriarchs in the upper chariot, so the tribes are close to them. And all is a term of measure, as in "and all in a third of the dust of the earth." It is also a term of yearning, as in "my spirit has yearned." And by their yearning and desire only to receive the influence of the patriarchs, through this yearning, a state of constriction and measures is created in the Torah. And this is what is meant by "all these are twelve," and "this which he spoke," that through this, the power of constriction and expansion is born in the Torah, as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the twelve tribes of Israel and the thirteen attributes through which the Torah is understood. It emphasizes that the tribes serve as vessels to channel the divine light of the Torah, similar to how the patriarchs embody the divine chariot. The tribes, being spiritual entities, reflect a yearning to receive the influence of the patriarchs, which in turn creates a framework of limitation and expansion within the Torah. Ultimately, this dynamic of desire and reception gives rise to the concept of contraction and expansion in the divine teachings.

passage_content: בפסוק האספו ואגידה הקבצו ושמעו. שהם ב' מיני כנסיות. כמ"ש כבר שרומזים למשיח בן יוסף ובן דוד. ויש אסיפה לעורר השפעה היורדת מן השמים וזה בחי' יוסף האספו ואגידה. והגמר והסוף הוא בחי' בן דוד הקבצו ושמעו שהוא הכח המקבל. דכתי' גבורי כח עושי דברו לשמוע. שבנ"י מעוררין הדיבור ואח"כ מוכנים לשמוע הדיבור כמ"ש בזוה"ק פ' בלק ע"ש. וב' אלו הדברים נשאר בישראל לעולם כמ"ש בכל יום. אנכי מצוך היום. וע"ז ניתקן שמע ישראל א"כ יש קול היורד משמים לבנ"י תמיד. ובחי' התפלה היא עבודה שבלב. זה הקבצו ושמעו כו'. ובוודאי מתקיים בכללות ישראל כל זה רק שצריכין לייגע עצמם להוציא מכח אל הפועל אלה הדברים. כי האבות והשבטים כולם הניחו שרשים בלבות בנ"י כי כל מעשיהם לא הי' במקרה כי המה עמודי העולם. כמ"ש כל אלה ש"י כו' וזאת אשר דיבר כו' שהעמיד כל א' על מקומו וקשר אותם בשורש העליון. ויברך אותם הוא התוספות שלמעלה מהטבע. ובאמת עיקר הברכה לא נזכר בכל השבטים רק ביוסף שהוא הכלי מחזיק ברכה שלום. ורמז ויברך אותם. האות שלהם. הוא הצדיק. ורמז ביוסף י"ב ברכות. ה' פעמים ברכות. תרי משמע. הם עשרה. ויברכך י"א. וכ' ויברך את יוסף הרי י"ב. שקיבל י"ב ברכות בעבור כולם. כדכ' ברכות אביך גברו כו' תהיינה לראש יוסף שהוא המקבל מיעקב ומשפיע להשבטים. ואמר ברכות אביך והול"ל ברכתי כדמסיים הורי. רק לרמז כי בכח יוסף הצדיק מתרומם ברכות אביך כמ"ש שהוא להבה ואש בלא להבה אינו שולט למרחוק. וכ' עזה כמות אהבה בחי' אברהם. קשה כו' בחי' יצחק. רשפי' רשפי אש בחי' יערב. שלהבת בחי' יוסף. וכל אלה השרשים נשארו בישראל לכן מים רבים לא יכבו האהבה כנ"ל:
translation: In the verse "Assemble and I will tell; gather and hear," these refer to two types of gatherings, as has been mentioned, hinting at Messiah son of Joseph and Messiah son of David. There is an assembly to awaken the influence that descends from heaven, and this is in the aspect of Joseph, "Assemble and I will tell." The completion and the end are in the aspect of son of David, "Gather and hear," which is the receiving power, as it is written, "Mighty ones of strength, doing His word, to hear." The Children of Israel awaken the speech and then are prepared to hear the speech, as mentioned in the Zohar, Parashat Balak, etc. These two matters remain with Israel forever, as it is said, "I command you today." And for this, the Shema Yisrael is established; thus, there is a voice that descends from heaven to the Children of Israel always. And the aspect of prayer is the service of the heart. This is "Gather and hear," etc. And certainly, all this is fulfilled in the entirety of Israel, only that they need to exert themselves to bring these matters from potential to actual. For the patriarchs and the tribes all left roots in the hearts of the Children of Israel, for all their deeds were not by chance, for they are the pillars of the world, as it is said, "All these are the names," etc., and "This is what he spoke," etc., that he established each one in their place and connected them to the upper root. And he blessed them; this is the addition that is above nature. And indeed, the essence of the blessing is not mentioned among all the tribes except for Joseph, who is the vessel that holds the blessing of peace. And the hint "And he blessed them," their letter is the righteous one. And the hint in Joseph is twelve blessings. Five times blessings, two means ten. "And He will bless you" is eleven. And it is written, "And He blessed Joseph," hence twelve, for he received twelve blessings on behalf of all. As it is written, "The blessings of your father have prevailed," etc., they shall be for the head of Joseph, who is the receiver from Jacob and the one who imparts to the tribes. And it says, "The blessings of your father," and it could have said, "I blessed," as it concludes with "my parents," only to hint that through the power of Joseph the righteous, the blessings of your father are elevated, as it is said, for he is a flame and fire; without a flame, it does not dominate from afar. And it is written, "As strong as death is love," in the aspect of Abraham. "Hard as the grave," in the aspect of Isaac. "Flames of fire," in the aspect of Jacob. "The flame," in the aspect of Joseph. And all these roots remain in Israel; therefore, many waters cannot quench love, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the dual aspects of gathering and listening in the context of the Messianic figures of Joseph and David, emphasizing the importance of spiritual preparation and receptivity among the Jewish people. It highlights the continuous divine communication to Israel and the role of prayer as heartfelt service. The text underscores the foundational impact of the patriarchs and tribes, particularly Joseph, who embodies the vessel of blessings and spiritual influence. Ultimately, it conveys that the deep-rooted love and connection to God within Israel cannot be extinguished, symbolizing an enduring spiritual legacy.

passage_content: במדרש פ' זו סתומה שנסתם עיניהם ולבם של ישראל. הענין להראות שבנ"י עושים רושם וכפי מה שנסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל כך נעשה פרשה סתומה בתורה. וזהו עצמו ענין אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה. עמו אנכי בצרה. כי גלותן של בנ"י איננו עונשין בלבד. רק כמו שהגאולות מסודרים בסדר נכון. כך יש סדר לאלה הגליות. דאיתא אורייתא וישראל וקוב"ה כולא חד. וכמה דשמא קדישא ואורייתא סתים וגליא כך הוא בנפשותיהן של בנ"י. ובזמן המקדש הי' התגלות למעלה ולמטה. ובעת הגלות הכל בסתום. ובב' בחינות הנ"ל נשתבחו בנ"י כמ"ש שחורה אני בגלות ונאוה בגאולה. וכ' גן נעול. פי' מה שבנ"י יכולין להסתיר עצמן ושלא להתערב בין האומות בהיותם בתוכם. וכ' כשושנה בין החוחים שאז בגלות כנס"י כשושנה אטומה. וכמו כן כתפוח בעצי היער כן דודי כו' דרשו חז"ל כמו תפוח שאין לו צל כו'. פי' כשבנ"י בגלות בין החוחים כך הוא הסדר למעלה כביכול להיות כתפוח בסתום. אבל בנ"י יודעין הסוד שכך יש בחי' סתים וגליא. לכן מתחזקין באמונתו גם בלילות. וז"ש בצלו חמדתי וישבתי פי' שזכו לבוא אח"כ לבחי' ההתגלות שאח"כ נגלה עליהם עיני כבודו ית' בפרהסיא כשהי' הגאולה למטה. וזה גל נעול בחי' ההתגלות. וגם אמת גן נעול וגל נעול הכל בעת הסתום דכ' נעול. והם בחי' עיניהם ולבם של ישראל. כי הלב נסתר ונק' גן. והעין גל. ושניהם נסתמו. ועין ולב הם העיקר כמ"ש ולא תתורו אחרי לבבכם ואחרי עיניכם כו' ע"ש במד'. ומאחר שעיקר הכח בהם בבחי' הקדושה ממילא יש עליהם הסתרות לכן כתיב ולא תתורו. ועיין בזוה"ק. ועל ב' אלו נתקן מצות התפילין. ש"י נגד הלב. וש"ר בין עיניך. ובכללות ישראל י"ל כי יהודה ויוסף המה ב' התפילין שהיד מיוחס ליהודה כמ"ש ידך בעורף. ידיו רב לו. וליוסף הראש כמ"ש לראש יוסף. עלי עין:
translation: In the Midrash, this section is sealed, as the eyes and hearts of Israel have been sealed. The matter is to show that the Children of Israel make an impression, and according to how their eyes and hearts have been sealed, so a sealed section is made in the Torah. This is the same matter as "I will go down with you to Egypt." I am with you in distress. For the exile of the Children of Israel is not merely punishment. Just as the redemptions are arranged in a proper order, so too there is an order to these exiles. It is stated that the Torah, Israel, and the Holy One, blessed be He, are all one. And as much as the Holy Name and the Torah are both concealed and revealed, so it is with the souls of the Children of Israel. In the time of the Temple, there was revelation above and below. But during the exile, everything is concealed. In these two aspects, the Children of Israel are praised, as it is said, "I am black in exile and beautiful in redemption." And it is written, "A locked garden." This means that the Children of Israel can hide themselves and not mingle among the nations while they are among them. And it is written, "As a rose among thorns," that then in exile, the congregation of Israel is like a closed rose. And likewise, "As an apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved." The sages have interpreted this as an apple that has no shade. This means that when the Children of Israel are in exile among the thorns, so is the order above, as it were, to be like an apple in concealment. But the Children of Israel know the secret that there are both aspects of concealment and revelation. Therefore, they strengthen themselves in their faith even at night. And this is what is meant by "In His shadow I delighted and sat," meaning that they merited to later come to a state of revelation when His glory was revealed to them publicly when the redemption was below. This is a locked revelation, an aspect of revelation. And also, "A true locked garden" and "A locked revelation" all refer to the time of concealment, as it is written, "locked." And these are the aspects of the eyes and hearts of Israel. For the heart is concealed and is called a garden, and the eye is revealed. And both have been sealed. The eye and heart are the essence, as it is written, "And you shall not stray after your hearts and after your eyes," etc., as stated in the Midrash. And since the main strength in them is in the aspect of holiness, therefore there are concealments upon them, hence it is written, "And you shall not stray." And see in the Zohar. And for these two, the commandment of tefillin was established: one for the heart, and one between your eyes. In general, it can be said that Judah and Joseph are the two tefillin, as the hand is attributed to Judah, as it is written, "Your hand is on the back of your enemies. His hands are plentiful for him." And for Joseph, the head, as it is written, "To the head of Joseph. Upon the eye."
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual state of the Jewish people during exile, emphasizing that their suffering is not merely punishment but part of a divine order that parallels their eventual redemption. It highlights the connection between the hiddenness of their spiritual essence and the concealed nature of the Torah, suggesting that both the Jewish soul and the Torah experience states of revelation and concealment. The text also underscores the importance of maintaining faith and connection to God during times of darkness, as symbolized by the mitzvot of tefillin, which represent the heart and eyes of Israel. Ultimately, it conveys that despite the concealment, there is a promise of future revelation and redemption.

passage_content: בפסוק ויקרא יעקב אל בניו כו'. כי קריאה הוא לשון התקרבות והתחברות כמ"ש וקרא זה א"ז. ולשון מינוי כמ"ש ויקרא לאור יום פי' חז"ל קריא רחמנא לנהורא ופקדי' אמצוותא דיממא כו'. והענין שנתן יעקב אע"ה לכל שבט מינוי שלו. והראה לכל א' מקומו והתחברות שלו ביעקב אביהם. כי כמו שיעקב אע"ה מקיים כל הבריאה כמ"ש חז"ל שצורתו חקוקה תחת כסה"כ. כן השבטים המה עמודים שכל העולם עומד עליהם. וע"ז כתיב לה' מצוקי ארץ וישת עליהם תבל. וכ' לה' עין אדם. וכל שבטי ישראל עין אדם הוא הצורה של יעקב אבינו שאחז"ל שופרי' דיעקב מעין שופרי' דאדם הראשון וכל השבטים הם ענפים שמתפשטין מזה האילן. וכ' וזאת אשר דיבר להם כו' ויברך אותם. יתכן לפרש כי הברכה הי' ממדה הזאת. וע"י שחיבר ודיבק אותם לבחי' הזאת קיבלו מזאת הברכה. וזה שרמזו חז"ל במד' במקום שסיים יעקב התחיל מרע"ה ע"ש בפ' וזאת הברכה. וז"ש וזאת אשר דיבר שהוא לשון התמנות שדיבר להם בחי' הזאת שהיא מלכות שמים. ויברך אותם הזאת הנ"ל שבו הברכה כמ"ש וזאת הברכה. ומצינו בבני יוסף שאמר יעקב אבינו ע"ה קחם נא אלי ואברכם. שיקרב אותם אליו. וממילא יתברכו ממנו. מכ"ש כפי התקרבות וחיבור הנפשות להשורש מקבלין ברכה משם. וזה ג"כ ברכת השבת דכתי' ויברך כו' את יום השביעי. ע"י שהשבת מעלה ומקרב כל הברואים אל השורש ממילא מקבלין ברכה כנ"ל:
translation: In the verse "And Jacob called to his sons," it is stated that calling is a term of closeness and connection, as it is said, "And he called, this is the meaning." And it is a term of appointment, as it is said, "And he called to the light of day," meaning the Holy One, blessed be He, called the light and appointed the commandments of the day, etc. The matter is that Jacob, our father, gave each tribe its own appointment and showed each one its place and connection to Jacob, their father. Just as Jacob, our father, fulfills all of creation, as our Sages have said, that his form is engraved under the Divine Throne, so too the tribes are pillars upon which the whole world stands. And concerning this, it is written, "To the Lord belong the foundations of the earth, and He established upon them the world." And it is written, "To the Lord, the eye of man." And all the tribes of Israel, the eye of man, is the form of our forefather Jacob, as our Sages have said, "The shofar of Jacob is like the shofar of Adam the first," and all the tribes are branches that extend from this tree. And it is written, "And this is what he spoke to them," and "He blessed them." It is possible to explain that the blessing was from this attribute. And by connecting and binding them to this aspect, they received from this blessing. This is what our Sages hinted at in the Midrash, that where Jacob finished, Moses began, as mentioned in the portion "And this is the blessing." And this is what is meant by "And this is what he spoke," which is a term of appointment, that he spoke to them in this aspect, which is the Kingdom of Heaven. "And He blessed them," this aforementioned aspect in which the blessing is contained, as it is said, "And this is the blessing." And we find with the sons of Joseph that our father Jacob, peace be upon him, said, "Bring them near to me, and I will bless them," to bring them close to him. And consequently, they would be blessed from him. How much more so, as the closeness and connection of the souls to the root, they receive blessing from there. This is also the blessing of the Sabbath, as it is written, "And He blessed the seventh day." By the Sabbath elevating and bringing all creations closer to the root, they automatically receive blessing, as mentioned above.
summary: In this passage, the author emphasizes the significance of Jacob's call to his sons as a means of fostering closeness and connection, reflecting the Hasidic idea of unity among the tribes of Israel. Jacob's blessings to each tribe symbolize their unique roles and their integral relationship with him, akin to the foundational pillars of the world. The text also highlights the concept that through spiritual connection and proximity to their source, the tribes receive divine blessings, paralleling the sanctity of the Sabbath, which elevates all creation towards its root. Ultimately, the passage illustrates the profound interconnectedness of the Jewish people and their relationship with God through their patriarch Jacob.

passage_content: בפסוק האספו ואגידה לכם כו' יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים. דרשו חז"ל כי פרשה זו הכנה על הגלות ולכן אמרו שביקש לגלות הקץ. כי הנה השבטים המה העמודים אשר כל בנ"י נשען עליהם בגלות. כי הג' אבות הם למעלה מעלמא דפירודא. והשבטים המה הולכים עד אחרית הימים. ומכלל שאמר האספו הקבצו. משמע שהמה בעלמא דפירודא כענין שנא' עם אחד מפוזר ומפורד בה"ע. פי' שבנ"י המה מבררין האחדות גם בעלמא דפירודא. ולכן איתא במדרשות כי הד' דגלים המה מוכנים לעקור הד' מלכיות. ואיתא במד' בראשית ומשם יפרד כו' שם הא' פישון כו' דורש על המלכיות ע"ש. וכי יעלה עה"ד כי הראשים אשר מתפרדין מגן עדן הם הד' מלכיות. רק הנהרות המושכין מג"ע עד עלמא דפירודא שהם הם הדגלים כענין שנא' כד' רוחות השמים פרשתי אתכם. והמה עומדין במקום שליטת המלכיות כענין שנאמר יצב גבולות עמים למספר בנ"י. והם הי"ב שבטים. והאבות הם בג"ע לעולם. והשבטים המה עולים ויורדים להעלות התחתונים. ולכן רמז אשר יקרא אתכם. וקשה אי הכוונה על זרעם אחריהם הול"ל אותנו. כי גם הוא אבינו. אך הרמז שהשבטים הולכים עם בנ"י עד סוף כל הדורות כנ"ל. ועל זכות השבטים מבקשין ברוגז אהבה תזכור שהמה אוהבי הקב"ה כדכ' ודגלו עלי אהבה. והם הי"ב שבטים ויוסף המאחד אותם כי אהבה גי' אחד. וכאשר הי' חוקקין שמות השבטים על לב אהרן לזכרון לפני הש"י. [ויתכן לומר כי האבות נק' רעים דלא מתפרשין והשבטים דודים]. ובאמת האבות והשבטים המה כלים אשר הכין השי"ת לקיום העולמות. ובפרט בנ"י הבוחרים בדרכיהם צריכין להתחזק בזכות השרשים כדכתי' הבו לה' בני אלים. ובענין המלכיות נראה דכ' מלכותך מלכות כל עולמים והכל לכבודו ברא. ובאמת לבנ"י בעצם הנהגת הבורא ית' עמהם בבחי' אב ע"י התורה והדעת שבנ"י מבינים כי לה' הארץ ומלואה והיא בחי' אבות. אך בחי' המלכות היא לברר ביד חזקה להלחם עם המורדים במלכות שמים. וזה יתקיים לעתיד וע"ז נשתלחו בנ"י בעלמא דפרודא לברר ולהעיד על עול מלכות שמים. וזהו בחי' הי"ב שבטים והדגלים ללחום מלחמות ה' כדאי' י"ב מנהיגים במלחמה. ובנ"י לבסוף יתקנו הכל בבחי' בן ובבחי' עבד. והם ב' העבודות שצריכין לעבוד אותו ית' והוא בחי' האבות והשבטים כמ"ש:
translation: In the verse "Gather and I will tell you... He will call you in the end of days," our Sages have interpreted that this section is a preparation for the exile, and therefore they said that he sought to reveal the end. For behold, the tribes are the pillars upon which all the children of Israel lean during the exile. The three Patriarchs are above the world of separation, while the tribes continue until the end of days. From the general statement "Gather," it implies that they are in the world of separation, as it is said, "A single nation scattered and dispersed among the nations." This means that the children of Israel are clarifying unity even in the world of separation. Therefore, it is stated in the Midrash that the four banners are prepared to uproot the four kingdoms. It is also stated in the Midrash, "And from there it will be separated..." There, the first river is Pishon... which is interpreted regarding the kingdoms, as mentioned. And if it arises in the mind, the heads that are separated from the Garden of Eden are the four kingdoms. Only the rivers that flow from the Garden of Eden to the world of separation are the banners, as it is said, "As the four winds of heaven I have spread you." They stand in the place of the dominion of the kingdoms, as it is said, "He set the boundaries of the nations according to the number of the children of Israel." And they are the twelve tribes. The Patriarchs are in the Garden of Eden forever, while the tribes ascend and descend to elevate the lower ones. Therefore, it hints at "He will call you." It is difficult; if the intention is for their descendants after them, it should have said "us," for he is also our father. However, the hint is that the tribes go with the children of Israel until the end of all generations, as mentioned. And for the merit of the tribes, we ask in anger and love, "Remember that they are the lovers of the Holy One, blessed be He," as it is written, "And His banner over me is love." They are the twelve tribes, and Joseph unites them because love equals one. And just as they would engrave the names of the tribes on the heart of Aaron for remembrance before the Holy One, blessed be He. [And it may be said that the Patriarchs are called friends who do not separate, while the tribes are called uncles]. In truth, the Patriarchs and the tribes are vessels that the Holy One, blessed be He, prepared for the existence of the worlds. Especially the children of Israel, who choose their paths, need to strengthen themselves in the merit of the roots, as it is written, "Give to the Lord, O sons of mighty ones." Regarding the kingdoms, it seems that it is written, "Your kingdom is the kingdom of all worlds, and everything was created for His glory." And indeed, for the children of Israel, in the essence of the governance of the Creator, may He be blessed, with them in the aspect of a father through the Torah and the knowledge that the children of Israel understand that the earth and its fullness belong to the Lord, and this is the aspect of the Patriarchs. However, the aspect of kingship is to clarify with a strong hand to fight against those who rebel against the heavenly kingdom. This will be fulfilled in the future, and for this, the children of Israel were sent into the world of separation to clarify and testify about the yoke of the heavenly kingdom. This is the aspect of the twelve tribes and the banners to wage the wars of the Lord, as there are twelve leaders in battle. And in the end, the children of Israel will rectify everything in the aspect of a son and in the aspect of a servant. These are the two forms of service that they need to serve Him, blessed be He, and this is the aspect of the Patriarchs and the tribes, as it is said.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the tribes of Israel as pillars supporting the Jewish people during exile, emphasizing their role in maintaining unity amidst division. It highlights the connection between the patriarchs, who exist in a higher spiritual realm, and the tribes, who actively engage with the world to elevate the lower realms. The tribes are seen as instruments for fighting against the forces of the four kingdoms, symbolizing the struggle for divine sovereignty. Ultimately, the Jewish people are called to strengthen their connection to their roots, embodying both the roles of sons and servants in their service to God.

passage_content: בפסוק בן פורת יוסף כו' עלי עין בנות צעדה עלי שור. אמו"ז ז"ל פי' ע"פ הגמ' יוסף שקידש העין זכה שיאכלו קדשים במשכן שילה בכל הרואה ובירושלים לפנים מן החומה וזה בנות צעדה השבטים עלי שור. ויוסף עלי עין. ועתה נבאר לפי דרכנו פורת עלי עין. דכ' ויוסף ישית ידו על עיניך. כי הנה צורתו של יעקב אבינו חקוקה תחת כסה"כ והיא הצורה אשר הקב"ה ברא בעולם. וע"ז כ' וירא כו' את כל א"ע והנה טוב מאוד. וצורה זו שנק' עין יעקב בוודאי היא לעולם בכללות בנ"י כענין שנאמר כל רואיהם יכירום כו'. אך אין העולם כדאי להתגלות זה העין בתוך הרשעים. וכשהי' בנ"י מתאספין ביחד בבהמ"ק ונבדלו מן האומות חל עליהם צורה זו וזה עליות ג' רגלים יראה כל זכורך. ואלה הבנינים במשכן ובבהמ"ק הי' חומות שהעמידו בנ"י להיות הבדל ביניהם. ואז כשנבדלין ומתאספין יש להם אחיזה עד צורתו של יעקב. וז"ש האספו ואגידה כו' והוא אמת לעולם כשיכולין להתאסף כראוי כמ"ש במ"א מזה. אכן כוחו של יוסף הצדיק הי' שאין עה"ר שולטת בו כמ"ש חז"ל בפ' וידגו לרוב. ולכן יכול לקבל הארת הקדושה גם כשהוא תוך הרשעים. ולכן הי' הוא המכין מקום במצרים עבור בנ"י. ויעקב אע"ה ירא לירד למצרים שלא ישלוט עין רעה באותו הצורה ואמר לו הקב"ה ויוסף ישית ידו כו'. וז"ש פורת עלי עין. והם ב' מיני עבודות. השבטים הכינו עצות להיות חומות מפסיקין. ויוסף הכין מקום לסמות עיניהם של הרשעים שלח יוכלו להסתכל ולמנוע האור מן הצדיקים. ובשבת מתקיים מעין ברכת יוסף שהקב"ה פורס סוכת שלום עלינו. ולכן אמרו חז"ל אין דומה מאור פניו של אדם בש"ק לחול. ע"י שיש שמירה ממילא חל על בנ"י בחי' עין יעקב כנ"ל. והיא הנשמה יתירה בש"ק כנ"ל:
translation: In the verse "Ben Porat Yosef" etc., "Ali Ayin" "Bnot Tz'eda" "Ali Shor." Our teacher, may his memory be blessed, explains according to the Gemara that Yosef, who sanctified the eye, merited that the holy offerings be eaten in the Mishkan of Shiloh by all who see, and in Jerusalem within the walls. This refers to "Bnot Tz'eda," the tribes "Ali Shor." And Yosef "Ali Ayin." Now we will explain according to our way "Porat Ali Ayin." For it is written, "And Yosef will place his hand upon your eyes." Behold, the form of our forefather Yaakov is engraved under the Divine Throne, and it is the form that the Holy One, blessed be He, created in the world. And concerning this it is written, "And he saw... all that He made, and behold, it was very good." This form, which is called the "Eye of Yaakov," is certainly eternal in the entirety of the Children of Israel, as it is said, "All who see them will recognize them." However, the world is not worthy of this eye being revealed among the wicked. And when the Children of Israel would gather together in the Holy Temple and separate themselves from the nations, this form would rest upon them, and this is during the three pilgrimage festivals when "All your males shall appear." And these buildings in the Mishkan and the Holy Temple were walls that the Children of Israel established to create a distinction between them. Then, when they separate and gather, they have a connection to the form of Yaakov. Therefore it is said, "Gather and I will tell..." and this is true forever when they can gather properly, as mentioned elsewhere regarding this. Indeed, the strength of Yosef the Righteous was that the evil eye did not rule over him, as our sages have said in the section "Vayidgu" for the majority. Therefore, he could receive the illumination of holiness even while among the wicked. And thus he was the one who prepared a place in Egypt for the Children of Israel. And Yaakov, our forefather, feared to go down to Egypt lest an evil eye should rule over that form, and the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "And Yosef will place his hand..." Therefore it is said "Porat Ali Ayin." And these are two types of service. The tribes prepared counsel to create walls that separate. And Yosef prepared a place to blind the eyes of the wicked so that they could look and prevent the light from the righteous. And on Shabbat, a semblance of the blessing of Yosef is fulfilled, as the Holy One, blessed be He, spreads a shelter of peace over us. Therefore our sages said that the radiance of a person's face on Shabbat is not like that of the weekdays. By having protection, the aspect of the "Eye of Yaakov" rests upon the Children of Israel, as mentioned. And this is the additional soul on Shabbat, as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's purity and his ability to maintain a divine connection even amidst the wicked, symbolized by the "eye of Jacob." It emphasizes the importance of the Jewish people's unity and separation from the nations, particularly during their gatherings in the Temple, which allows them to access this divine form. Joseph's role in preparing a place for the Israelites in Egypt is highlighted, as he shields them from negative influences, while the concept of Shabbat is presented as a time when the divine light and protection are especially present, granting the Jewish people an elevated spiritual state.

passage_content: במדרש למה פרשה זו סתומה שנסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל ד"א שביקש לגלות הקץ ונסתם ממנו. הגם כי לא הי' השיעבוד בימי השבטים. אבל מקודם הרגישו הגלות בפנימיות בעבודת הש"י שזה העין והלב בחי' תש"ר ותש"י. כמ"ש במ"א שהוא בחי' יוסף ויהודה. ותש"י הוא התקשרות הגוף להש"י נגד הלב. ותש"ר התקשרות מן המוח שהוא בחי' הנשמות. וזה עצמו פי' האספו הקבצו. ובוודאי אם הי' להם התאספות והקיבוץ כראוי הי' מגלה להם הקץ. ופי' הקץ כמ"ש אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים. כי השבטים הם ההארות שמתפשטין מבחי' האבות עד סוף כל הדורות. וכ' ויקרא יעקב א"ב. קריאה הוא התמנות. כמ"ש במדרשים ישראל מקוראי. כי השבטים הם תקרות העולם. ד' דגלים. י"ב גבולי אלכסון. וסידר אותם יעקב אבינו כ"א על מקומו והתאחדו בהם כל הדורות. ועליהם נאמר גבורי כח עושי דברו. כמ"ש וזאת אשר דיבר להם. כי הם בעשי'. ושורש האבות הוא גבוה מכל העשי'. כמ"ש הן הן המרכבה. והוא בחי' אור תורה. והשבטים הם בחי' נר מצוה שהם התפשטות הארת התורה בכלים. שהם תרי"ג מצות. וכ"כ ויכל יעקב לצוות את בניו ויאסוף רגליו כו'. פי' שהדביק אותם אליו כמו שמדליקין הנרות באור והניח כוחו בהם:
translation: In the Midrash, why is this section closed? Because the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed. Another explanation is that he sought to reveal the end, but it was concealed from him. Although there was no servitude in the days of the tribes, they felt the exile internally in their service of the Blessed One, which is the eye and heart in the aspect of Tash"r and Tash"y. As mentioned elsewhere, this is in the aspect of Yosef and Yehuda. Tash"y is the connection of the body to the Blessed One against the heart. Tash"r is the connection from the brain, which is the aspect of the souls. This itself explains the gathering, the assembly. Certainly, if they had gathered and assembled properly, the end would have been revealed to them. And the end is explained as it is written, "which will call you in the latter days." For the tribes are the illuminations that spread from the aspect of the patriarchs until the end of all generations. And it is written, "And Jacob called his sons." Calling is an appointment, as it is said in the Midrash, "Israel is called." For the tribes are the pillars of the world: four banners, twelve diagonal boundaries. And Jacob our father arranged them, each in its place, and all generations united in them. Upon them it is said, "Mighty in strength, doing His word," as it is written, "And this is what He spoke to them." For they are in action. And the root of the patriarchs is higher than all actions, as it is said, "Behold, they are the chariot." And it is in the aspect of the light of the Torah. And the tribes are in the aspect of the candle of the commandment, which is the spreading of the illumination of the Torah in vessels, which are the 613 commandments. And it is also written, "And Jacob was able to command his sons, and he gathered his feet," meaning that he adhered them to himself, as one lights the candles with light and placed his strength within them.
summary: The passage discusses the hidden nature of the end of days, emphasizing that the spiritual blindness of the Israelites prevented the revelation of the ultimate redemption. It highlights the connection between the tribes, representing the divine attributes and the continuity of Jewish tradition, and the importance of unity among them to access deeper spiritual insights. The tribes are seen as vessels for the light of the Torah, with Jacob's gathering of his sons symbolizing the transmission of divine wisdom and the fulfillment of the commandments. Ultimately, the text underscores the significance of collective spiritual engagement in revealing the divine purpose in history.

passage_content: במדרש הרועה אותי כו' הגואל אותי הקיש גאולה לפרנסה מה פרנסה בכל יום כו'. פרנסה אינו בגוף בלבד כי גם התחדשות הנפשות בכל יום הוא בכלל פרנסה כמ"ש המחדש בטובו בכל יום מ"ב. וגאולה ג"כ בכל יום שיש בכל יום הארת הגאולה בפרט הגלות שיש בכל זמן איזה הסתר לכל עובד ה' כמ"ש יצרו מתגבר עליו בכ"י ומול זה יש גאולה ג"כ בכל יום כמ"ש גואל ישראל בתפלה לשון הוה. אם כי אינו גאולה שלימה מ"מ נמצא הארת הגאולה בכל יום. והקדים פרנסה לגאולה כמו שהקדים אפרים למנשה כי שם מנשה כי נשני אלקים כל עמלי הוא בחי' גאולה. ואפרים ע"ש הפרני היא פרנסה. ושמעתי מפי מו"ז ז"ל כי ב' ענינים אלי הם סור מרע ועשה טוב ויוסף הי' דרכו להיות מקודם סור מרע. ויעקב אע"ה תיקן שיתן השי"ת פתיחת הלב לתורה הגם שאין מתוקנים כראוי ועי"ז ההארה נוכל אח"כ להיות סור מרע כו'. וזה ענין הקדמת הפרנסה לגאולה כמ"ש:
translation: In the Midrash, "He shepherds me," etc., "He redeems me," the connection between redemption and sustenance is made: just as sustenance is every day, etc. Sustenance is not only physical; the renewal of souls every day is also included in sustenance, as it is said, "He renews in His goodness every day, continually." And redemption is also every day, as there is a light of redemption every day, particularly in the exile, where there is some concealment for every servant of God, as it is said, "His inclination overcomes him," and against this, there is also redemption every day, as it is said, "Redeemer of Israel" in prayer, in the present tense. Although it is not complete redemption, nonetheless, the light of redemption is found every day. And sustenance is mentioned before redemption, just as Ephraim was mentioned before Manasseh, for there Manasseh is named because "God has made me forget all my toil," which is a form of redemption. And Ephraim is named for "I have been fruitful," which is sustenance. And I heard from my revered teacher, may his memory be blessed, that there are two matters: "Turn away from evil and do good," and Joseph's way was to first turn away from evil. And Jacob, our father, may peace be upon him, rectified that the Holy One, blessed be He, should grant the opening of the heart to the Torah, even though they are not properly rectified, and through this illumination, we can then turn away from evil, etc. This is the matter of the precedence of sustenance to redemption, as it is said.
summary: The passage emphasizes the connection between redemption (geulah) and sustenance (parnassah), suggesting that both are essential aspects of daily life and spiritual renewal. It highlights that sustenance is not merely physical but also includes the renewal of souls each day, reflecting God's continuous creation. The text further explains that while complete redemption may not be realized daily, there is always a glimmer of redemption present. Additionally, it draws a parallel between the biblical figures of Ephraim and Menashe, illustrating the importance of prioritizing sustenance before redemption in the spiritual journey.

passage_content: בפסוק שמעון ולוי אחים בסודם א"ת נפשי. פרש"י כשנתקבצו שבטו של שמעון ואמרו למרע"ה בת יתרו מי התיר לך כו'. ולמה הוצרך רש"י לפרסם דיבורם לגנות ח"ו. אבל מאחר שנק' סוד א"כ לא היו באים בעזות פנים כרשעים ח"ו. רק שהיו רוצים לקרב כוחות הסט"א להקדושה ורצו ג"כ לעשות כמעשה מרע"ה אבל לא כל הרוצה ליטול השם יבוא ויטול. ובאמת הי' לשבטים אלו כח גבורה והיו יכולין להעלות הכל להקדושה. וז"ש אחים כמ"ש אחות לנו קטנה דרשו חז"ל מלשון איחוי ודביקות ע"ש פ' לך לך. אך כח זה צריך להיות מתוך כלל ישראל. לכן אמר אחלקם ביעקב ואפיצם בישראל. ונשאר זה הכח לשבט לוי ומרע"ה שהי' רבן של כל ישראל. ואפשר ג"כ כי ע"י מכירת יוסף לא עלתה בידם לתקן זה הסוד כראוי לכן כ' כי באפם הרגו כו'. ובוודאי גם דברים אלו הי' ברכות כמ"ש ויברך אותם לכל השבטים וכ' איש אשר כברכתו שסידר להם כ"א הברכה כפי השייך לו. ולכן מסר כח שמעון ולוי לכלל ישראל כמ"ש:
translation: In the verse "Shimon and Levi are brothers; instruments of violence are their swords," Rashi explains that when the tribe of Shimon gathered and said to Moshe, the son of Yitro, "Who permitted you...?" And why did Rashi need to publicize their words to condemn them, Heaven forbid? However, since it is called a secret, they would not come with brazen faces like wicked ones, Heaven forbid. Rather, they wanted to draw the forces of the Other Side to holiness and also wanted to act like Moshe, but not everyone who wishes to take the name may come and take it. In truth, these tribes had the strength of might and could elevate everything to holiness. This is what is meant by "brothers," as it is said, "We have a little sister," which our Sages interpreted as a term of healing and attachment, as mentioned in the portion of Lech Lecha. However, this strength must come from the entirety of Israel. Therefore, it is said, "I will divide them in Jacob and scatter them in Israel." This strength remained with the tribe of Levi and Moshe, who was the teacher of all Israel. It is also possible that due to the sale of Yosef, they were not able to rectify this secret properly; therefore, it is written, "For in their anger they killed..." And certainly, these words were also blessings, as it is said, "And he blessed them, each one according to his blessing," meaning he arranged for each one the blessing appropriate to him. Therefore, he transmitted the strength of Shimon and Levi to the entirety of Israel, as it is said.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the tribes of Simeon and Levi, emphasizing their potential to elevate the forces of impurity to holiness through unity and strength. It highlights the importance of collective action within the Jewish people, as their power must be rooted in the broader community. The text also reflects on the consequences of their actions, particularly in relation to the sale of Joseph, suggesting that their failure to properly rectify the spiritual "sod" (mystery) led to negative outcomes. Ultimately, the blessings given to each tribe are seen as tailored to their unique strengths and roles within the collective of Israel.

passage_content: בפסוק בן פורת יוסף כו' עלי עין כו' ברכות אביך גברו כו'. אמו"ז ז"ל הגיד כי הוא ברכת השבת כמ"ש חז"ל והאכלתיך נחלת יעקב נחלה בלי מצרים כו'. ולבאר הענין כי האבות והשבטים הם עמודי העולם. וכ' בהבראם באברהם. וכמו כן השבטים הם הי"ב גבולים כמ"ש יצב גבולות עמים למב"י. והם בחי' ו' ימי המעשה. ימים ולילות. ערב ובקר. כמ"ש ששת ימים עשה ה' השמים והארץ. והאבות הם בחי' השבת יומא דנשמתין ולאו דגופא. אכן בחי' יעקב הוא כח נוסף בחי' נשמה יתירה שהיא למעלה מכל הבריאה. וכמ"ש גברו על ברכות הורי. והוא מתעורר בכוחו של יוסף לכן כתי' ברכות אביך ולא ברכתי. וזהו מוסף שבת כמ"ש תמידין כסדרן מוספים כהלכתן. כי התמידים יש להם סדר מסודר. ובשבתות וי"ט יש מוסף שהוא שינוי שלא בהדרגה ולמעלה מן הטבע. לכן איתא שבת הוא מעין עוה"ב. והארה זו א"י להיות בעוה"ז בקביעות רק לפעמים יש התגלות לפי שעה. וזה מנוחה ונחלה דרשו חז"ל מנוחה זו שילה נחלה ירושלים. כי ירושלים היא בחי' יהודה ודהע"ה שהיא בנין קבוע כמ"ש ירושלים בין הגוים שמתי'. והיא חומה המבדלת בין ישראל לעמים. אכן בחי' משכן שילה הוא מקום שאין התנגדות האומות מגיע שם כלל וזהו בחי' השבת שנקרא מנוחה. וכ' ביוסף עלי עין שהוא למעלה מבחי' יצב גבולות עמים שאין מגע נכרי שם כלל לכן נק' מנוחה. לכן לא הי' בקביעות רק לפי שעה כנ"ל:
translation: In the verse "Ben Porat Yosef" etc., "Above the eye" etc., "The blessings of your father have prevailed" etc. Our teacher, may his memory be blessed, explained that this is the blessing of the Sabbath, as our sages have said, "And I will feed you with the inheritance of Jacob, an inheritance without limits" etc. To clarify the matter, the patriarchs and the tribes are the pillars of the world. It is written, "In their creation, in Abraham." Likewise, the tribes are the twelve boundaries, as it is said, "He set the boundaries of the nations for the number of the children of Israel." They represent the six days of creation, days and nights, evening and morning, as it is written, "For in six days the Lord made the heavens and the earth." The patriarchs represent the Sabbath, the day of the soul and not of the body. However, the aspect of Jacob is an additional power, a higher soul that is above all creation. As it is written, "They prevailed over the blessings of my parents." He is awakened by the power of Joseph; therefore, it is written "the blessings of your father" and not "I blessed." This is the additional offering of the Sabbath, as it is said, "The daily offerings in their order, the additional offerings according to their law." For the daily offerings have an orderly arrangement. On Sabbaths and festivals, there is an additional offering, which is a change that is not gradual and is above nature. Therefore, it is stated that the Sabbath is a taste of the World to Come. This illumination cannot be present in this world consistently, only at times is there a revelation for a moment. This is rest and inheritance, as our sages have interpreted, "This rest is Shiloh, the inheritance of Jerusalem." For Jerusalem is the aspect of Judah, and may it be built, which is a permanent structure, as it is written, "I have set Jerusalem among the nations." It is a wall that separates between Israel and the nations. However, the aspect of the Tabernacle in Shiloh is a place where the opposition of the nations does not reach at all, and this is the aspect of the Sabbath, which is called rest. It is written about Joseph, "Above the eye," which is above the aspect of "He set the boundaries of the nations," where there is no foreign contact at all; therefore, it is called rest. Thus, it was not consistent but only for a moment, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the blessings associated with Joseph, highlighting the connection between the patriarchs and the concept of the Sabbath as a spiritual realm beyond the physical world. It emphasizes that the patriarchs and tribes serve as foundational pillars of creation, with Jacob representing an elevated spiritual state. The text contrasts the structured nature of the weekdays with the transcendent quality of the Sabbath, which is seen as a foretaste of the World to Come, and notes that true divine rest and revelation can only be experienced intermittently in this world. Ultimately, it portrays Jerusalem and Shiloh as embodiments of this divine rest, free from external opposition, reflecting the essence of spiritual tranquility.

passage_content: עוד לפ' הנ"ל. בענין שילה שנאכל קדשים בכל הרואה ובירושלים לפנים מן החומה. דאיתא אפי' מחיצה של ברזל אינה מפסקת בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים. והוא בחי' בנים שיש לבנ"י מדריגת בנים ושם אין מגע נכרי כלל ולכן א"צ מחיצה להבדיל ביניהם כשמתגלה זו ההארה שע"ז אמרו בנ"י עלו במחשבה והיא בחי' התורה שהתחיל מיעקב אבינו ע"ה ועליו נאמר ברכות אביך גברו כו' תאות גבעות עולם שהיא בחי' מקדם. למעלה מן הטבע. ובשבת מתגלה הארה זו. לכן נק' מנוחה. נחלה בלי מצרים. אכן באמת בנ"י נבראו בעוה"ז לברר מלכותו ית' גם בעולם הטבע. וזה הי' בנין בהמ"ק ולכן הי' צריך מחיצה והבדל להיות השראת השכינה אפי' בעוה"ז. כמ"ש עדות היא שהשכינה שורה בישראל. וזה הי' בחי' יהודה והשבטים בחי' עבדי אלקי אביך. והיא בחי' ימי המעשה. ואמת כי קדמה משכן שילה שמקודם היו צריכין בנ"י לקשר עצמם בבחי' בנים. והשאיר להם ברכה להמשיך הקדושה גם בבחי' עבדים. וכמו שהשבת נותן ברכה על ימי המעשה. וירושלים נק' נחלה כמ"ש ז"ל פי' נחלה בלי הפסק היינו כח בהמ"ק שההארה מצוי' גם בעולם הטבע:
translation: Further to the above. Regarding Shiloh, where holy things were eaten by all who saw, and in Jerusalem, within the wall. For it is stated that even a barrier of iron does not separate between Israel and their Father in Heaven. This is in the aspect of children, as the Jewish people have the level of children, and there is no contact with the foreigner at all there; therefore, there is no need for a partition to distinguish between them when this illumination is revealed. Concerning this, it is said that the Jewish people ascended in thought, and this is the aspect of the Torah that began with our forefather Jacob, peace be upon him, and upon him it is said, "The blessings of your father have prevailed," etc., the desire of the hills of the world, which is in the aspect of the primordial. Above nature. And on Shabbat, this illumination is revealed. Therefore, it is called rest, an inheritance without measure. Indeed, the Jewish people were created in this world to clarify His sovereignty, even in the world of nature. This was the construction of the Holy Temple, and therefore a partition and distinction were necessary for the resting of the Shechinah even in this world, as it is said, "It is a testimony that the Shechinah dwells in Israel." This was in the aspect of Judah and the tribes, in the aspect of "servants of the God of your father." And it is in the aspect of the days of action. And it is true that the Mishkan in Shiloh preceded, for beforehand the Jewish people needed to connect themselves in the aspect of children. And He left them a blessing to continue the holiness also in the aspect of servants. Just as Shabbat gives a blessing to the days of action. And Jerusalem is called an inheritance, as our sages explained, meaning an inheritance without interruption, that is, like the Holy Temple, where the illumination is present even in the world of nature.
summary: The passage discusses the unique relationship between the Jewish people and God, emphasizing that even a barrier of iron cannot separate them from their divine Father, reflecting their status as children of God. It highlights the spiritual elevation experienced in Jerusalem and Shiloh, where the divine presence is felt without separation, particularly on Shabbat, which represents a state of rest and connection to the divine. The text also underscores the necessity of the Temple as a means to manifest God's sovereignty in the physical world, illustrating the dual role of the Jewish people as both children and servants of God, tasked with bringing holiness into the mundane. Ultimately, it conveys that the divine light is accessible even within the natural order, particularly through the sanctity of Jerusalem and the Temple.

passage_content: בפסוק האספו ואגידה. הקבצו ושמעו בנ"י ושמעו אל ישראל. ואז"ל ביקש לגלות להם הקץ. משמע שהכל תלוי כפי האסיפה שיכולין בנ"י לבוא אל האחדות. וכן שמעתי מפי מו"ז ז"ל כי כפי הכנסי' לש"ש כך יכולין לשמוע. ובאמת בזה תלוי הגאולה כמ"ש היום אם בקולו תשמעו. ולכן שבת קודש דבי' מתאחדין ברזא דאחד יכולין לשמוע דבר ה' והוא מפתח של הגאולה. ואיתא בירושלמי תענית אם משמרין בנ"י שבת אחד נגאלין דכ' היום א"ב תשמעו וכ' אכלוהו היום כי שבת היום כו'. והוא כנ"ל שהשבת מוכן לשמיעה זו. דהנה בשבת ניתנה תורה לכן השבת מסייע לבנ"י ע"י שמבטלין כל המעשים בש"ק ומוכנים לקבל דבר ה'. ולכן ניתקן לכו נרננה בכניסת שבת היום אם בקולו תשמעו. וכ' ג"פ היום שיש שמיעה אחר שמיעה כמ"ש ואגידה כו' וכ' שמעו כו' ושמעו. כמ"ש אם שמוע תשמעון. שמקודם יש כינוס כדי לשמוע כי הקיבוץ ג"כ בכלל שמיעה כדכ' וישמע שאול את העם. ואח"כ היא השמיעה. וכ' שמעי בת וראי והטי אזנך שהיא שמיעה פנימיות להיות בטל כל כח השמיעה לדבר הנשמע. וזה תשמעון כמ"ש והטי אזנך. והג' סעודות של שבת מסייעין לאלה ג' השמיעות והוא מפתח של הגאולה כנ"ל:
translation: In the verse "Gather and I will tell," gather and listen, O children of Israel. Our sages have said that He sought to reveal to them the end. This implies that everything depends on the gathering, through which the children of Israel can come to unity. Likewise, I heard from my revered teacher, may his memory be blessed, that according to the gathering to the Holy Name, so too can they hear. Indeed, the redemption depends on this, as it is written, "Today, if you will listen to His voice." Therefore, on the holy Sabbath, they unite in the secret of the One, and they can hear the word of God, which is the key to redemption. And it is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud, Taanit, that if the children of Israel observe one Sabbath, they will be redeemed, as it is written, "Today, if you will listen," and it is written, "Eat it today, for today is the Sabbath." This is as mentioned above, that the Sabbath is prepared for this hearing. For on the Sabbath, the Torah was given; therefore, the Sabbath assists the children of Israel by nullifying all actions on the Sabbath and preparing to receive the word of God. And thus it is established, "Come, let us sing joyfully at the entrance of the Sabbath, today, if you will listen to His voice." And it is written multiple times "today," indicating that there is hearing after hearing, as it is written, "And I will tell," and it is written, "Listen," and "Listen." As it is said, "If you will listen, you will listen." First, there is a gathering in order to hear, for the gathering is also included in hearing, as it is written, "And Saul heard the people." And afterwards, there is the hearing. And it is written, "Listen, O daughter, and see, and incline your ear," which is an inner hearing, to nullify all the power of hearing to the spoken word. This is "you will listen," as it is written, "and incline your ear." And the three meals of the Sabbath assist these three hearings, and this is the key to redemption, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of unity among the Jewish people as a prerequisite for receiving divine revelation and achieving redemption. It highlights that the collective gathering and listening, particularly on Shabbat, are essential for spiritual elevation and connection to God. The act of coming together on Shabbat facilitates a readiness to hear God's word, which is linked to the potential for redemption. The three meals of Shabbat are seen as instrumental in fostering this deep listening and unity, serving as a key to the ultimate redemption.

passage_content: במדרש ויברך את יוסף כו' הקיש גאולה לפרנסה ופרנסה לגאולה מה גאולה פלאים כו' ע"ש כל המדרש קשה פרנסה מלידה כו' בעצב כו' ובפרנסה כ' בעצבון. הענין הוא כי צריכין לידע ולהבין כמו שנראה נפלאות הש"י כשמשנה הטבע ע"פ נס שהוא פלאים לעיני ב"ו בעלמא דשיקרא. אבל באמת הנהגת הטבע הוא פלא יותר מה שצימצם הקב"ה כח השפע שלו שהוא רוחניי ומתלבש ומתצמצם בגשמיות הוא פלא והפלא ביותר. וז"ש כך פרנסה פלאים. ובאמת קודם החטא הי' מקבלין השפע וכל ההנהגה ברוחניות. אך אחר החטא שנתערב טוב ורע צריך להיות הקבלה ע"י צימצום וגשמיות. והוא עיקר העצבון מאחר שבא ע"י הסתר בתוך הטבע. לכן פרנסה יותר עצבון מלידה כי בלידה הנשמה הנולדת היא דבוק ברוחניות רק שמשתתף בו חלק אב ואם בגשמיות. ובפרנסה מתלבש יותר בטבע ועבודה בשדה לכן כתיב בי' בעצבון. ובאמת זה עצמו ענין סמיכת גאולה לתפלה. זה ההיקש גאולה לפרנסה. כי פרנסה אינו דוקא מזונות. רק כל הצטרכות והבקשות שבי"ב ברכות אמצעיות שבתפלה הם פרנסה. וצריכין לסמוך תפלה לגאולה לברר כי כל אותן ההנהגות נמשכין מלמעלה מן הטבע ושם הם רוחניות. ובאמת כל אלה ההסתרות נעשו ע"י החטא לכן כשיש גאולה כמ"ש הגואל אותי מכל רע וכשנתברר הטוב מן הרע זוכין לקבל ההנהגה העליונה. וכמו כן בש"ק שנק' טוב ואין בו תערובת רע והיא בחי' יוסף הצדיק מקבלין השפע ברוחניות. וזה הי' עיקר הברכה שכ' ויברך את יוסף שיהי' התקשרות כל הפרנסה בשורש העליון בסמיכות גאולה לפרנסה כנ"ל. דאיתא חיי בני מזוני במזלא תליא מילתא. ומזלא אינו הטבע רק שורש העליון. לכן אמרו תליא כדאיתא על ש"ק כל ברכאן בשביעאה תליא כמ"ש בפרשיות הקודמין בזה. וכן צריכין לסמוך ולבטל ולחבר כל ימי המעשה אל השבת והוא סמיכות גאולה לתפלה ג"כ. לכן בשבת שמחה ועונג שאין בו עצבון. וחז"ל רמזו מרבה נכסים מרבה דאגה שזה עיקר העצבון מה שעוסקין ביותר בפעולות גשמיות וכל עבודה בשדה שפרנסה הבאה בדרכים אלו מביאין העצבון. אבל האי דסמיך גאולה לתפלה אמרו עליו דלא פסיק חוכא מפומי' כל יומא. שזה עיקר השמחה כשמקבלין השפע בלי צמצומים ולבושים גשמיים כנ"ל:
translation: In the Midrash, "And he blessed Joseph," it connects redemption to sustenance and sustenance to redemption. Just as redemption is miraculous, etc., as stated in the entire Midrash, sustenance is difficult from birth, etc., in sorrow, etc., and in sustenance it is written "in sorrow." The matter is that we need to know and understand that just as we see the wonders of the Blessed One when He alters nature through a miracle, which is a wonder in the eyes of man in a world of falsehood. But in truth, the governance of nature is a greater wonder, as the Holy One, blessed be He, has contracted His flow of abundance, which is spiritual, and it is clothed and contracted in physicality; this is a wonder, and the greatest wonder. And this is what is meant by "sustenance of wonders." In truth, before the sin, they would receive the abundance and all governance in spirituality. However, after the sin, when good and evil became mixed, the reception must be through contraction and physicality. This is the essence of sorrow, as it comes through concealment within nature. Therefore, sustenance is more sorrowful than birth, because at birth the soul that is born is attached to spirituality, only that it participates with a part of the father and mother in physicality. And in sustenance, it is more clothed in nature and work in the field; therefore, it is written about it "in sorrow." And indeed, this itself is the matter of connecting redemption to prayer. This is the connection of redemption to sustenance, for sustenance is not only food. Rather, all needs and requests that are in the twelve intermediate blessings of prayer are sustenance. And we need to connect prayer to redemption to clarify that all those governances are drawn from above nature, and there they are spiritual. And indeed, all these concealments were caused by the sin; therefore, when there is redemption, as it is said, "the Redeemer who saves me from all evil," and when the good is clarified from the evil, we merit to receive the higher governance. And likewise on Shabbat, which is called good and has no mixture of evil, and it is in the aspect of Joseph the Righteous, we receive the abundance in spirituality. And this was the essence of the blessing that is written, "And he blessed Joseph," that all sustenance should be connected to the upper root in the connection of redemption to sustenance, as mentioned above. It is stated, "The life of the children depends on sustenance," and sustenance is not nature but the upper root. Therefore, they said it depends, as it is stated about Shabbat, "All blessings depend on the seventh," as mentioned in the previous sections regarding this. And so we need to connect, nullify, and unite all the days of work to Shabbat, and this is also the connection of redemption to prayer. Therefore, on Shabbat there is joy and delight without sorrow. And our Sages hinted that "the more possessions, the more worries," which is the essence of sorrow, as those who are most engaged in physical actions and all work in the field, the sustenance that comes through these ways brings sorrow. But the one who connects redemption to prayer, it is said about him that "laughter does not cease from his mouth every day." This is the essence of joy when we receive the abundance without contractions and physical garments, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between redemption (geulah) and sustenance (parnasa), emphasizing that true sustenance is a spiritual phenomenon that has become obscured by the physical world due to sin. It highlights that while miraculous interventions reveal God's wonders, the natural order, where divine abundance is constrained within physicality, is an even greater miracle. The text asserts that genuine sustenance should be linked to spiritual sources, and that the ultimate redemption allows for a return to a higher, untainted state of existence, free from the sorrow associated with material struggles. The relationship between prayer and redemption is underscored, suggesting that true joy and fulfillment come from receiving divine blessings without the limitations of the physical realm.

passage_content: וזהו ענין הפסוק שיכל את ידיו כי מנשה הבכור ומתרגמינן אחכמינון לידוהי. והוא כדכ' שאו ידיכם קודש. וזה ענין נשיאת כפים בברכה כמ"ש וישא אהרן א"י. כי הידים הם המקבלים וכלי נק' יד. אבל עיקר הברכה כשמעלין הכל אל השורש. ובוודאי גם יוסף ראה והבין כי מנשה יש לו קדימה אבל ברכת יעקב אע"ה הי' בעולם שלמעלה מזה ושם יש לאפרים קדימה. והרמז כשנושאין כפים נעשה עליונים למטה ותחתונים למעלה וע"י ששיכל את ידיו הקדים אפרים. [וכזה נמצא בגמ' בברי' דריב"ל שראה עליונים למטה ותחתונים למעלה ואמר עולם הפוך ראיתי והשיב לו בני עולם ברור ראית] כי באותו מדרגה שלמעלה יש לאפרים קדימה. ועמ"ש לקמן בפ' נשא מזה:
translation: And this is the matter of the verse "he crossed his hands" because Manasseh is the firstborn, and we translate it "he made them known to his hands." And it is as it is written, "Lift up your hands in holiness." This is the matter of the lifting of the hands in blessing, as it is said, "And Aaron lifted his hands." For the hands are the receivers, and a vessel is called a hand. But the essence of the blessing is when everything is elevated to the root. And certainly, Joseph saw and understood that Manasseh has precedence, but the blessing of Jacob our father was in a world above this, and there Ephraim has precedence. The hint is that when the hands are lifted, the upper ones are made lower and the lower ones are made higher, and by his crossing his hands, Ephraim was given precedence. [And thus it is found in the Gemara in the teaching of Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai, who saw the upper ones below and the lower ones above and said, "I have seen a world turned upside down," and they replied to him, "Son, you have seen a clear world."] For in that level above, Ephraim has precedence. And as I will explain further on in Parshat Naso regarding this.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the blessing given by Jacob to his grandsons, Ephraim and Manasseh, highlighting the concept of spiritual precedence. It emphasizes that while Manasseh is the firstborn, the higher spiritual realm grants Ephraim precedence in the blessing, symbolized by the act of raising hands during the priestly blessing. This act reflects the elevation of the lower realms to the higher, illustrating the interconnectedness of the spiritual and physical worlds. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that true blessing comes from aligning with the divine source, where the higher spiritual order determines precedence.

passage_content: בפסוק וברצונם עקרו שור פרש"י רצו לעקור. וי"ל כפשוטו ג"כ כי באמת הלכה כרבים וכיון שלא היו השבטים יכולים לדברו לשלום נתעקר מתוכם. אך כי נתעלה במדריגה שלמעלה מהם כידוע. ונשאר הנהגה למטה לפי דרכיהם. וזה לשון עקרו שור. ועיין בזוה"ק בענין רבות בנות כו' ואת עלית ע"כ. [ועי"ז נתעלה מבחי' שור ובהמה לבחי' אדם. ומקום שלו ניתן למנשה ואפרים. ויש לכוין זה בברכת מרע"ה שאמר בכור שורו כו' והם רבבות אפרים וה"א מנשה. ואולי שזה הי' סיבה אח"כ לחטא העגל שעי"ז נשתנה שור לכרוב אלא שאין לי עסק בנסתרות]. וז"ש אתם חשבתם כו' אלקים חשבה לטובה:
translation: In the verse "And in their desire they uprooted an ox," Rashi explains that they wanted to uproot. It can also be understood literally, for indeed the halacha follows the majority, and since the tribes were unable to speak to him in peace, he was uprooted from among them. However, he was elevated to a level above them, as is known. And he remained a leadership below according to their ways. This is the meaning of "they uprooted an ox." And see in the Zohar regarding the matter of "Many daughters have done well... but you have surpassed them all." [And through this, he was elevated from the level of an ox and beast to the level of a man. His place was given to Manasseh and Ephraim. This can be connected to the blessing of Moshe Rabbeinu, who said, "His firstborn ox..." and they are the myriads of Ephraim and the letter "He" for Manasseh. And perhaps this was the reason later for the sin of the golden calf, whereby the ox was changed to a cherub, but I have no business in the hidden matters.] This is what is meant by "You thought... but God thought for good."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual elevation and transformation, highlighting how the tribes of Israel, unable to reconcile peacefully, led to a divine shift where the essence of "שור" (ox) was elevated to a higher state of "אדם" (man). This transformation allowed for the leadership roles of Menashe and Ephraim to emerge, reflecting a deeper connection to divine purpose. The text also suggests that human intentions, even when flawed, can ultimately align with God's benevolent plans, as indicated by the phrase "אלקים חשבה לטובה."
