passage_content: בפסוק בן פורת פרש"י לשון חן. והוא כמ"ש כשהצדיק בעיר הוא הודה זיוה הדרה. והוא הזיו והיופי שנמצא בכלל ישראל ע"י שעמך כולם צדיקים כו' מעשה ידי להתפאר. והוא המציאות חן שיש לכנס"י דכ' הראיני את מראיך השמיעיני את קולך. והם ב' אלו המיוחדים שבט יהודה ויוסף. קולך ערב הוא יהודה ודוד נעים זמירות ישראל וכ' שמע ה' קול יהודה. ולו ניתן המלכות שהוא בחי' לב. עבודה שבלב. ומראיך נאוה הוא בחי' יוסף הצדיק והוא עין טובה שב' אלו הם העיקר עין טוב ולב טוב. והם בחי' זכור ושמור. וכ' עין טוב הוא יבורך והוא כלי מחזיק ברכה [ובתפלה ברכת שמע קולינו הוא בחי' יהודה ודוד. ושים שלום הוא בחי' יוסף הצדיק] והוא נועם הש"י אשר פורס סוכת שלום עלינו. וע"ז מבקשין ישדר לן שופרי'. לכן עיקר הברכה ניתן ליוסף כמ"ש ברכות אביך גברו כו':
translation: In the verse "Ben Porat," Rashi explains it as a language of grace. This is as it is said, when the righteous are in the city, he is acknowledged for his radiance and splendor. This is the radiance and beauty found among the people of Israel because your people are all righteous, etc., the work of My hands to be glorified. This is the essence of grace that the Congregation of Israel possesses, as it is written, "Show me Your appearance, let me hear Your voice." These are the two special ones, the tribes of Judah and Joseph. "Your voice is pleasant" refers to Judah, and "David is pleasant in songs of Israel," as it is written, "Hear, O Lord, the voice of Judah." To him was given the kingship, which is the aspect of the heart, the service of the heart. "Your appearance is beautiful" refers to Joseph the righteous, and he is the good eye. These two are the essence of a good eye and a good heart. They correspond to the aspects of "remember" and "guard." It is written, "A good eye will be blessed," and it is a vessel that holds blessing. [And in prayer, the blessing "Hear our voice" corresponds to Judah and David, and "Grant peace" corresponds to Joseph the righteous.] This is the pleasantness of the Holy One, Blessed be He, who spreads a shelter of peace over us. For this, we request that the shofars be sounded for us. Therefore, the essence of the blessing is given to Joseph, as it is said, "The blessings of your father have surpassed..."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "חן" (grace) as it relates to the righteous within Israel, emphasizing the beauty and glory that emanate from their presence. It highlights the dual aspects of Judah and Joseph, representing the heart's devotion and the eye's benevolence, respectively, which are essential for spiritual elevation. The text connects these attributes to the blessings of unity and peace, illustrating how the righteous embody divine qualities that bring about harmony in the community. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of these traits in receiving blessings and fostering a connection with the Divine.

passage_content: במדרש פרשה זו סתומה כו'. הענין להודיע כי גלות בנ"י אינו במקרה וכל תהלוכת בנ"י עושה רושם בתורה. הרי אמרו חז"ל באורייתא ברא קוב"ה עלמא. הביט בתורה וברא את העולם. ועיקר הבריאה הי' עבור בנ"י. א"כ הביט הקב"ה בתורה. ובפרשיותי' מתנהג כל תהלוכת בנ"י. ויש פרשה המיוחדת לגלות לכן היא סתומה. והקב"ה הכין התורה קודם שנברא העולם להיות הרפואה קודם למכה. ובוודאי יש ג"כ פרשיות המיוחדים לגלותינו עתה. וכמ"ש וענתה השירה הזאת כו' כי ידעתי את יצרו כו' בטרם אביאנו. וע"ד הרמז י"ל ידעתי לשון שבירה כמו ויודע בם אנשי סוכות. וכדאיתא בראתי יצה"ר בראתי תבלין כנגדו זו התורה. וז"ש ידעתי את יצרו בטרם אביאנו. שהקדים הרפואה קודם המכה. וזה עצמו שכ' אנכי ארד עמך כו' היא התורה אנכי ה"א והתורה משתתפת בצערן של בנ"י. וז"ש עמו אנכי בצרה כו' ובאמת ירידת יעקב אבינו למצרים היא ג"כ כנ"ל כי יעקב הוא שורש התורה:
translation: In the Midrash, this section is closed, etc. The matter is to inform that the exile of the Jewish people is not by chance, and every journey of the Jewish people makes an impression in the Torah. Thus, our Sages have said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world through the Torah. He looked into the Torah and created the world. The essence of creation was for the Jewish people. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, looked into the Torah, and in its sections, all the journeys of the Jewish people are conducted. There is a section that is specifically related to the exile, and that is why it is closed. The Holy One, Blessed be He, prepared the Torah before the world was created to be the remedy before the affliction. And certainly, there are also sections that are specific to our current exile. As it is written, "And this song shall answer for you," etc., "for I know his inclination," etc., "before I bring him." And according to the hint, it can be said that "I know" is a term of breaking, as in "and he knows them, the men of Succoth." And as it is stated, "I created the evil inclination, I created a remedy against it, this is the Torah." And this is what is meant by "I know his inclination before I bring him," that the remedy was prepared before the affliction. This itself is what is written, "I will go down with you," etc., that is the Torah, "I" is the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the Torah shares in the suffering of the Jewish people. Therefore, it is said, "I am with him in trouble," etc. And indeed, the descent of our forefather Jacob to Egypt is also as mentioned above, for Jacob is the root of the Torah.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the exile of the Jewish people is not coincidental but is intricately connected to the Torah, which was created with their journey in mind. It highlights the idea that God prepared the Torah as a remedy for the challenges faced by the Jewish people, indicating that every aspect of their experience is reflected in the sacred text. The connection between the Torah and the suffering of the Jewish people is underscored, with the assertion that God's presence accompanies them in their hardships, as exemplified by Jacob's descent into Egypt, which symbolizes the deep relationship between the Torah and the Jewish experience.

passage_content: בפסוק האספו כו'. מאחר שכ' אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית. א"כ פרשה זו הכנה עד דור האחרון. ואיתא במדרש שמע ישראל סבא. שיכול כל איש ישראל להכניס עצמו בק"ש בכלל ישראל וזה הכח שהניח לנו יעקב אבינו. ב"פ ושמעו. [ושמעו בנ"י] נגד שמע בערבית. ושמעו אל ישראל אביכם נגד שמע בשחרית:
translation: In the verse "Assemble," since it is written "who will call you at the end," this section serves as preparation for the last generation. It is stated in the Midrash "Shema Yisrael Saba" that every Jewish person can include themselves in the Shema with all of Israel, and this is the power that our forefather Jacob left us. Twice it says "and they will listen" [and they will listen, O children of Israel], corresponding to the Shema in the evening, and "and they will listen, O Israel your father," corresponding to the Shema in the morning.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of the Shema as a unifying declaration for the Jewish people, particularly in the context of the end of days. It highlights the idea that every individual Jew can connect themselves to the collective identity of Israel, a strength bequeathed by Jacob. The repetition of "שמע" in different contexts signifies the continuity of this connection through daily prayers, linking the evening and morning rituals. This reflects a deep theological insight into the enduring bond between God and the Jewish people across generations.

passage_content: בזוה"ק בפסוק מאשר שמנה לחמו לחם משנה בשבת דאית לחם עוני ולחם פנג כו' ע"ש כל הענין. משנה גימ' השמים והוא בכח הנשמה. כי האדם כולל נשמה מן השמים והגוף מן הארץ. ושבת יומא דנשמתין ולאו דגופא. ויורד הנשמה יתירה שהיא החלק מן השמים וז"ש ביני ובין בנ"י אות היא כו' ששת ימים עשה כו' השמים כו'. וכיון שבנ"י צריכין להעיד על בריאת שמים. וזה א"א רק שינתן להם חלק מן השמים. ולכן השבת אות על בנ"י שיורד להם החלק מן השמים. וכ' השמים שמים לה' והארץ נתן לבני אדם פרשנו כי הכל מן השמים רק שיורד בצימצום הארץ ואינו מתגלה הפנימיות. רק בשבת שמנה לחמו וכבר הארכתי בזה בכמה מקומות:
translation: In the Zohar on the verse "from which He made bread for the double portion on Shabbat," there is the bread of affliction and the bread of the poor, etc., as explained in the entire matter. "Double" is the gematria of the heavens, and it is in the power of the soul. For man encompasses a soul from the heavens and a body from the earth. And Shabbat is the day of the souls and not of the body. The additional soul descends, which is the part from the heavens, and this is what is said, "between Me and the children of Israel is a sign," etc., "for six days He made," etc., "the heavens," etc. And since the children of Israel need to testify about the creation of the heavens, this cannot be done unless they are given a portion from the heavens. Therefore, Shabbat is a sign for the children of Israel that the portion from the heavens descends to them. And it is written, "The heavens are the heavens for the Lord, but the earth He has given to mankind." We explained that everything is from the heavens, only that it descends in a contraction to the earth and does not reveal its inner essence. Only on Shabbat does He provide the bread of affliction, and I have elaborated on this in several places.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Shabbat as a time when the soul, a divine element from the heavens, is elevated above the physical body, which is of the earth. It emphasizes that the Jewish people receive a portion of the heavenly essence on Shabbat, symbolizing their unique role in testifying to the creation of the heavens. The concept of "bread of affliction" and "double bread" on Shabbat reflects the spiritual nourishment that connects the earthly and the divine, revealing deeper truths that are otherwise concealed during the week. Ultimately, Shabbat serves as a sign of the covenant between God and the Jewish people, highlighting their spiritual connection to the divine.

passage_content: בפסוק כרע רבץ כארי. אמר מו"ז ז"ל כי כוחו של יהודה אפי' בשעת שפלות שהוא שוכב הוא כארי ולביא שכן הי' במעשה תמר שהודה ולא בוש. ומזה נבנה המשיח. ולכן הרמז כל השם ביהודה ואות ד' להראות כי אפי' כשהוא דל ה' עמו עכ"ד. ויתכן לומר שהוא בכח ההכנעה כמ"ש בשמו ז"ל שע"ש זה נק' יהודה שממעט עצמו. ורמז ג"כ שהגם שכל השם בו הוא שפל ודל בעיניו. ע"ש. ולכן כיון שיודע שאפי' אחר כל המעלות והתרוממות שהכל מהשי"ת והוא שפל בעיניו לכן שכרו שהגם שהוא נופל ה' עמו. וזה ב' הבחי' שכ' במד' כרע שכב. כרע רבץ ע"ש. פי' שבעת תקפו הוא כורע ומכניע עצמו. ובעת שפלותו הוא ג"כ רובץ כארי. והוא באמת מדת ההשתוות שהוא בחי' גדולה מאוד להיות שוה בשעת הירידה כבשעת העלי'. [וכל בנ"י נק' יהודים על שמו שזה כוחן של בנ"י שממעטין עצמן. והשם עמהם אפי' בעת צרה ושפלות. והוא בחי' אמונה כמ"ש וצדיק באמונתו דרשו חז"ל אפי' צדיקו של עולם פי' שכפי האמונה משרה שכינתו]:
translation: In the verse "He crouched, he lay down like a lion." Our teacher, may his memory be blessed, said that the strength of Judah, even in a time of lowliness when he is lying down, is like a lion, for he was in the act of Tamar, where he acknowledged and was not ashamed. From this, the Messiah is built. Therefore, the hint is in the entire name of Judah and the letter 'D' to show that even when he is poor, the Lord is with him. Thus far the words. It can also be said that it is through the power of humility, as our teacher, may his memory be blessed, said that for this reason he is called Judah, for he diminishes himself. It also hints that although the entire name in him is lowly and poor in his eyes, therefore, since he knows that even after all the virtues and elevations, that everything is from the Holy One, blessed be He, and he is lowly in his eyes, his reward is that even when he falls, the Lord is with him. This is the two aspects written in the Midrash: "He crouched, he lay down." The meaning is that at the time of his strength, he bows and humbles himself, and at the time of his lowliness, he also lies down like a lion. And this is truly the attribute of equanimity, which is a very great quality, to be equal in a time of descent as in a time of elevation. [And all the children of Israel are called Jews in his name, for this is the strength of the children of Israel, that they diminish themselves. And the name is with them even in times of trouble and lowliness. And this is the aspect of faith, as it is said, "And the righteous shall live by his faith," our sages taught that even the righteous of the world, meaning that according to the faith, the Divine Presence rests.]
summary: The passage emphasizes the strength of Judah, symbolized as a lion, even in moments of humility and lowliness, reflecting the idea that true greatness lies in self-effacement. It highlights that despite one's perceived shortcomings, God's presence remains with them, reinforcing the concept of faith and trust in divine support during difficult times. The text also connects the name "Judah" to the quality of humility, suggesting that the Jewish people embody this trait, which allows them to maintain their connection to God even in adversity. Ultimately, it illustrates the dual nature of humility and strength, where one can be both submissive and powerful, embodying a profound level of faith.

passage_content: בברכת יוסף ברכות אביך גברו כו'. אמר מו"ז ז"ל כי היא בחי' נחלה בלי מצרים שהיא ברכת שבת כמ"ש חז"ל המענג את השבת נותנין לו נחלה בלי מצרים. וביאור המענג השבת שיש לו תענוג ממצות השבת ומניח בעבור זה כל הדאגות כשבא שבת ונח. לכן מסירין ממנו כל המצרים כנ"ל. ונ"ל שזה רמזו חז"ל מענגי' לעולם כבוד ינחלו ופי' הרוקח לעולם שהיא נחלה בלי מצרים. ולפי הנ"ל פי' מענגי' לעולם. שאפי' בעת צר לו מניח הכל ומענג השבת. ולכך כבוד ינחלו בלי מצרים. ויתכן עוד לפרש לעולם ממש כי השבת צריך להיות נשאר באדם אפי' בימי המעשה שהוא ברית עולם. וכשאדם נזכר מן השבת צריך להיות מלא עונג ושמחה כמ"ש שש אנכי על אמרתך. וכמו שהוא באות ברית קודש בגוף. כן באות השבת שאדם יש לשמוח שהוא מיוחד להעיד על הקב"ה ויש לו חלק בברית השבת וזה מענגי' לעולם. וברכת השבת היא למעלה בשורש כמ"ש בזוה"ק דלא אשתכח בי' מנא משום דכל ברכאין בשביעאה תליין כמ"ש בכמה מקומות בזה. והיא ברכת יוסף שלמעלה מברכת כל השבטים וכ' כל אלה כו' ויברך אותם איש אשר כברכתו ברך. פי' ויברך אותם בכלל. וכ' אותם מלא בוא"ו הוא בחי' יוסף פי' אות שלהם אות ברית קודש שבו שורש כל הברכות. וכמו שהוא בכל אדם כן בכלל הי' יוסף אות ברית קודש. איש כברכתו הוא בפרט כל א' וא'. והני תלתא בני חיי מזוני דלאו בזכותא תלי' רק במזלא הם בברכת יוסף. ברכות שמים חיי. ברכות תהום מזוני. שדים ורחם בני. וכ' ה' רועי לא אחסר הוא בחי' השפע היורדת בשבת שהיא מהשי"ת בעצמו שורש הברכות על מי מנוחות כו' ואינו בגשמיות. והוא נותן ברכה להתפשט אח"כ בימי המעשה בגשמיות ופרטיות. וזה תערוך לפני שולחן כו' והוא בעוה"ז נגד צוררי כי בשבת אין מגע סט"א כלל. והנה בחי' השבטים הוא ראשי חדשים כדאיתא בטור או"ח הל' ר"ח שהי' ראוי להיות ימים טובים וע"י החטא נתבטלו. לכן לעתיד יהי' יו"ט כמ"ש מדי חדש בחדשו כו'. וע"י שאלה ההארות שהי' ראוין להתגלות ע"י השבטים הם קרובים יותר לעוה"ז לכן נפגמו ע"י החטא ולעתיד יתקיים תערוך לפני שלחן נגד צוררי שיהי' התיקון אפי' בעוה"ז כמ"ש לתקן עולם במלכות שדי שהוא הנהגת הטבע שהוא כח מעשיו כו'. ולכן יש י"ב חדשים ד' תקופות. והפנימיות הוא שמות מיוחדים. ד' דגלים י"ב שבטים. וכ' מי זאת הנשקפה כו'. ואיתא במד' שד' מדריגות אלו עומדין נגד הד' מלכיות. והרמז למ"ש כי שלחן הוא ר"ת שחר לבנה חמה נדגלות והם נגד צוררי כדכ' יצב גבולות עמים למב"י:
translation:
In the blessing of Joseph, the blessings of your father have prevailed, etc. Our master, may his memory be blessed, said that this is the aspect of an inheritance without boundaries, which is the blessing of Shabbat, as our sages have said, "Whoever delights in the Shabbat, they are given an inheritance without boundaries." The explanation of delighting in the Shabbat is that one has pleasure from the commandments of Shabbat and sets aside all worries when Shabbat arrives and rests. Therefore, all constraints are removed from him, as mentioned above. And it seems to me that this is hinted at by our sages, "Those who delight in it will inherit honor," and the Rokach explained that "forever" means it is an inheritance without boundaries. According to the above, the explanation of "delighting in it forever" is that even in times of distress, one sets everything aside and delights in Shabbat. Therefore, "honor" will be inherited without boundaries. It may also be interpreted as "forever" in the literal sense, for Shabbat should remain with a person even during the weekdays, as it is a covenant of eternity. And when a person remembers Shabbat, they should be filled with delight and joy, as it is said, "I rejoice at Your word." Just as it is in the covenant of holiness in the body, so too is it in the essence of Shabbat, that a person should rejoice, for it is designated to testify about the Holy One, blessed be He, and one has a share in the covenant of Shabbat, and this is "delighting in it forever." 

And the blessing of Shabbat is above in its root, as it is written in the Zohar that blessings are not found in the tenth measure because all blessings depend on the seventh, as mentioned in several places regarding this. And it is the blessing of Joseph, which is above the blessing of all the tribes, and it is written, "And he blessed them, each one according to his blessing he blessed them." The explanation is that "he blessed them" in general. And the "them" written with a full vav is the aspect of Joseph, meaning their sign is the sign of the holy covenant, which is the root of all blessings. And just as it is in every person, so too in general, Joseph was the sign of the holy covenant. "A man according to his blessing" refers specifically to each one individually. And these three sons, life, sustenance, are not dependent on merit but rather on fortune, they are in the blessing of Joseph. Blessings from the heavens are life. Blessings from the depths are sustenance. Demons and wombs are children. And it is written, "The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want," which is the aspect of the flow that descends on Shabbat, which is from the Holy One, blessed be He, the root of blessings, upon still waters, etc., and it is not in physicality. And He gives a blessing to be spread out afterwards in the weekdays in physicality and particulars. And this prepares a table before me, etc., and it is in this world against my enemies, for on Shabbat there is no contact with the other side at all. 

And behold, the aspect of the tribes is the heads of the months, as it is stated in the Tur, Orach Chaim, regarding the laws of Rosh Chodesh, that they were meant to be festive days, and due to sin, they were nullified. Therefore, in the future, there will be a festival, as it is said, "From month to month," etc. And through the illumination that was meant to be revealed through the tribes, they are closer to this world; therefore, they were blemished through sin, and in the future, it will be fulfilled, "You prepare a table before me against my enemies," that the rectification will be even in this world, as it is said, "To rectify the world under the sovereignty of the Almighty," which is the governance of nature, which is the power of His deeds, etc. Therefore, there are twelve months and four seasons. And the inner aspect is special names. Four banners, twelve tribes. And it is written, "Who is this that looks forth," etc. And it is stated in the Midrash that these four levels stand against the four kingdoms. And the hint to what is said is that "table" is an acronym for "dawn, moon, sun, banners," and they are against my enemies, as it is written, "He set the boundaries of the nations for the sake of Israel."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "delighting in Shabbat" as a means to attain a spiritual inheritance that transcends worldly limitations, reflecting the idea that true joy in observing Shabbat allows one to rise above earthly concerns. It emphasizes that the blessings associated with Shabbat, particularly those linked to the figure of Joseph, represent a higher spiritual source that nourishes both physical and spiritual needs. The text also connects the observance of Shabbat with the eternal covenant between God and Israel, suggesting that the joy and sanctity of Shabbat should remain with a person even during the weekdays. Ultimately, it envisions a future restoration where the spiritual insights and blessings of the Shabbat will manifest in the world, overcoming the challenges posed by the forces of negativity.

passage_content: איתא בזוה"ק בפסוק מאשר שמנה לחמו לחם משנה דשבת דאית לחם מן הארץ ולחם מה"ש ובש"ק מתחברין כו' ע"ש. והענין הוא כי ב' הלחם הם בחי' התורה שבכתב ושבע"פ. כי הנה שורש התורה בשמים ולמטה א"י להתגלות בשלימות לכן הוא לחם עוני ובשבת יש התגלות גם למטה לכן יש קריאת התורה בשבת. ואיתא כי יוסף הוא בחי' השבת צדיק יסוד עולם דאחיד בשמי' וארעא. ולכן יוסף גימ' ב' פעמים לחם. והנה יש ו' סדרים בתורה כדכ' תורת ה' תמימה כו'. ויש ששה שמות ובכולם פורט ב' ענינים למעלה ולמטה. תמימה היא בשורש למעלה ומשיבת נפש למטה. וכמו כן עדות ה' נאמנה למעלה מחכימת פתי למטה. וכן כולם. ויתכן לומר שאלה החילוקים הם בס"ת שכ' חז"ל שס' במדבר כולל ג' ספרים ויהי בנסוע ס' מיוחד בנתים ע"ש. א"כ יש ששה ספרים ששה בחי' הנ"ל. וס' דברים שנק' משנה תורה הוא המחבר ב' בחי' הנ"ל. שכן הוא הסיפור שביאר משה רבינו ע"ה התורה לבנ"י והוא בחי' משנה לחם הנ"ל. והוא בחי' יוסף שגימ' ששה הויות הנ"ל. ובארץ יש רק החצי כמ"ש שאין השם שלם עד שימחה שמו של עמלק. ולכן א"י להתגלות למטה בשלימות רק שיש זמנים כמו ש"ק. וכמו כן בנפשות הצדיקים שבכוחם יש התגלות בשלימות. ובאמת התגלות הנ"ל תלי' ג"כ בהתעברות הסט"א. והנה יוסף נק' ע"ש אסף אלקים את חרפתי. והוא רמז להסרת הערלה כדכ' חרפה היא לנו. וע"י כן יש התגלות הקדושה. והוא רמוז ביוסף ה' לי בן אחר. שזה התוספות הבא מלמעלה אחר התעברות הסט"א. שכן הוא במילה שמתגלה אות ברית קודש בהסרת הערלה. וב' בחי' הנ"ל הם גם בשבת קודש. שנק' שבת ע"ש השביתה והחזרת הכל אל השורש. ונק' ג"כ ע"ש השבתת הסט"א כדאיתא דסט"א ערקת בשבת. ולכן יש התגלות נשמה יתירה שניתוסף בשבת. וב' בחי' הנ"ל הם בחי' זכור ושמור:
translation:
It is stated in the Zohar on the verse "from which he prepared his bread, the double portion of Shabbat," that there is bread from the earth and bread from above, and on Shabbat they unite, etc. The matter is that the two breads represent the Written Torah and the Oral Torah. For the root of the Torah is in the heavens, and below, the Land of Israel, it is revealed in completeness; therefore, it is called "bread of poverty." On Shabbat, there is a revelation also below; hence, there is a reading of the Torah on Shabbat. It is stated that Joseph is the aspect of Shabbat, the righteous one, the foundation of the world, who is united in the heavens and the earth. Therefore, Joseph equals two times "bread." 

Now, there are six orders in the Torah, as it is written, "The Torah of the Lord is perfect," etc. There are six names, and in all of them, two matters are detailed, above and below. "Perfect" is in the root above, and "restoring the soul" is below. Likewise, "The testimony of the Lord is trustworthy" is above, "making wise the simple" is below. And so it is with all of them. It can be said that these distinctions are in the scrolls, as our Sages wrote that the scroll of Numbers includes three scrolls, and "when they journeyed" is a special scroll in between, etc. Thus, there are six scrolls corresponding to the six aspects mentioned above. The scroll of Deuteronomy, which is called "the repetition of the Torah," is the one that connects the two aspects mentioned above. 

Thus, it is the narrative that Moses our teacher, peace be upon him, explained the Torah to the Children of Israel, and it is the aspect of the "double bread" mentioned above. And it is the aspect of Joseph, which equals six existences mentioned above. In the land, there is only the half, as it is said that the name is not complete until the name of Amalek is erased. Therefore, it cannot be revealed below in completeness, only at times like Shabbat. Likewise, in the souls of the righteous, through their power, there is a revelation in completeness. And indeed, the aforementioned revelation is also dependent on the conception of the other side. 

And behold, Joseph is called after "God has gathered my reproach." This is a hint to the removal of the orlah, as it is written, "It is a reproach to us." And through this, there is a revelation of holiness. This is hinted at in Joseph's words, "God has given me another son." This is the addition that comes from above after the conception of the other side. Thus, it is in the circumcision, which reveals the letter of the holy covenant through the removal of the orlah. And the two aspects mentioned above are also in the holy Shabbat, which is called Shabbat after the cessation and the return of everything to the root. It is also called after the cessation of the other side, as it is stated that the other side is weakened on Shabbat. Therefore, there is a revelation of an additional soul that is added on Shabbat. And the two aspects mentioned above are the aspects of "remember" and "guard."
summary: The passage discusses the dual aspects of the Torah, represented by the two loaves of bread, which symbolize the Written and Oral Torah. It emphasizes that while the Torah's root is in the heavens, its complete revelation occurs on Shabbat, a time when the spiritual and physical realms connect. The figure of Joseph is highlighted as embodying this connection, representing the ultimate unity of the divine and earthly realms, and the transformative power of Shabbat, which brings an additional spiritual essence. The text also notes that the full manifestation of holiness is contingent upon the removal of spiritual impurities, paralleling the themes of redemption and the restoration of the divine order.

passage_content: בפסוק הקבצו ושמעו בנ"י ושמעו אל ישראל אביכם. ובמד' כי מכאן זכו בנ"י לק"ש בכל יום ע"ש. דאיתא יעקב אבינו לא מת. הפי' כי כל כוחו הניח בכלל ישראל. וכמ"ש ז"ל כל המניח בן ממלא מקומו כאילו לא מת. ויכולין בנ"י לעורר בכל יום כוחו של יעקב אבינו. וכ' ב"פ שמעו והוא כמ"ש שמעי בת כו' והטי אזנך. והם ב' מיני שמיעות. הראשון הוא במדת כל א' לפי מה שהוא וזה שמעי בת. בת היא מדה. אח"כ והטי אזנך הוא לעורר השורש ע"י ביטול כל הדעת כמ"ש ושכחי עמך כו'. וכן הכא שמעו בני יעקב. אח"כ ושמעו אל ישראל הוא קריאת שמע בכללות בנ"י כמ"ש במד' שמע ישראל סבא. וכוונת המד' שיעקב ביקש זאת מהם להשמיע אליו הקול כמ"ש השמיעיני את קולך [ועיין בזוה"ק פ' זו כעין זה בפי' הפסוק הנבא אל הרוח אח"כ הנבא ב"א ודבר אל הרוח ע"ש ד' רל"ה וכעין זה הוא בכאן] כי בודאי כוחן של האבות הוא מאוד נעלה. אעפ"כ כמו שהאבות מעוררין כל בנ"י. כן כללות בנ"י בכוחם לעורר את האבות. ולכן ושמעו א"י אביכם הוא מדריגה גדולה כמ"ש שמע ישראל והמשכיל יבין:
translation: In the verse "Gather and hear, O sons of Jacob, and hear, O Israel, your father." And in the Midrash, it is stated that from here the sons of Israel merited to recite the Shema every day, in His name. It is said that our forefather Jacob did not die. The meaning is that all his strength was left within the community of Israel. As our sages have said, whoever leaves a son fills his place as if he had not died. And the sons of Israel can awaken every day the strength of our forefather Jacob. And it is written twice "hear," and it is as it is said, "Hearken, O daughter," and "Incline your ear." These are two types of hearing. The first is in the measure of each one according to what he is, and this is "Hearken, O daughter." A daughter is a measure. Afterwards, "Incline your ear" is to awaken the root by nullifying all knowledge, as it is said, "Forget your people." And so here, "Hear, O sons of Jacob." Afterwards, "And hear, O Israel" is the recitation of the Shema in general for the sons of Israel, as it is said in the Midrash, "Hear, O Israel, our grandfather." And the intention of the Midrash is that Jacob requested this from them to make the voice heard to him, as it is said, "Let me hear your voice" [and see in the Zohar, Parashat this, similar to the interpretation of the verse "Prophesy to the wind," afterwards "Prophesy to the sons of men" and speak to the wind, in the name of the Lord, 205, and similar to this is here]. For certainly, the strength of the patriarchs is very exalted. Nevertheless, just as the patriarchs awaken all the sons of Israel, so the entirety of the sons of Israel, through their strength, can awaken the patriarchs. And therefore, "And hear, O Israel, your father" is a great level, as it is said, "Hear, O Israel," and the wise will understand.
summary: The passage emphasizes the enduring spiritual connection between the Jewish people and their patriarch Jacob, asserting that his essence and strength remain present within Israel. It highlights the dual nature of listening—each individual attuning to their unique spiritual measure and collectively uniting in the recitation of the Shema. The text suggests that the patriarchs, while powerful, are also invoked and energized by the collective prayers and actions of the Jewish people. Ultimately, the call to "hear" signifies a profound relationship where both the ancestors and their descendants mutually inspire and elevate one another spiritually.

passage_content: בפסוק יהודה כו' כרע רבץ כו'. אמו"ז ז"ל אמר כי הגם שיוסף הוא הצדיק ועליו נאמר אור זרוע לצדיק. מ"מ יהודה גבר באחיו והוא בחי' לישרי לב שמחה. ורש"י פי' ישר עדיף מצדיק וביאר כי יהודה בכוחו להעלות כל הנופלים ליישר אורחותם וזה כרע רבץ אפי' בשעת נפילה כו'. והכלל כי השבטים נק' ישרי לב והם עמודים לתקן הטבע כי בחי' יוסף הוא למעלה מהטבע כמ"ש במ"א כי הוא בחי' עץ החיים. ויהודה תיקון עה"ד. כמ"ש בכל דרכיך דעהו ואמרו חז"ל שהיא פרשה קטנה שגופי תורה תלוין בה. פי' אף שהיא בקטנות לתקן הדברים המקולקלים שצריכין להתיישר. לכן כ' והוא יישר אורחותיך. ולכן משיח בן דוד יתקן כל המעוות. ועל יוסף ויהודה אמרו אמת ויציב שחרית ואמת ואמונה ערבית. כי תיקון התערובות ע"י אמונה. ובגמ' דרשו והי' אמונת עתיך ששואלין לאדם נשאת ונתת באמונה קבעת עתים לתורה והוא בחי' הנ"ל לתקן הטבע והזמן ע"י אמונה לחברם אל התורה להאמין כי גם מה שהאדם עוסק במו"מ וגם כל העתים המתחלפים כמ"ש לכל זמן ועת כו' תחת השמים. אבל האדם צריך לבטלם ולקבעם ולחברם אל התורה. אח"כ צפית לישועה כמ"ש ושם דרך אראנו בישע אלקים כמ"ש חז"ל המדליק נרות במבואות אפלים זוכה לראות בישועת ה':
translation: In the verse "Judah, you are he whom your brothers shall praise," it is said that although Joseph is the righteous one, of whom it is stated "Light is sown for the righteous," nevertheless, Judah is a man among his brothers and represents the aspect of the "upright of heart" who brings joy. Rashi explains that the upright is superior to the righteous and clarifies that Judah has the power to uplift all those who have fallen to straighten their paths, and this is akin to "he crouches and lies down" even at the time of falling. The principle is that the tribes are called the upright of heart, and they are pillars to rectify nature, for the aspect of Joseph is above nature, as stated elsewhere, for he is the Tree of Life. And Judah is the rectification of the sin of Adam. As it is written, "In all your ways acknowledge Him," and our sages said that this is a small section upon which the essence of the Torah depends. This means that even though it is small, it rectifies the corrupted matters that need to be straightened. Therefore, it is written, "And He will straighten your paths." Hence, the Messiah, son of David, will rectify all that is distorted. Concerning Joseph and Judah, it is said, "True and established is the morning, and true and faithful is the evening," for the rectification of the mixtures is through faith. And in the Gemara, they expounded, "And your faith will be the strength of your times," which asks a person whether he has engaged in business dealings with faith and whether he has set times for Torah study. This is the aforementioned aspect of rectifying nature and time through faith, to connect them to the Torah, to believe that even what a person engages in business and all the changing times, as it is written, "To everything there is a season and a time for every matter under heaven." However, a person must nullify them and establish them and connect them to the Torah. Afterwards, you will look forward to salvation, as it is written, "And there I will show you the way of salvation," as our sages said, "One who lights candles in dark doorways merits to see the salvation of God."
summary: The passage discusses the roles of the tribes of Judah and Joseph, highlighting Judah's ability to uplift and guide others towards righteousness, while Joseph represents a higher spiritual state beyond nature. It emphasizes that the tribes, referred to as "Yeshrei Lev" (upright of heart), serve to rectify the natural order, with Judah's role being particularly focused on restoring what is broken. The text also connects the concepts of faith and the importance of integrating daily life with Torah, suggesting that true belief can transform mundane activities into spiritual endeavors, ultimately leading to redemption and divine salvation.

passage_content: בענין יששכר וזבולון. שע"י שזבולון הכין פרנסת יששכר לכן קיבל יששכר ב' חלקים. ולכן נקרא יששכר שכר לו ושכר לזבולון. ומעין זה הוא ימי המעשה שהם הכנה לשבת לכן יש בשבת לחם משנה וכל מעשי שבת כפולין שהשבת מקבל ברכה גם לימי המעשה:
translation: Regarding Issachar and Zebulun. Because Zebulun prepared the livelihood for Issachar, therefore Issachar received two portions. And thus Issachar is called "wages for him" and "wages for Zebulun." In a similar manner, the days of work are a preparation for Shabbat; therefore, on Shabbat there is lechem mishneh (double bread), and all the acts of Shabbat are doubled, as Shabbat receives blessing also for the days of work.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the tribes of Issachar and Zebulun, highlighting that Zebulun's provision for Issachar's sustenance results in Issachar receiving a double portion of reward. This reflects the idea that the preparation during the weekdays (the "days of action") is essential for the sanctity of Shabbat, which in turn receives a double blessing. The concept of "bread for two" on Shabbat symbolizes the spiritual abundance that arises from the labor and preparation of the weekdays, emphasizing the interconnectedness of work and spiritual fulfillment.

passage_content: בפסוק האספו ואגידה הקבצו ושמעו. הם ב' מיני התאספות והוא ברית המעור וברית הלשון. האספו כמ"ש אספו לי חסידי כו'. הקבצו ושמעו הוא ברית הלשון וע"י המילה זוכין לתורה כמ"ש מי יעלה לנו השמימה ויקחה לנו וישמיענו כו' ודרשו ר"ת מילה. וכ' לאדם מערכי לב הוא בכח המילה. ומה' מענה לשון כי הדיבור הוא בהתגלות והמילה היא בסתר ובפנימיות. וכן לשון אסיפה הוא על הפנימיות כמ"ש אם ישים אליו לבו רו"נ אליו יאסוף. וכ"כ בנפשות נאסף אל עמי. והקבצו הוא התאחדות הגופות בהתגלות. וב' אלו הם בחי' יוסף ויהודה. ושמעתי מאמו"ז ז"ל כי ברכת יוסף פורת עלי עין עולי עין שאין ע"ר שולטת כדאי' בגמ' ולכן עיקר הברכה היא ביוסף דכ' ישלח ברכה באסמיך במקום הסמוי מן העין. וכן הוא בשבת ברזא דאחד שנמצא בכל איש ישראל נקודה סתומה ונסתרת כו' עכ"ד. ולכן אמרו מתנה טובה יש לי בבית גנזי. וכן במילה כ' סוד ה' ליראיו שהיא נקודה סתומה ונעולה לכן יש שם ערלה ומכסה על הפנימיות להבדיל בין ישראל לעמים. אבל ובריתו להודיעם שניתן לישראל ברית המילה שעי"ז יהי' להם דביקות בזה הסוד הגנוז בהם. והנה השבטים הם עמודים וגבולים להבדיל בין ישראל לעמים כמ"ש יצב גבולות עמים למב"י. ויוסף בחי' גבוה מזה כמ"ש מו"ז ז"ל כי יש בב"י בחי' מספר ואין מספר ע"ש פ' שמות. וכאן כתיב למספר בנ"י יש גבולות. אבל בחי' יוסף היא אין מספר רמז לדבר בפסוק ויצבור יוסף בר וגו' כי חדל לספור ומסיים הפסוק כי אין מספר פי' לאשר יוסף הוא בחי' אין מספר לכן כן דרכו להעלות כל המספרים להדביקם אל השורש ששם חדל המספר וזה הוא לעולם מ"ש ויצבור יוסף כו'. כן בכל ש"ק השבת מעלה כל הנעשה בימי המעשה שמתלבש תוך הטבע והצמצום אל השורש ואז חדל המספר. והוא מעין יום שכולו שבת כי לעתיד יתעלו ויתוקנו כל המעשים ויתברר כי לכל הנעשה בטבע יש להם אחיזה ודביקות בשורש שלמעלה. ומעין זה בשבת קודש. לכן אמרו דאתאחדת ברזא דאחד ואז לפני אחד מה אתה סופר כידוע למביני דעת:
translation: In the verse "Assemble and I will tell, gather and hear," there are two types of gathering: the covenant of the mixture and the covenant of the tongue. "Assemble" as it is written, "Assemble to Me, My pious ones," etc. "Gather and hear" refers to the covenant of the tongue, and through the word, we merit the Torah, as it is said, "Who will ascend to heaven for us and take it for us and make us hear," etc., and they interpreted the acronym of "word." And it is written, "The plans of the heart belong to man," which is through the power of the word. And from God, the answer of the tongue, for speech is in revelation, and the word is in secrecy and in the inner aspect. Likewise, the term "assembly" refers to the inner aspect, as it is written, "If he sets his heart to it, he will gather to him." And it is also written, "And the souls are gathered to my people." And "gathering" is the unification of bodies in revelation. These two are the aspects of Joseph and Judah. I heard from my teacher, may his memory be blessed, that the blessing of Joseph is "A fruitful bough, a fruitful bough by a well," that the evil eye does not rule, as stated in the Gemara, and therefore the essence of the blessing is in Joseph, as it is written, "He will send a blessing upon your storehouses," in the place hidden from the eye. And so it is on Shabbat, the secret of the One, which is found in every Jew, a hidden and concealed point, etc. Therefore, it is said, "I have a good gift in my treasure house." And likewise, regarding the word, it is written, "The secret of the Lord is for those who fear Him," which is a hidden and locked point; therefore, there is an orlah there, covering the inner aspect to distinguish between Israel and the nations. But His covenant is to inform them that the covenant of circumcision was given to Israel, so that they may have attachment to this hidden secret within them. And behold, the tribes are pillars and boundaries to distinguish between Israel and the nations, as it is written, "He set the boundaries of the nations for the children of Israel." And Joseph is a higher aspect than this, as my teacher, may his memory be blessed, said, for there is in Israel an aspect of number and no number, as mentioned in the portion of Shemot. And here it is written, "To number the children of Israel, there are boundaries." But the aspect of Joseph is without number, hinted at in the verse, "And Joseph gathered grain," etc., for he ceased to count, and the verse concludes, "For there is no number," meaning that what Joseph represents is the aspect of no number; therefore, it is his way to elevate all numbers to attach them to the root, where counting ceases, and this is forever, as it is said, "And Joseph gathered," etc. So too, every Shabbat, the Sabbath elevates all that is done during the days of action, which is clothed within nature and constriction, to the root, and then counting ceases. It is a semblance of a day that is entirely Shabbat, for in the future, all actions will be elevated and rectified, and it will be clarified that all that is done in nature has a hold and attachment to the root above. And in a similar manner on the holy Shabbat. Therefore, they said, "The secret of the One is united," and then before the One, what are you counting, as is known to those who understand knowledge.
summary: The passage discusses two types of gatherings: the gathering of the heart (the inner essence) and the gathering of speech (external expression), emphasizing the significance of the covenant of circumcision as a means for Jews to connect with their inner spiritual essence. It contrasts the roles of Joseph and Judah, highlighting Joseph's unique ability to transcend numerical limitations and unify all aspects of existence with their divine source. The text also reflects on the nature of Shabbat as a time when all actions are elevated and connected to their spiritual roots, ultimately revealing the hidden unity within creation. This unity is symbolized by the secret of the covenant, which distinguishes Israel from the nations and fosters a deep connection to the divine.

passage_content: במדרש הרועה אותי המלאך הגואל הקיש גאולה לפרנסה מה פרנסה בכל יום כו'. ופרנסה ע"י הקב"ה גאולה ע"י מלאך. כי הקב"ה מחדש בכל יום מעשה בראשית וכל פרנסת היום. וכשבא השפע לעוה"ז מתלבש בטבע וזהו ע"י מלאך ולכן צריך גאולה בכל יום כי בבוא השפע בזה ההתלבשות מתערב בו פסולת ותערובות וצריך גאולה ובירור להוציא אוכל מתוך פסולת. ועיקר תכלית הברכה להיות דבוק בשורש. וז"ש ויקרא בהם שמי ושם אבותי כי זה תכלית עבודת האדם כמ"ש חייב אדם לומר מתי יגיעו מעשי למעשה אבותי אברהם יצחק ויעקב. ויעקב אע"ה בירך הנערים להיות להם דביקות באבות וכמו כן ברכת כל השבטים כמ"ש ויקרא יעקב אל בניו. קריאה לשון חבה ודביקות. ואמרו חז"ל כלי מחזיק ברכה היא שלום. ופי' שלום כשיש דביקות וחיבור עד השורש. והאבות הם שורש הכל. ולכן בשבת כתיב ויברך כו' א"י השביעי הואיל ובשבת מתעלין הכל אל השורש ויכולין לקבל הברכה:
translation: In the Midrash, the shepherd said: The redeeming angel connects redemption to sustenance. Just as sustenance is provided every day, so too is redemption. Sustenance is through the Holy One, Blessed be He, and redemption is through an angel. For the Holy One, Blessed be He, renews every day the work of creation and the sustenance of the day. When the abundance comes to this world, it is clothed in nature, and this is through an angel. Therefore, redemption is needed every day, for when the abundance comes in this clothing, it is mixed with waste and impurities, and redemption and clarification are needed to extract food from the waste. The main purpose of the blessing is to be attached to the root. And this is what is meant by "I will call upon them by My name and the name of my forefathers," for this is the ultimate purpose of a person's service, as it is said: A person is obligated to say, "When will my deeds reach the deeds of my forefathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob?" And Jacob, peace be upon him, blessed the youths to have attachment to the forefathers, and likewise the blessing of all the tribes, as it is said: "And Jacob called his sons." Calling is a term of affection and attachment. And our Sages have said: "The vessel that holds blessing is peace." And the explanation of peace is when there is attachment and connection to the root. And the forefathers are the root of everything. Therefore, on Shabbat it is written: "And He blessed..." The seventh day is blessed, for on Shabbat everything ascends to the root and can receive the blessing.
summary: The passage emphasizes the connection between divine sustenance and redemption, illustrating that while sustenance is provided by God through nature, redemption is facilitated by angels. It highlights the necessity of daily redemption to purify and elevate the material world, allowing for the extraction of spiritual essence from the mundane. The ultimate goal of human endeavor is to achieve a deep connection with the patriarchs, as exemplified by Jacob's blessings to his sons, which symbolize a bond to their spiritual roots. The text concludes by noting that true blessing and peace arise from this connection to the divine source, particularly on the Sabbath, when all is elevated to its root.

passage_content: ענין יוסף ויהודה הם כלל כל השבטים. יוסף ראש ולמעלה מהם ולכן יש לו ברכה לעצמו כמ"ש ויברך את יוסף מלבד הברכה של כל השבטים. וכ' בו שכם אחד על אחיך. ויהודה הוא הכלל בתוך כל השבטים ולכן כ' יהודה גבר באחיו ולא על אחיו. וכ"כ ואל עמו תביאנו ואי' במד' שבנ"י נקראו על שמו יהודים לפי שהי' חביב לאביו נתן לו חלקו וחלק עם אחיו ע"ש. היינו שיש לכל שבט חלק מכחו של יהודה. וכמו כן יוסף מעלה כל השבטים דיש נשיא ומלך מלגאו ומלבר. וזהו משיח בן יוסף. ובן דוד:
translation: The matter of Joseph and Judah encompasses all the tribes. Joseph is the head and above them, and therefore he has a blessing for himself, as it is said, "And he blessed Joseph besides the blessing of all the tribes." It is written about him, "A shechem (shoulder) one upon your brothers." And Judah is the general within all the tribes, and thus it is written, "Judah is a lion's whelp from the prey, my son, you have gone up," not "over" his brothers. And it is also written, "And to his people you shall bring him," and it is stated in the Midrash that the Children of Israel are called by his name, Jews, because he was beloved by his father, who gave him his portion and the portion with his brothers, as mentioned. This means that each tribe has a share from the strength of Judah. Likewise, Joseph elevates all the tribes, for there is a prince and a king from within and from without. And this is the Messiah, son of Joseph, and son of David.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph and Judah as representative figures of the tribes of Israel, with Joseph being the leader and receiving a unique blessing, while Judah embodies the collective essence of the tribes. It highlights that each tribe has a share in Judah's strength, and that Joseph elevates all the tribes, symbolizing the dual leadership of the Messiah, both as the son of Joseph and the son of David. This reflects the interconnectedness of the tribes and their roles in the divine plan.

passage_content: בפסוק האספו ואגידה כו' ושמעו. ואחז"ל ביקש לגלות הקץ ונסתם ממנו כו'. כבר כתבנו במ"א כי האספו והקבצו הם ב' מיני כינוסים. האספו הוא בכלות הנפש כמ"ש רוחו כו' אליו יאסוף. והוא כמו הקדמת נעשה לנשמע שהי' בקבלת התורה כמ"ש חז"ל בפי' עושי דברו כדי לשמוע בק"ד. וז"ש האספו ואגידה בחי' עושי דברו שבנ"י עושים הדיבור כמ"ש חז"ל בפסוק שמעה עמי ואדברה אין מעידין אלא בשומע לכן הקדים שמעה אז ואדברה נמצא שנעשה הדיבור על ידיהם כמ"ש בזוה"ק פ' בלק. הקבצו ושמעו היא השמיעה ואחז"ל קלקלתם נעשה הזהרו בנשמע כי זו ההקדמה שהיא למעלה מן הטבע לא נתקיימה בידינו. ומעין זה עצמו הי' בהשבטים אם הי' מתאספים כרצונו הי' ניתקן הכל. כי באמת בנ"י מוכנים לזה ויכולים להגאל כהרף עין כמו שהי' בקבלת התורה כשהקדימו נעשה לנשמע היו מוכנים להיות חירות ממיתה כמ"ש אלקים אתם כו'. ואז נעשים בני חורין כיון שמתעלים מן הטבע וכל הגלות רק בבחי' הטבע. וכשמתדבקין בעץ החיים [מתעלים מן הטבע]. והוא השטר חירות שרמז במד' שרצה יעקב למסור להם וכיון שלא הי' התיקון כראוי הזהיר אותם בשמיעה. והם ב' פרשיות שבק"ש שאומרים בכל יום. שמע כו' ה' אחד היא מס"נ ואיתא בשם האר"י ז"ל אם הי' מכוונים ביחוד כראוי הי' נעשה הגאולה מיד. ואח"כ פ' והי' אם שמוע בחי' נשמע. אח"כ פ' יצי"מ רמז לגאולה שע"י פרשיות שבק"ש מתעורר הגאולה:
translation:
In the verse "Assemble and I will tell you," and "Listen." Our Sages said that he sought to reveal the end and it was concealed from him. We have already written previously that "assemble" and "gather" are two types of gatherings. "Assemble" refers to the totality of the soul, as it is said, "His spirit will gather him." It is like the precedence of "We will do" before "We will hear," which was at the giving of the Torah, as our Sages explained in the interpretation of "Do His word to hear." Therefore, it is said "Assemble and I will tell" in the aspect of "Do His word" that the Children of Israel perform the speech, as our Sages said regarding the verse "Hear, O My people, and I will speak," that one only bears witness when they hear. Thus, it is preceded by "Hear" and then "I will speak," indicating that the speech is made through them, as mentioned in the Zohar in Parashat Balak. 

"Gather and listen" refers to the listening, and our Sages said, "You have corrupted; be careful in listening," for this preparation, which is above nature, was not fulfilled in our hands. And a similar thing occurred with the tribes; if they had gathered according to his will, everything would have been rectified. For indeed, the Children of Israel are prepared for this and can be redeemed in the blink of an eye, just as it was at the giving of the Torah when they preceded "We will do" to "We will hear," they were prepared to be free from death, as it is said, "You are gods." Then they become free people since they rise above nature, and all exile is only in the aspect of nature. And when they cling to the Tree of Life [they rise above nature]. This is the document of freedom that Jacob hinted at in the Midrash that he wanted to give to them, and since the rectification was not as it should be, he warned them in listening. 

And these are the two sections of the Shema that we say every day. "Hear, O Israel, the Lord is our God, the Lord is One," which is self-sacrifice, and it is stated in the name of the Ari, blessed be his memory, that if one were to be properly focused in particular, the redemption would happen immediately. And afterwards, the section "And it shall be, if you listen," which is the aspect of "We will hear." Then the section of the Exodus from Egypt hints at the redemption, for through the sections of the Shema, the redemption is awakened.
summary: The passage discusses the dual concepts of "אספו" (gathering) and "קבצו" (assembling) in the context of spiritual readiness for redemption. It emphasizes that true gathering involves a complete dedication of the soul, akin to the Jewish people's acceptance of the Torah, where they proclaimed "נעשה ונשמע" (we will do and we will hear). The text highlights that the potential for immediate redemption exists when the Jewish people align themselves with divine will, transcending natural limitations. Ultimately, the recitation of the Shema serves as a catalyst for awakening the process of redemption through sincere commitment and unity.

passage_content: בענין ברכת השבטים שבירך יעקב עיקר הברכות קיבלו יהודה ויוסף. ומו"ז ז"ל אמר כי ברכת יוסף הוא ברכת השבת נחלה בלי מצרים כמ"ש ברכות אביך גברו כו'. ובספרים איתא כי ברכת יהודה הוא השבת ע"ש בס' רקנטי ור' בחיי. ונראה דשניהם אמת כי יש בשבת זכור ושמור והוא בחי' יוסף ויהודה. והם בחי' סתים וגליא ברית המעור וברית הלשון. כי שבת סהדותא איקרי. והפה הוא בחי' התגלות שהפה נברא להודות לה' וזכור הוא באתכסיא. ולכן לא הכירו השבטים כוחו של יוסף. ויהודה כ' בי' אתה יודוך אחיך כי הארה שלו בהתגלות. ואיתא יוסף קידש ש"ש בסתר ניתוסף לו ה' משמו של הקב"ה ויהודה קידש ש"ש בפרהסיא נקרא כולו ע"ש של הקב"ה. והגם כי בחי' יוסף למעלה מיהודה. אות ה' שניתוסף לו היא מן השם הוי' הנעלה שבו משתתף יוסף עם הג' אבות. ואות ה' ניתן ליוסף שבזה מאיר לשם הוי' שביהודה. ולכן איתא בזוה"ק כי בשבת לא אשתכח בי' מנא משום דכולהו ברכאין בי' תליין דייקא וא"י להיות בגלוי רק בשורש הנסתר ולא באתגליא. וכתיב בשבת ביני ובין בנ"י אות היא. א"כ השבת יש בו חלק להקב"ה וחלק לבנ"י. וב' אלו הם ב' בחי' הנ"ל. זכור ושמור. יוסף ויהודה. וזה בחי' משנה לחם שכ' בזוה"ק ע"ש לחם מן הארץ ולחם מן השמים. ובחי' יהודה לחם מן הארץ והוא הלחם שזוכין ע"י בירור בימי המעשה. ובנ"י בכח גלות מצרים הרויחו זה הלחם כמ"ש לחם עוני שבא ע"י עינוי. ושבת נק' מנוחה שבשבת זוכין ללחם זה שלא ע"י עינוי ובירור. דאין בו פסולת. ואח"כ בקבלת התורה זכו בנ"י ללחם מן השמים התורה. ושבת זכר ליצי"מ ולקבלת התורה לכן יש בו לחם משנה:
translation: Regarding the blessing of the tribes that Jacob blessed, the main blessings were received by Judah and Joseph. Our teacher, may his memory be blessed, said that the blessing of Joseph is the blessing of the Sabbath, an inheritance without boundaries, as it is written, "The blessings of your father have surpassed..." In the books, it is stated that the blessing of Judah is the Sabbath, as mentioned in the book of Rekanti and Rabbi Bachaye. It seems that both are true, for in the Sabbath there is "Zachor" (Remember) and "Shamor" (Observe), which correspond to the aspects of Joseph and Judah. They represent the concealed and the revealed, the covenant of the mixture and the covenant of the tongue. For the Sabbath is called a testimony. The mouth is the aspect of revelation, as the mouth was created to give thanks to God, and "Zachor" is in the hidden. Therefore, the tribes did not recognize the power of Joseph. And Judah said, "You are praised by your brothers," for his illumination is in revelation. It is stated that Joseph sanctified the Sabbath in secret, and he was added the letter "He" from the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, while Judah sanctified the Sabbath in public, and he is called entirely by the name of the Holy One, blessed be He. And although the aspect of Joseph is higher than that of Judah, the letter "He" that was added to him is from the exalted name of "Havayah," in which Joseph shares with the three patriarchs. And the letter "He" was given to Joseph, through which he illuminates the name "Havayah" that is in Judah. Therefore, it is stated in the Zohar that on the Sabbath, the letter "Yud" is not found, because all blessings are specifically dependent on the "Yud," and it cannot be in revelation, only in the root of the hidden and not in the revealed. It is written about the Sabbath, "Between Me and the children of Israel, it is a sign." Thus, the Sabbath has a part for the Holy One, blessed be He, and a part for the children of Israel. These two are the two aspects mentioned above: "Zachor" and "Shamor," Joseph and Judah. This is the aspect of the double portion of bread mentioned in the Zohar, corresponding to "bread from the earth" and "bread from the heavens." The aspect of Judah is "bread from the earth," which is the bread that is earned through refinement during the days of action. And the children of Israel, through the power of the Egyptian exile, earned this bread, as it is said, "the bread of affliction that comes through affliction." And the Sabbath is called a rest, for on the Sabbath, they merit this bread not through affliction and refinement, for it has no waste. And afterwards, with the receiving of the Torah, the children of Israel merited the bread from the heavens, which is the Torah. And the Sabbath is a remembrance of the Exodus from Egypt and the receiving of the Torah; therefore, it has the double portion of bread.
summary: The passage discusses the blessings given by Jacob to his sons Judah and Joseph, highlighting their distinct spiritual roles. Joseph's blessing represents the hidden aspects of the Sabbath, while Judah's blessing embodies its revealed aspects. The text emphasizes the duality of "Zachor" (remember) and "Shamor" (observe) in relation to the Sabbath, linking it to the divine and the Jewish people. Ultimately, the Sabbath serves as a connection between God and Israel, symbolizing both earthly sustenance and heavenly nourishment through the Torah.

passage_content: בפסוק יהודה אתה יודוך אחיך כו'. כי יהודה הכין הדרך לכל בנ"י ונק' יהודים על שמו. וזה כח הודאה מודה על האמת. ובזה יכולין להתדבק באמת והיא בחי' אמונה כרע רבץ כארי כו' לומר אפי' בשעת ירידה יש לו התחזקות והתאמצות. וזה החילוק בין יוסף ויהודה דכ' ובידך לגדל ולחזק לכל. יש נושעים ע"י התנשאות ויש ע"י התחזקות. ויוסף נתעלה במדריגה גבוה. ויהודה ניתן לו החיזוק כמו שהוא והוא גברא דמרי' סייעי'. ולכן כל השם בו עם אות ד'. לומר אשכון את דכא לפי דלית לי' מגרמי' כלום. והי' בו בחי' הביטול לגמרי אל הקב"ה. ועבד מלך מלך. והנה הקב"ה משפיל גאים ומגביה שפלים. ואין הפי' על מי שהוא בעל גיאה בשקר. אך המידה היא כך כי לפי התרוממות הגאים. כך יש בהם בחי' השפלה. והכל עדות על הבורא ית"ש כי לו המלוכה. ולכן אפי' בשרים שלמעלה כך היא המדה. והרי העליונים הם קדושים וכל הנהגת העולם השפל נעשה על ידיהם. ובנ"י התחתונים הם שפלים וכל העולמות מתנהגין ע"פ מעשה התחתונים וז"ש כי גאה גאה. לאפוקי שאין שום גיאות שלא יהי' בו שפלות כי לפי התרוממות השרים כך היא שפלתם. בלתי הבורא ית' כי גאה גאה. וכן מה שדרשו חז"ל גאות אדם תשפילנו על אדה"ר ויוסף הצדיק. ע"ש זה הכוונה שלפי הגיאות והתרוממות שניתן להם לכן נשפלו כי כך היא המדה. ויהודה הוא שפל וגבוה. ויוסף הוא בחי' זקיפה כמ"ש קמה אלומתי וגם נצבה. ויהודה הכריעה כמ"ש כרע שכב. ואעפ"כ הוא כארי וכלביא. זה גבורת הבורא ית' וידו החזקה ששלח נשמות בנ"י למטה ויש להם כמה מיני שפלות ומחלוקות ומסטינים מלבר ומלגאו. והקב"ה מחזיק אותם. משל לגבור שהעמיד את הקורה ומורה בה חצים. החצים כלים. והקורה עומדת כמ"ש במדרש נצבים. וזה כח מלכותו ית"ש דכ' מלכותך מלכות כל עולמים. בתוך כל העלמות והסתרות אעפ"כ לו המלוכה. וזה ניתן ליהודה ודוד. ואיתא בפסוק וישתחו ישראל על ראש המטה וכן בפסוק ויפלו לפניו כו' הננו לך לעבדים אמרו תעלא בעידני' סגיד לי'. והענין הוא כי המלוכה ניתן ליהודה בקביעות כמו ארי מלך בחיות. ומ"מ השועל שהוא פקח בחכמתו מייעץ גם להארי באיזה זמנים ואז גם הארי משתחוה לו. וכן הוא יהודה מלך. ויוסף שהוא באמת עלי עין ויש זמנים שמתגלה הארת יוסף ואז הכל משתחוים לו. כי ביהודה כ' לא יסור שבט. וכ' וזאת ליהודה. זאת הוא דבר המתקיים תמיד. כי אין עולם מתקיים בלי מלך. אבל יוסף ע"ש התוספות שבא מעולם העליון. וזה לא יוכל להיות תמיד רק בשבתות ויו"ט שמתגלה הארה הנ"ל. ואז מתחברין. ויגש אליו יהודה כמ"ש לעיל במדרש ויגש:
translation: In the verse, "Judah, you will be praised by your brothers," it is because Judah prepared the way for all the children of Israel, and they are called Jews in his name. This is the power of acknowledgment, admitting the truth. Through this, they can cling to the truth, which is the aspect of faith, as a lion crouches. This means that even at the time of descent, one has strength and effort. This is the distinction between Joseph and Judah, as it is written, "In your hand is the ability to elevate and strengthen all." There are those who are saved through elevation and those through strengthening. Joseph was elevated to a high level, while Judah was given the strength as he is, and he is a mighty man who assists. Therefore, the name contains the letter "D" to indicate, "I will dwell with the humble," for he has nothing of his own. In him, there was a complete nullification to the Holy One, blessed be He. A servant of the King is a king. And behold, the Holy One, blessed be He, brings down the proud and elevates the humble. The meaning is not about someone who is proud in falsehood, but the measure is such that according to the elevation of the proud, so is their humiliation. All this is a testimony to the Creator, blessed be He, for to Him belongs the kingdom. Therefore, even the ministers above follow this measure. And behold, the higher beings are holy, and all the governance of the lowly world is done through them. And the lower children of Israel are humble, and all the worlds are governed according to the actions of the lowly. This is what is said, "For the proud is proud," to indicate that there is no pride that does not contain humility, for according to the elevation of the ministers, so is their lowliness, except for the Creator, blessed be He, for He is proud and proud. And so what our sages taught, "The pride of man will bring him low," refers to Adam and Joseph the righteous. The intention is that according to the pride and elevation given to them, therefore they were brought low, for such is the measure. Judah is lowly and high, while Joseph is in the aspect of uprightness, as it is written, "My sheaves arose and also stood." And Judah bowed down, as it is written, "He crouched and lay down." Nevertheless, he is like a lion and a young lion. This is the might of the Creator, blessed be He, and His strong hand that sent the souls of the children of Israel below, and they have many kinds of lowliness and disputes and adversaries from outside and from within. And the Holy One, blessed be He, holds them up. It is like a mighty man who stands the beam and shoots arrows with it. The arrows are consumed, but the beam stands, as it is written in the Midrash, "You stand." This is the power of His kingship, blessed be He, as it is written, "Your kingdom is the kingdom of all worlds." Amidst all the concealments and hiddenness, nevertheless, to Him belongs the kingdom. And this was given to Judah and David. It is stated in the verse, "And Israel bowed down at the head of the bed," and also in the verse, "And they fell before him," saying, "Here we are, your servants," they said, "Elevate us in the times of the festival." The matter is that the kingship was given to Judah permanently, like a lion, the king of beasts. Nevertheless, the fox, who is clever in his wisdom, advises even the lion at certain times, and then the lion bows down to him. So it is with Judah, the king. And Joseph, who is truly above, has times when the light of Joseph is revealed, and then everyone bows down to him. For it is written about Judah, "The scepter shall not depart from Judah," and it is written, "And this is for Judah." This is a matter that is always established, for the world cannot exist without a king. But Joseph, due to the additions that come from the upper world, this cannot always be, only on Shabbat and festivals when the above light is revealed. Then they connect. "And Judah approached him," as it is written above in the Midrash, "And Judah approached."
summary: The passage discusses the roles of Judah and Joseph in the context of Jewish identity and divine providence. Judah represents humility and the ability to connect with God through acknowledgment of truth, embodying the concept of faith even in times of struggle. In contrast, Joseph symbolizes elevation and wisdom, with his status being temporary and dependent on specific times of divine revelation. Ultimately, the text emphasizes that true kingship and stability in the world are rooted in the humility and steadfastness of Judah, while acknowledging the transient nature of Joseph's elevated state.

passage_content: בפסוק ויקרא יעקב כו' מהיכן זכו ישראל לק"ש ע"ש במדרש. מפסוק זה שמעו אל ישראל כו'. ואח"כ כתיב וזאת אשר דיבר כו' ויברך אותם. נראה כי הוא בחי' התפלה אחר ק"ש שהם הי"ב בקשות שמכוונים מול י"ב שבטים שיש לכל א' ברכה מיוחדת. והוא בחי' הדיבור כי ק"ש בחי' קול. וכ' ברכו ה' מלאכיו גבורי כח עו"ד. כי הקול בחי' יעקב והדיבור תיקנו השבטים כאן. וזאת אשר דיבר להם פי' לצרכם הוריד עצמו יעקב לחבר קול לדיבור ועי"ז נעשה הברכה. וכן בכל יום צריכין לברר מלכות שמים בקול ודיבור בק"ש ותפלה. וכל זה הכין לנו יעקב אבינו ע"ה בזאת הברכה:
translation: In the verse "And Jacob called," etc., from where did Israel merit the Shema, as mentioned in the Midrash? From this verse, "Hear, O Israel," etc. And afterwards it is written, "And this is what he spoke," etc., "and he blessed them." It appears that this is the aspect of prayer after the Shema, which consists of the twelve requests directed towards the twelve tribes, each having a special blessing. This is the aspect of speech, for the Shema is the aspect of voice. And it is written, "Bless the Lord, you His angels, mighty in strength," for the voice is the aspect of Jacob, and the speech was rectified by the tribes here. "And this is what he spoke to them" means that for their sake, Jacob lowered himself to connect voice to speech, and through this, the blessing was made. Likewise, every day we need to clarify the Kingdom of Heaven with voice and speech in the Shema and prayer. All this was prepared for us by our father Jacob, peace be upon him, in this blessing.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, it is explained that the recitation of the Shema (Kriat Shema) is a profound act through which the Jewish people connect to divine blessings, as initiated by Jacob. The twelve requests in the Shema correspond to the twelve tribes, each receiving a unique blessing. Jacob's role is emphasized as he harmonizes the voice (representing the Shema) with speech (representing prayer), thereby facilitating the transmission of blessings. This practice underscores the importance of affirming God's sovereignty daily through the Shema and prayer, a legacy established by our patriarch Jacob.

passage_content: ברש"י נסתמו עיניהם ולבן של ישראל. כבר כ' במ"א כי הגלות והגאולה תלוים בעין ולב. והם בחי' ברית המעור והלשון. בחי' יהודה ויוסף. וברית הלשון תלוי בלב כדכ' לאדם מערכי לב כפי היגיעה בלב נותן לו הש"י מענה לשון. וכפי שמירת העין זוכים לברית המעור לכן כתיב ול"ת אחרי לבבכם ואחרי עיניכם כו' ומסיים אשר הוצאתי אתכם מארץ מצרים. כי ברית הוא התקשרות. וכפי מה שנמצא זה ההתקשרות נעשים בני חורין וכאשר נסתם זה הכח אז יש גלות כנ"ל:
translation: In Rashi, their eyes were closed and the heart of Israel. It has already been written elsewhere that exile and redemption are dependent on the eye and the heart. They are the aspect of the covenant of the light and the tongue, the aspect of Judah and Joseph. And the covenant of the tongue is dependent on the heart, as it is written, "A person's heart plans his way, but the Lord directs his steps." And according to the guarding of the eye, one merits the covenant of the light; therefore, it is written, "And do not follow after your heart and after your eyes..." and it concludes, "which I brought you out of the land of Egypt." For a covenant is a connection. And according to how this connection is found, one becomes free. And when this power is closed, then there is exile, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the eyes and heart in the context of exile and redemption, emphasizing that the covenant of the eye and tongue reflects the spiritual states of Judah and Joseph. It highlights that the heart's intentions influence one's speech, and the safeguarding of the eyes leads to a deeper connection with the divine covenant. The text concludes that true freedom arises from this connection, and when this spiritual power is blocked, it results in exile.

passage_content: בפסוק הקבצו ושמעו בנ"י ושמעו אל ישראל. ב' שמיעות כמ"ש בכ"מ שמוע תשמעו וחז"ל דרשו אם שמוע בישן תשמעו בחדש. דהנה כ' ויקם עדות ביעקב. עדות הוא במקום שיש תערובות. והוא בחי' תיקון הדעת טוב ורע. ותורה שם בישראל הוא עץ החיים. והם ב' השמות יעקב וישראל. וע"ז אומרים השם נפשנו בחיים. ולא נתן למוט רגלינו הוא דרגא תחתונה שע"ש זה נק' יעקב. ויעקב אבינו ע"ה הנחיל לזרעו ב' השמות. ושמעו בני יעקב הוא הנטיעה שכבר נטע בהם רק שצריכים להוציאו מכח אל הפועל. וזה ניתקן בגלות מצרים לברר הדעת. וזהו בחי' שמוע בישן לתקן כל אחד הנטוע בו כמ"ש חיי עולם נטע בתוכינו בחי' תורה שבע"פ. אח"כ שמעו אל ישראל הוא השמיעה בחדש שזכו במתן תורה וכן הוא בכל איש ישראל:
translation: In the verse "Gather and hear, O sons of Jacob, and hear, O Israel," there are two hearings, as it is written elsewhere, "If you will listen, you will listen." The Sages have interpreted that if you listen in the old way, you will listen in the new way. Behold, it is written, "And He established a testimony in Jacob." A testimony is in a place where there is mixture, and it is the aspect of rectifying the knowledge of good and evil. And the Torah there in Israel is the Tree of Life. These are the two names, Jacob and Israel. And concerning this, it is said, "The name of our soul is alive." And He did not allow our feet to stumble; this is the lower level, which is why it is called Jacob. And our father Jacob, peace be upon him, bequeathed to his descendants the two names. "And hear, O sons of Jacob," refers to the planting that has already been planted within them, but they need to bring it from potential to actual. This was rectified in the exile of Egypt to clarify the knowledge. This is the aspect of "listening in the old way" to rectify each one that is planted within him, as it is said, "Eternal life You have planted within us," in the aspect of the Oral Torah. Afterwards, "And hear, O Israel," is the hearing in the new way, which they merited at the giving of the Torah, and so it is with every individual in Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the dual aspects of listening and understanding within the Jewish tradition, represented by the names Jacob and Israel. It emphasizes the importance of refining one's knowledge of good and evil, which is achieved through the Torah, likened to the Tree of Life. The text highlights that the potential for spiritual growth is inherent within each individual, needing to be actualized, particularly through the experiences of exile and redemption. Ultimately, it connects the historical context of the Jewish people with the ongoing process of spiritual elevation and revelation through the Torah.

passage_content: בפסוק ויחי יעקב בא"מ שבע עשרה שנה. גימ' טוב לומר כי יעקב בירר כל התערובות שעיקר גלות מצרים הי' לברר תערובת טוב ורע וע"ז נק' כור הברזל. אבל יעקב כתי' בי' הגואל אותי מכל רע ואפי' במצרים לא הי' לו מגע רע וזה הי' הכנה לגאולה:
translation: In the verse "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years," it is good to say that Jacob clarified all the mixtures, for the essence of the Egyptian exile was to clarify the mixture of good and evil, and for this reason it is called the iron furnace. However, Jacob wrote, "He who redeems me from all evil," and even in Egypt, he did not have contact with evil, and this was a preparation for redemption.
summary: In the passage, it is emphasized that Jacob's life in Egypt, lasting seventeen years, was a period of refining the mixture of good and evil, akin to the process of purification in a furnace. Jacob's declaration of being redeemed from all evil signifies that even in Egypt, he remained untouched by negativity. This state of spiritual purity served as a preparation for the eventual redemption of the Jewish people. The text highlights the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of maintaining faith and righteousness amidst challenges.

passage_content: בפסוק ויקרא יעקב א"ב כו' האספו ואגידה. ובמדרש מהיכן זכו ישראל לק"ש מיעקב ע"ש. דכתי' וזאת אשר דיבר להם אביהם שמסר להם כח הדיבור. שבזה הכח מעידין בנ"י על הבורא וכתי' שפת אמת תכון כו'. יעקב הוא האמת כדכ' תתן אמת ליעקב. והשבטים הם שפת אמת כי הדיבור נשלם ע"י השפתים. ומקודם הי' שפה אחת ובדור הפלגה ע"י שלא היו דבוקים באמת ניטל מהם כח הדיבור ונשאר רק לבנ"י. וכ' אתם עדי נאום ה' פי' בכח כ"ב אותיות ולשון הקודש שנמסר לבנ"י לשון שמה"ש משתמשין בו והוא א' מהדברים שדומה האדם לעליונים שמדבר בלשון הקודש. וזה החילוק בין שפה לשפת כי השפתים הם להשלים הדיבור וגם לסתום ולהעציר מה שא"צ לדבר ולגלות. שפה ה' פתוחה. ושפת בת' סתומה עד לעתיד דכ' אז אהפוך כו' שפה ברורה. ובאמת ע"י שפת אמת של בנ"י יהי' כל התיקון לעתיד. וזה תכון לעד פועל יוצא שע"י שפת אמת יתתקנו כל הלשונות. וזה כח לשון הקודש הנחיל יעקב לבניו. וע"ז כתי' זכור ימו"ע כו' שאל אביך ויגדך כמ"ש ואגידה לכם. ובנ"י צריכין בכל יום לבקש האמת ומתגלה להם כדכ' תתן אמת ליעקב לשון הוה בכל יום בכח קריאת שמע. [ולכן מברכין קודם ק"ש הבוחר בעמו ישראל ע"ש שבחר בנו מכל הלשונות כמ"ש יצב גבולות עמים למב"י חלק ה' עמו. ויצאנו מן הכלל ללמד על הכלל כולו ולתקן כל הלשונות כדפרש"י ה' שהוא עתה אלקינו עתיד להיות מבורר בכל העמים]:
translation: In the verse "And Jacob called his sons" (Genesis 49:1), "Assemble and I will tell you." And in the Midrash, from where did Israel merit the Shema from Jacob, as it is written: "And this is what their father spoke to them," he imparted to them the power of speech. With this power, the Children of Israel testify about the Creator, as it is written, "The lips of truth shall be established." Jacob is the truth, as it is written, "You shall give truth to Jacob." And the tribes are the lips of truth because speech is completed through the lips. Previously, there was one language, and in the generation of the Tower of Babel, because they were not united in truth, the power of speech was taken from them and remained only with the Children of Israel. And it is written, "You are My witnesses, says the Lord," meaning through the power of the 22 letters and the Holy Language that was given to the Children of Israel, a language that the heavenly beings use, and this is one of the things that makes man similar to the higher beings, that he speaks in the Holy Language. This is the distinction between "language" and "lips," for the lips are to complete speech and also to seal and restrain what is unnecessary to speak and reveal. A "language" is open, while "lips" are closed until the future, as it is written, "Then I will turn to the peoples a pure language." And indeed, through the lips of truth of the Children of Israel, all rectification will come in the future. And this "shall be established forever," an outcome that through the lips of truth, all languages will be rectified. And this is the power of the Holy Language that Jacob bequeathed to his sons. And for this, it is written, "Remember the day of Shabbat," etc., "Ask your father and he will tell you," as it is said, "And I will tell you." And the Children of Israel need to seek the truth every day, and it is revealed to them, as it is written, "You shall give truth to Jacob," a language that is present every day through the power of the Shema. [And therefore, we bless before the Shema, "Who chooses His people Israel," because He chose us from all the languages, as it is said, "He set the boundaries of the nations for the sake of His people," and we have emerged from the general to teach about the whole and to rectify all languages, as Rashi explains, "He who is now our God will be clarified among all nations."]
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Shema, emphasizing that Jacob imparted the power of speech to the Israelites, enabling them to testify to God's existence. It highlights the concept of "Shfat Emet" (the language of truth) as a means of connecting with the divine, contrasting it with the confusion of languages at the Tower of Babel. The text asserts that through the holy language, the Jewish people can achieve spiritual rectification and that their daily recitation of the Shema is a call to seek and reveal truth. Ultimately, it underscores the unique role of the Jewish people in restoring the purity of language and connecting all nations to God.

passage_content: ויהי יעקב בא"מ. מו"ז ז"ל אמר כי ע"י מדת יעקב האמת יכולין למצוא החיות גם בא"מ עכ"ד. ויתכן ג"כ לפרש כי יעקב מצא האמת גם במצרים והכין יעקב בגלות מצרים דרך למצוא האמת בכל הד' גליות דאיתא במד' אמת אמר אל יברא דהוא עלמא דשיקרא ותשלך אמת ארצה ע"ש. והרמז שזה הי' אבידה מדעת שהשליך האמת בארציות וגשמיות הטבע. וגם התורה נתלבשה במצות מעשיות. וזה עיקר האמת אין אמת אלא תורה. וזה עבודת איש ישראל למצוא זו האבידה ואז אמת מארץ תצמח ר"ת אמת. ואיתא בזוה"ק תרומה בענין הד' אמת בברכת אמת ויציב שהקב"ה הבטיח לכנס"י ביצי"מ לד' גאולות בד' גליות. לכן ד' לשונות של גאולה ביצי"מ. וביאר שם דיש ד' אמת למעלה וד' אמת למטה. והם ב' הבחי' של האבות והשבטים כי האבות הן המרכבה והם דבקים בעצם האמת. והשבטים עומדין על הגבולים והם ד' דגלים. ועליהם נאמר שפת אמת תכון לעד. ואיתא בזוה"ק תשא. עתידה דתכון ועתה שיקרא שלטא. והוא בחי' שפת אמת של השבטים שאחודים באמת כמ"ש ויקרא יעקב אל בניו והוא לשון חיבור ודביקות שמדרגת השבטים מחובר אל בחי' האבות. והם שומרים בחי' האמת של האבות שלא להתפשט במקום הסט"א. ועתיד להתגלות האמת בכל העולם בכח בנ"י. וע"ז מעידין בכל יום שמע ישראל שעתיד להיות ה' אחד גם לכל האומות כמ"ש אז אהפוך כו' שפה ברורה. וזה הרמז במד' מסיר שפה לנאמנים שרצה יעקב לגלות הקץ. כמ"ש אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים פי' שבסוף גם כל העולם כט) יהי' להם דביקות והתקשרות בישראל. וזו השפה אחת רצה יעקב לגלות לבניו ולפי שעדיין לא הי' ניתקן העולם. מסיר הקב"ה שפה שלא להתפשט האמת בעלמא דשיקרא עד לעתיד דיהי' תכון לעד: וב' בחי' אמת הנ"ל הם בחי' אמת ויציב שחרית שהוא בחי' יוסף כמ"ש במ"א ואמת ואמונה ערבית שהוא יהודה והשבטים. וכן הפריש יעקב מלבד שכלל ליוסף בהקריאה לבניו. כ' בפ"ע ויקרא לבנו ליוסף שהוא דביקות בפ"ע במדרגה שלמעלה. שים כו' ידך תחת ירכי להיות נמשך אחריו. ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת. כי ב' אלו הנחיל הקב"ה ליעקב כמ"ש החסדים כו' האמת אשר עשית את עבדך. ופרשנו שם שבאמצעיות יעקב יורד החסד ואמת לעולם. וכמו כן פי' הכתוב כאן ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת באמצעיות זה הכח שהוריש לו אביו מתגלגל החסד ואמת בעולם. וד' אמת האחרונים הם בחי' אמת ואמונה בחי' שפת אמת דעתידה להיות תכון לעד:
translation: And it came to pass that Jacob was in the land of Egypt. Our master, may his memory be blessed, said that through the attribute of Jacob, which is truth, one can find life even in the land of Egypt, thus he said. It is also possible to explain that Jacob found the truth even in Egypt and that Jacob prepared in the exile of Egypt a way to find the truth in all four exiles, as it is stated in the Midrash: "Truth said, 'Do not create me,' for it is a world of falsehood," and "He cast truth to the ground," referring to this being a loss of knowledge, having cast truth into the materiality and physicality of nature. And the Torah is also clothed in practical commandments. This is the essence of truth; there is no truth except the Torah. And this is the work of a Jew to find this loss, and then "Truth will spring forth from the earth," which is an acronym for truth. And it is stated in the Zohar, Terumah, regarding the four truths in the blessing of "Truth and Established," that the Holy One, blessed be He, promised the congregation of Israel in the exile of Egypt four redemptions in the four exiles. Therefore, there are four expressions of redemption in the exile of Egypt. It is explained there that there are four truths above and four truths below. They correspond to the two aspects of the patriarchs and the tribes, for the patriarchs are the chariot and they are attached to the essence of truth. The tribes stand on the borders, and they are the four banners. Concerning them, it is said, "The lips of truth will be established forever." And it is stated in the Zohar, Tetzaveh, that in the future it will be established, and now falsehood reigns. This is the aspect of the lips of truth of the tribes, who are united in truth, as it is said, "And Jacob called his sons," which is a language of connection and attachment, indicating that the level of the tribes is connected to the aspect of the patriarchs. They guard the aspect of the truth of the patriarchs so that it does not spread in the realm of the Other Side. And the truth will be revealed throughout the world through the power of the children of Israel. And for this, they testify every day, "Hear, O Israel," that in the future, the Lord will be one for all nations, as it is said, "Then I will turn..." a clear language. This is the hint in the Midrash, "He removes the language from the faithful," that Jacob wanted to reveal the end, as it is said, "That which will be called upon you in the end of days," meaning that in the end, the whole world will have attachment and connection to Israel. And this one language is what Jacob wanted to reveal to his sons, and because the world had not yet been rectified, the Holy One, blessed be He, removes the language so that the truth does not spread in the world of falsehood until the future when it will be established forever. And the two aspects of truth mentioned above are the aspect of "Truth and Established" in the morning, which is the aspect of Joseph, as explained elsewhere, and "Truth and Faith" in the evening, which is Judah and the tribes. Thus, Jacob distinguished, aside from including Joseph in the calling to his sons, as it is written, "And he called his son Joseph," which is an attachment in itself at the level above. "Put your hand under my thigh to be drawn after him." "And you will do kindness and truth with me." For these two, the Holy One, blessed be He, bequeathed to Jacob, as it is written, "The kindness..." and "the truth which you have done to your servant." And we explained there that through the mediacy of Jacob, kindness and truth descend into the world. And likewise, the verse here, "And you will do kindness and truth with me," in this mediacy, this is the power that his father bequeathed to him, drawing kindness and truth into the world. And the last four truths are the aspect of truth and faith, the aspect of the lips of truth that will be established forever.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of truth as embodied by Jacob, who finds and prepares a path for truth even in exile, particularly in Egypt. It emphasizes that the essence of truth is the Torah, which is manifested through the commandments, and that the Jewish people's mission is to recover this lost truth. The text also highlights the connection between the patriarchs and the tribes, with the tribes serving as guardians of the truth, ultimately leading to a future revelation of divine truth to all nations. Jacob's desire to reveal the end of days reflects the belief that a unified language of truth will prevail in the world, culminating in a time when God's oneness is recognized universally.
