passage_content: בפסוק ועתה שני בניך כו'. ועתה הוא המשכת דרך חדש. לכן איתא ועתה לשון תשובה. לפי שבעל תשובה צריך להמשיך דרך חדש לתקן מה שקלקל. וכן עשה כאן יעקב דרך חדש והעלה בני יוסף להיות להם דביקות באבות כמ"ש ויקרא בהם שמי ושם אבותי. אבל מולדתך כו' ע"ש אחיהם יקראו. שדביקות הע' נפש הוא בהי"ב שבטים והי"ב שבטים דבקים במדרגת האבות. והעלה את מנשה ואפרים לתוך השבטים. ויוסף הועלה למעלה ממדרגת השבטים כמ"ש שכם אחד על אחיך:
translation: In the verse "And now your two sons..." "And now" signifies the continuation of a new path. Therefore, it is stated that "and now" is a term of repentance. This is because a penitent must continue a new path to rectify what was spoiled. Thus, here Jacob established a new path and elevated the sons of Joseph to have a connection with the Patriarchs, as it is said, "And I will call upon them by my name and the name of my fathers." But your birthplace... in the name of their brothers they will be called. The connection of the 70 souls is with the 12 tribes, and the 12 tribes are connected to the level of the Patriarchs. He elevated Manasseh and Ephraim into the tribes, and Joseph was elevated above the level of the tribes, as it is said, "A single shoulder above your brothers."
summary: In this passage, the concept of "עתה" (now) signifies a new path and the idea of repentance, where one must create a new way to rectify past mistakes. Jacob's act of elevating Joseph's sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, to the status of tribes reflects the importance of connecting to the patriarchs and achieving spiritual unity. This elevation illustrates the notion that true devotion and connection to the divine can transcend previous limitations, as Joseph is raised above the tribes, symbolizing a higher spiritual level. Ultimately, the passage emphasizes the significance of renewal and the potential for spiritual elevation through connection to one's roots.

passage_content: בפסוק כל אלה שבטי ישראל י"ב וזאת אשר דיבר כו' איש אשר כברכתו כו'. עיקר הברכה היא כל כמו שנתברכו אבותינו בכל מכל כל. וזה הכל הוא קיום כל הבריאה. וכ' כל אשר חפץ ה' עשה בשמים ובארץ בימים. וזה הרצון והחפץ הוא קיום הכל ונמסר הכל לאבות ובנ"י אחריהם. והוא ג"כ ברכת השבת דכ' ששת ימים עשה כו' השמים כו' הארץ כו' הים כו' וינח ביום השביעי שהוא עיקר חפץ ה' לכן ויברך אותו. וז"ש בקידו' ורצה בנו. וכ"כ אתם תהיו ארץ חפץ וכ' אם חפץ בנו ה' לכן מסר לנו השבת שהוא אות שחפץ בנו ה' ויכולין בנ"י למצוא רצונו ית' בכל מקום ובכל עת וזהו עצמו הברכה. ואיתא במדרש שלשה ברכות נתברכו בנ"י לאברהם נאמר כה יהי' זרעך ככוכבי השמים וליצחק כחול א"ע שפת הים. ליעקב כעפר הארץ. וזה הג' כל הנ"ל כ"א חפץ ה' עשה כו'. והם עצמם בחי' השלשה סעודות בשבת. שלשה ברכות הנ"ל. ואלו הג' בחי' הנחיל יעקב לי"ב השבטים. וז"ש כל אלה כו' וזאת אשר דיבר להם שהמשיך להם זה הכל. והוא עצמו וזאת אשר דיבר להם. שנק' כל ונקרא זאת הברכה. איש אשר כברכתו. איש. ר"ת. ארץ ים שמים. שכמו שיש י"ב גבולין בארץ לי"ב שבטים. כמו כן לי"ב גזרים נגזר להם הים. וכמו כן יש בשמים י"ב שערים מול הי"ב שבטים. וגם ג' אלו הי"ב. בארץ וים ושמים. הם גימ' אלה:
translation: In the verse "All these are the tribes of Israel, twelve," and "This is what he spoke," etc., "A man according to his blessing," etc. The essence of the blessing is all, as our forefathers were blessed in everything, from all to all. And this all is the sustenance of all creation. And it is written, "All that the Lord desires, He has done in heaven and on earth, in the seas." And this will and desire is the sustenance of everything, and all was entrusted to the forefathers and to the Children of Israel after them. It is also the blessing of the Sabbath, as it is written, "For six days He made," etc., "the heavens," etc., "the earth," etc., "the sea," etc., "and He rested on the seventh day," which is the essence of the Lord's desire; therefore, He blessed it. And this is what is said in the Kiddush, "and He desired us." And it is also written, "You shall be a land of desire," and "If the Lord desires us," therefore He entrusted us with the Sabbath, which is a sign that the Lord desires us, and the Children of Israel can find His will everywhere and at all times, and this itself is the blessing. And it is stated in the Midrash that three blessings were bestowed upon the Children of Israel: to Abraham it was said, "So shall your seed be as the stars of heaven," and to Isaac, "as the sand of the sea," and to Jacob, "as the dust of the earth." And these three, all of the above, are each the desire of the Lord. And they themselves are the three meals of the Sabbath, the three blessings mentioned above. And these three are the inheritance that Jacob bequeathed to the twelve tribes. And this is what is meant by "All these," etc., "and this is what he spoke to them," that he extended to them this all. And it is itself "And this is what he spoke to them," which is called all and is called this blessing, "A man according to his blessing." "A man" is an acronym for "land, sea, heavens." Just as there are twelve boundaries in the land for the twelve tribes, so too, twelve decrees were decreed for them from the sea. And likewise, there are twelve gates in heaven corresponding to the twelve tribes. And these three, the twelve in land, sea, and heavens, are the gematria of "these."
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept of divine blessing as a fundamental aspect of creation, linking the blessings given to the patriarchs with the sustenance of the world. It highlights the significance of the Sabbath as a manifestation of God's desire for His people, symbolizing their connection to His will. The three blessings bestowed upon the patriarchs—Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—are paralleled with the three meals of Shabbat, representing the inheritance passed down to the twelve tribes. Ultimately, the text illustrates the interconnectedness of land, sea, and heaven, each corresponding to the twelve tribes, reflecting the completeness of God's creation and His ongoing relationship with Israel.

passage_content: בפסוק הקבצו ושמעו כו' ושמעו אל ישראל כו'. ב' השמיעות כמ"ש אם שמוע בישן תשמעו בחדש. וכ' שמעי בת כו' אח"כ והטי אזנך. היא שמיעה פנימיות מילין דאתאמרין בלחישה שצריכין להטות אוזן לשמעם. כי באמת גם קודם קבלת התורה. הצדיקים שמעו דברי אלקים חיים בעולם מצד הבריאה ועשרה מאמרות. דכל מה שברא הקב"ה בעולמו לא ברא אלא לכבודו. והחכם עיניו בראשו איך להכיר את הבורא מתוך הבריאה. וזו השמיעה הראשונה. וכאשר בנ"י היו כלים לזה ושמעו זאת זכו אח"כ לקבלת התורה שמיעה הפנימיות. לכן אמר שמעו בני יעקב שהם מוכנים לשמיעה זו ויזכו אח"כ לשמיעה פנימיות. ושמעו אל ישראל אביכם. פי' במד' לאלקי ישראל אביכם. הוא שמיעה המיוחדת רק לבנ"י זהו והטי אזנך שמיוחד רק אליך וז"ש במדרש שמעה עמי ואדברה. אין מעידין אלא בשומע. ואיך יתכן להיות שומע קודם הדיבור רק הוא השמיעה הראשונה הנ"ל. וז"ש עושי דברו לשמוע בקול דברו:
translation: In the verse "Gather and hear... and hear, O Israel...". There are two types of hearing, as it is said, "If you will listen in the old, you will hear in the new." And it is written, "Listen, my daughter..." and afterwards, "Incline your ear." This is an inner hearing of the words that are spoken in a whisper, which requires one to incline their ear to hear them. For indeed, even before the giving of the Torah, the righteous heard the words of the living God in the world through creation and the ten utterances. For all that the Holy One, blessed be He, created in His world, He created only for His glory. And the wise person has their eyes in their head, how to recognize the Creator from the creation. And this is the first hearing. And when the Children of Israel were prepared for this and heard it, they merited afterwards to receive the Torah, which is the inner hearing. Therefore, it is said, "Hear, O sons of Jacob," for they are prepared for this hearing and will merit afterwards to the inner hearing. "And hear, O Israel, your father." This means, as it is explained in the Midrash, to the God of Israel, your father. This is a hearing that is unique only to the Children of Israel; this is "Incline your ear," which is special only to you. And this is what is said in the Midrash, "Hear, O My people, and I will speak." One can only testify if they have heard. And how can it be that one hears before the speaking? It is only the first hearing mentioned above. And this is what is said, "Those who do His word, to hear the voice of His word."
summary: The passage discusses the dual aspects of hearing in the context of receiving the Torah, emphasizing the importance of internalizing divine communication. It highlights that even before the giving of the Torah, the righteous were attuned to God's words through creation, recognizing His presence in the world. The text underscores that the Jewish people, prepared for deeper spiritual understanding, are called to listen to God's voice uniquely, which is a special privilege granted to them. Ultimately, true listening is portrayed as an active engagement with divine will, leading to a profound connection with the Creator.

passage_content: עוד לפסוק הנ"ל האספו ואגידה הקבצו ושמעו. וכבר כ' מזה במ"א כי האספו בחי' הנשמה והנפשות נאמר בהם אסיפה כמו נאסף אל עמי והוא בחי' עמידה בתפלה לכן מקדימין ופי יגיד תהלתך שהתפלה למשוך המשכות מלמעלה. ז"ש ואגידה לכם. הקבצו הוא אחדות הגופות. וזהו ק"ש. רמ"ח תיבות נגד רמ"ח אברים. ושמעו הוא ק"ש שצריך איש ישראל לעסוק בכל יום בב' בחי' אחדות הנ"ל בגוף ונפש. והנה הסדר ק"ש אח"כ תפלה. ומה שהקדים יעקב בחי' האספו שהי' סבור שהם מוכנים למדרגה גבוה. וכאשר נסתלקה ממנו שכינה ראה שהם במדרגה שלמטה מזו ואמר הקבצו ושמעו:
translation: Further to the aforementioned verse, "Assemble and I will tell you; gather and hear." It has already been written about this elsewhere that "assemble" refers to the aspect of the soul and the souls, as it is said, "gathered to his people," which is the aspect of standing in prayer. Therefore, they precede "and my mouth will declare Your praise," for prayer is to draw down influences from above. This is what is meant by "and I will tell you." "Gather" refers to the unity of the bodies, and this is the Shema. The 248 words correspond to the 248 limbs. "And hear" refers to the Shema, which a Jewish person must engage in every day in both aspects of the aforementioned unity, in body and soul. And behold, the order is Shema followed by prayer. And the reason Jacob preceded the aspect of "assemble" was that he thought they were prepared for a higher level. But when the Shechinah departed from him, he saw that they were at a level lower than that and said, "gather and hear."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of gathering (אספו) and unity (קבצו) in the context of prayer and the Shema, emphasizing the connection between the soul and the body. It highlights that the act of gathering represents the spiritual elevation of the soul, while the unity of bodies is reflected in the recitation of the Shema, which corresponds to the physical aspects of worship. The sequence of reciting the Shema followed by prayer illustrates the progression from spiritual readiness to divine connection. Ultimately, it reflects Jacob's realization of the need for unity and preparation among the people, as he perceived their spiritual state was lower than expected.

passage_content: במדרש יהודה אתה יודוך אחיך כולן נקראו על שמך יהודים ע"ש. דיעקב אע"ה כתיב בי' תתן אמת ליעקב והוא מתנה בעלמא דשיקרא. אך בנ"י הם מאמינים בני מאמינים ובזו האמונה יכול כל איש ישראל להתדבק באמת. וזהו בחי' הודאה מודה על האמת להיות נמשך עכ"פ אחר האמת. וע"י הברכות והודאות ושבחות בפה זוכין אל האמת. וזה כח הפה שלא נברא אלא להודות. וזה ניתן ליהודה ודוד המלך ע"ה נעים זמירות ישראל. וזה כח הפה נפתח בש"ק. לכן נאמר בו טוב להודות לה' ושבת סהדותא איקרי:
translation: In the Midrash, Judah, you will be praised; your brothers are all called by your name, Jews, in your honor. For it is written regarding Jacob, may peace be upon him, "You shall give truth to Jacob," and this is a mere gift of falsehood. However, the children of Israel are believers, the children of believers, and through this faith, every Jewish person can cling to the truth. This is the aspect of acknowledgment, admitting the truth, to be drawn, at least, after the truth. And through blessings, acknowledgments, and praises spoken with the mouth, one merits the truth. This is the power of the mouth, which was created only to give thanks. And this was given to Judah, and King David, may peace be upon him, is the sweet singer of Israel. And this power of the mouth is opened on Shabbat. Therefore, it is said, "It is good to give thanks to the Lord," and Shabbat is called a testimony.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of gratitude and acknowledgment of truth in the Jewish faith, particularly through the lineage of Judah, from whom King David descends. It highlights that the Jewish people, as "believers, children of believers," possess the ability to connect with truth through their faith. The act of verbal praise and blessings is seen as a means to attain this truth, with the mouth being created specifically for the purpose of expressing gratitude. The text also notes that the Sabbath is a special time for such acknowledgments, reinforcing the idea that recognizing and thanking God is central to spiritual life.

passage_content: בפסוק הקבצו ושמעו בנ"י ושמעו אל ישראל אביכם. ב' השמיעות כמ"ש שמוע תשמעו שמוע בישן תשמעו בחדש. כי העוסק בתורה לשמה מתחדשין הדברים. ונפתח בהם סודות הגנוזים בהם. לכן תשמעו כמו פועל יוצא. וכמו כן הפי' בכאן ושמעו אל ישראל פועל יוצא כמו המחכים את רבו. כי לפי הכנתם כך יהי' נשמע לישראל אביכם. ואחז"ל ביושב והוגה בתורה הקב"ה יושב ושונה כנגדו. ולכן מקודם כ' בני יעקב ואח"כ אל ישראל. כי זה עצמו ב' השמות. שזכה יעקב לשם חדש ישראל. כי השם הוא הענין שנברא עליו לתקנו וכאשר תיקן שמו בשלימות זכה לשם חדש. וב' אלו השמות נשארו בכלל ישראל שנקראו יעקב וישראל. ושם ישראל הוא בש"ק לכן זוכין בו לנשמה יתירה והוא התחדשות הבא מלמעלה. והנה יצחק הנחיל ליעקב הקול כמ"ש הקול קול יעקב. ויעקב הנחיל לבניו הדיבור כדכ' וזאת אשר דיבר להם. כי הדיבור הוא התפשטות הארת הקול אל פרטי הנהגה שבעוה"ז. וזה צריך שמירה ונמסר לי"ב שבטים שהם עומדים על הגבולים. וכפי תיקון הדיבור כך שורה עליו בחי' הקול שהוא מדרגה שלמעלה. וכ' תתן אמת ליעקב והיא עצם התורה. והשבטים הם בחי' י"ג מדות שהתורה נדרשת בהם שע"י אלה המדות באים אל האמת. כמו שע"י המדות ק"ו גז"ש משיגין הלכה אמתיות שבתורה. כמו כן הוא בפנימיות שע"י המדות יכולים לבוא אל האמת. ואיתא במדרש יהודה אתה יודוך אחיך שכל ישראל נקראו על שמו יהודים ע"ש כי מדת יהודה הוא מודה על האמת. ובחי' יוסף דובר אמת בלבבו. והוא התקרבות ביותר אל האמת. אבל בחי' הודאה על האמת נמצא בכל איש ישראל הגם שמרוחק מן האמת אבל מודה ומשתוקק לבוא אל האמת. כי האמת נעדרת בעוה"ז עלמא דשיקרא. וא"י להכיר האמת רק כפי כח רושם אלקיות שנמצא בנפשות בנ"י כמ"ש ה' אלקים אמת. וכפי הארת הנפש אלקיות באדם זוכה אל האמת. וע"י היגיעה בי"ג מדות שהתורה נדרשת בהם באים אל האמת כמ"ש יגעתי ומצאתי תאמין. מציאה הוא הנעדר בעולם והוא האמת כנ"ל:
translation: In the verse "Gather and hear, O sons of Jacob, and listen to Israel your father," there are two forms of hearing, as it is said, "You shall surely hear," meaning you will hear in the old way and you will hear in the new way. For one who engages in the Torah for its own sake, the matters are renewed, and the hidden secrets within them are revealed. Therefore, "hear" is like a direct object. Similarly, the interpretation here, "and listen to Israel," is a direct object, like one who waits for his teacher. For according to their preparation, so will it be heard by Israel your father. And our sages said, "One who sits and studies the Torah, the Holy One, blessed be He, sits and learns opposite him." Therefore, it first says "sons of Jacob" and afterwards "to Israel," for these are two names. Jacob earned the new name Israel because the name is the matter for which he was created to rectify, and when he perfected his name in completeness, he earned a new name. These two names remain among all of Israel, who are called Jacob and Israel. The name Israel is on Shabbat, therefore they merit an additional soul, which is the renewal that comes from above. And behold, Isaac bequeathed to Jacob the voice, as it is said, "The voice is the voice of Jacob." And Jacob bequeathed to his sons the speech, as it is written, "And this is what he spoke to them." For speech is the expansion of the light of the voice into the particulars of guidance in this world. This requires guarding and was entrusted to the twelve tribes, who stand at the borders. According to the rectification of speech, so does the aspect of the voice dwell upon him, which is a level that is higher. And it is written, "You shall give truth to Jacob," and this is the essence of the Torah. The tribes are the aspect of the thirteen attributes through which the Torah is interpreted, and by these attributes, they come to the truth. Just as through the attributes, one can derive logical conclusions and scriptural comparisons to attain true halachot in the Torah, so too in the inner aspect, through the attributes, one can come to the truth. And it is stated in the Midrash, "Judah, you shall be praised by your brothers," for all of Israel are called by his name, Jews, because the attribute of Judah is one who acknowledges the truth. And the aspect of Joseph speaks truth in his heart, and this is the closest approach to the truth. However, the aspect of acknowledgment of the truth is found in every Jew, even if he is distant from the truth, but he acknowledges and yearns to come to the truth. For the truth is absent in this world, the world of falsehood. And it cannot recognize the truth except according to the power of the divine impression found in the souls of the children of Israel, as it is said, "The Lord is God, truth." And according to the illumination of the divine soul in a person, he merits the truth. And through the effort in the thirteen attributes through which the Torah is interpreted, they come to the truth, as it is said, "I toiled and found, you should believe." Finding is the absent in the world, and it is the truth, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage emphasizes the duality of the names "Yaakov" and "Yisrael," representing different spiritual states, with "Yisrael" signifying a higher level of divine connection and renewal. It highlights the importance of studying Torah for its own sake, which reveals hidden secrets and allows for a deeper understanding of truth. The text also discusses the role of the tribes, particularly Judah and Joseph, in embodying and acknowledging truth, suggesting that even those distanced from truth possess an innate desire to connect with it. Ultimately, it asserts that through diligent study and the application of the thirteen attributes of interpretation, one can attain a deeper grasp of the ultimate truth, which is often obscured in the material world.

passage_content: בפסוק האספו ואגידה לכם. ובמדרש שזכו מכאן לק"ש כו'. דאיתא כל כנסי' שהיא לש"ש סופה להתקיים. והנה כנסי' זו בוודאי הי' לש"ש ולכן היא קיימת לעד וכמ"ש אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים שאסיפה זו הי' הכנה לכל הדורות. וגם מה שקיבלו אח"כ התורה הי' בכח זה כמ"ש מורשה קהלת יעקב. ובכל אסיפה לש"ש מסייע כוחו של יעקב דיעקב כלול הוא כדאיתא בזוה"ק. ולכן בש"ק שהוא זמן אסיפה זוכין לנחלת יעקב. והרי כל ישראל נקראו ע"ש יעקב וישראל. א"כ כל השורש מכנסי' הוא יעקב ולכן אמר בקהלם אל תחד כבודי שידע שכל הקהילות מתאספין בכוחו ואמר שלא תחד כבודי הואיל ולא הי' לשם שמים דכתיב תתן אמת ליעקב וכנסי' שהיא לש"ש נקראת אמת כמ"ש וה' אלקים אמת והוא מתקיים. וקריאת שמע היא מתוך אסיפת כלל ישראל כי העדות על הקב"ה אינו באיש יחידי רק כלל ישראל. וכמ"ש שמע ישראל שמע הוא קיבוץ ואסיפה וחל ע"ז שם ה' אלקינו וסופה להתקיים כמ"ש שפת אמת תכון לעד:
translation: In the verse "Gather and I will tell you," the Midrash teaches that from here they merited the Shema, etc. It is stated that any gathering that is for the sake of Heaven will ultimately endure. And this gathering was certainly for the sake of Heaven, and therefore it exists forever, as it is written, "that He will call you in the end of days," for this assembly was a preparation for all generations. Moreover, what they later received, the Torah, was through this power, as it is written, "an inheritance for the congregation of Jacob." In every gathering for the sake of Heaven, the strength of Jacob is assisted, for Jacob is included in all, as it is stated in the Zohar. Therefore, on Shabbat, which is a time of gathering, we merit the inheritance of Jacob. And behold, all of Israel is called by the name of Jacob and Israel. Thus, the entire root of the gathering is Jacob, and therefore he said, "In their assembly do not diminish my honor," so that it would be known that all the communities gather through his strength. And he said, "do not diminish my honor" because it was not for the sake of Heaven, as it is written, "You shall give truth to Jacob," and a gathering that is for the sake of Heaven is called truth, as it is said, "And the Lord God is truth," and it endures. The recitation of the Shema is from the gathering of all of Israel, for the testimony of the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not come from an individual, but from all of Israel. As it is said, "Hear, O Israel," "Hear" is a gathering and assembly, and upon this the name of the Lord our God rests, and it will ultimately endure, as it is said, "The lips of truth shall be established forever."
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of communal gatherings for the sake of Heaven, asserting that such assemblies are destined to endure, as they embody the essence of truth and divine purpose. It highlights the connection between these gatherings and the legacy of Jacob, whose name symbolizes the collective identity of Israel. The recitation of the Shema is presented as a communal testimony to God's unity, reinforcing the idea that true acknowledgment of God arises from the collective voice of the Jewish people. Ultimately, the text underscores that gatherings dedicated to divine service are rooted in the eternal truth of God's presence among Israel.
